title: Why Most People Will Never Be Great At PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
Today, there is a powerful and disturbing story in NYTimes about UNC’s  pediatric cardiac surgery unit. It had a much higher death rate than other similar programs.   There was many lessons here in terms of why failure persisted and flaws were so slow to remediate. I want to focus on just 1 now. But there is much to be garnered from this investigative piece about other failures, including in education, airplane manufacturing and pharmacology.   The doctors at UNC at several points considered sending patients elsewhere and one physician is quoted as asking:  Would you send your own child here? Once the answer had been yes and then it turned to no. Lesson: if you wouldn’t send your own child here, don’t send anyone else’s.  The litmus year of quality is whether you or your family would use the services or product.  Consider that question at Boeing with its Max plane. Consider that question at some schools and colleges. The question begs institutions to turn into somewhere or something they’d encourage their family to use (assuming appropriateness as surely you’d only use a pediatric cardiac team if your child needed that).   Quality can be measured, then, by whether one would recommend the service/product for one’s own.  So Boeing, did you or your families fly on the Max? 
 
 
 …see more

title: POLITICAL Smackdown!
content:
So I wanted to share several things -- seemingly different but related.  The Cookery in Shirlington (Arlington) VA is having an event June 1 starting at noon in their remarkable cooking/food store for International Children's Day. And, they will be making a donation to Save the Children. I will be doing a book reading and signing at this event -- with two of my newest children's books. There will be food, fun and activities. One of the goals is to enable children to appreciate the fun that can come from engaged reading and the books are meant to achieve that.  Also, given the starvation and deaths of children across the globe, it is worth pausing and reflecting on what we can do to improve the lives of the next generation -- near and far. There is homelessness and food scarcity in many areas -- hidden and not so hidden poverty and a deep inequality for children in education too. That gets me to my next point: I will be at Molly Stark School in VT (which is I believe close to 100% free and reduced lunch) on June 3 to read and work with children.  I will be sharing one of the new books and helping kids appreciate the value of words and reading.  And, it is key to curb summer melt causing low income kids to fall behind while their wealthier peers progress ahead.   Come join us.

title: 10 Ways To Reinvent Your OPERATING SYSTEM
content:
Morehouse College Honorary Degree Recipient Robert F. Smith did an extraordinary thing: he announced that he and his family would pay the debt of every graduate.  He said he was part of the Class of 2019 and they all needed to start the next phase on a level field.  Wow! How remarkable, especially given that there was apparently no knowledge ahead of time that Mr. (now Doctor) would make that promise. What a gift. What an act of grace. What a way of paying it forward. And Mr. Smith wasn’t  a Morehouse alum! Forget how high the bar is for honorary degree recipients moving forward.  Forget the feelings of relief so many there experienced. Don’t forget that Morehouse is an HBCU that has struggled financially.  Don’t forget the powerful message of belief in graduates and their promising future as leaders. If I had a magic wand or billions of dollars (I don’t), I would repay the debt of every 2019 graduate of a college that is closing this year. Talk about a remarkable end. I understand the “last” Southern Vermont College graduation this weekend was moving and forward looking. I’m glad the event was so memorable. Now, here’s my other hope: that this will not be SVC’s last Commencement because other donors will see the value of small colleges.  That would be a remarkable gift.

The same newsletter noted that the Hermitage might be auctioned off.  What a contrast.  That got me thinking again of Southern Vermont College, founded in 1926.  This will be its 93rd commencement if my math is right.  And, I hope it is not its last.  I, along with others, am committed to seeing if this remarkable college can celebrate its 100th Commencement!   I get the challenges.  I get the tightness of the timetable.  But, I still believe.  Yes.  So, don't bury SVC yet.  It's funeral may come but not if I can help it.  At least my group will go down fighting hard.  Very hard.  If you don't try and don't believe, I can assure you nothing survives.  So, best to try and believe.  The other pathways foreshadow doom.  And, for the record, doom and lack of transparency aren't my thing.  Success is -- and I mean success not in the monetary sense. I mean in helping people become their best selves.  That's part of the SVC mission -- enabling people to realize on their potential.  How any anyone who believes in the mission NOT fight?

Well, this is a post of a different nature. Many moons ago, an old friend Steve Leveen asked if I would do a podcast where he interviewed me for his site and project: America the Bilingual.  I did but promptly forgot about the initiative until he just completed a podcast called Buds of Bilingualism and there I am speaking Icelandic.  It brought back memories, reminding me of my own tradition where I give the introduction to my remarks in the language of the nation where I am speaking. I had recently been in the Yakama Nation and started my remarks at Heritage University in Yakama. So, you are interested in how to use foreign language to develop cultural competency, this podcast's for you. Link's below.  But, for me, the podcast also raises a deeply troubling question in American education. We seem to look down at our non- or beginning English speaking students. Because they do not speak our language, we assume them to be "lesser."  Yet, they speak more languages than most Americans -- they speak their native language plus at least some English. So why do we denigrate others who speak a non-English language well and are learning English rapidly? Can you explain that?  Here's the podcast link:

title: Rules Not To Follow About PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
I want to share a concept in my new book on trauma that is  counter-intuitive.   When disasters strike like shootings at schools/colleges, we often go on lockdown and then release kids to families or older students to their dorms or homes.  We even shut down institutions. If the end of a school year is upon us, we wrap things up and folks depart. I think more attention needs to be paid to what I call “processing in place.”  Instead of separating people, we need to focus on and foster community.  Instead of going away, we need to go back and share with those who were there.   Ponder the experience of soldiers when they get stateside and lose their buddies.  Is that why vet suicides occur at VA hospital sites—the soldier is with others like them in some sense?   In the case  of UNC-Charlotte, the end of the semester is not trauma’s friend.  Perhaps the university will extend the semester, allowing students, faculty and staff to process in place — if they want that. How we process in place isn’t a simple idea and if space is tainted, that’s problematic.  More on those points later.  But you can’t process in place if you aren’t in place — physically or perhaps virtually.   Ponder the power of processing in place with me. 
 
 
 …see more

title: How You Can (Do) SCIENCE In 24 Hours Or Less For Free
content:
Folks, yesterday saw guilty pleas of a dozen or so wealthy parents and coaches for bribery, illegal money transfers across state lines, and tax fraud among other charges.  Felicity issued an apology, seemingly sincere.  Here's an idea I want to refloat:    When we get to the punishment phase, I want to reiterate the idea of a cy pres award. Elite colleges were harmed. True. But the whole incident shines a spotlight in inequality in education and across America. And, ironically, the bribes ostensibly went to help low income kids. Yup, that's the tax fraud part. So have those pleading guilty do just that: donate to a cy pres fund that benefits low income kids and the non-elite small colleges that serve them. Redistribute the cy pres to colleges with more than 40% Pell eligible students and/or 50% first gen students and under 1200 students and endowments under $10 million. Then use the funds for scholarships and institution sustainability. The cy pres agreement would be part of a court ordered settlement and the distribution could be decided by a cy pres committee or designated court appointed official. Make lemonade out of lemons. Force these parents to do what they actually said: give to help low income students. Do good from bad.

title: Old School SCIENCE
content:
I have often thought rich colleges could partner with less wealthy colleges — sort of academic adoption.  When endowment size was an issue that threatened their continuance, I thought this was an idea: invest in a neighboring small colleges and help them thrive and now survive.  No takers.  Williams wasn’t interested when I asked and their president then (not Morty Shapiro) showed overt disdain.  I actually chatted with famous Yale endowment advisor (Swensen) and he saw merit. That said, the rich get richer.  And small colleges that serve communities and students who are not going to elite colleges for any number of reasons, get poorer.  Sure, some small colleges are not being innovative and creative.  I still believe SVC can be saved and I continue to pursue different avenues regardless of naysayers.  Giving up isn’t in my vocabulary.  SVC didn’t train nurses and Rad techs to give up on patients.  We didn’t give up on students who struggled.  So, why give up on SVC?  Bravo to the author!

title: How You Can (Do) PROGRAMMING Almost Instantly
content:
So I am sitting in a crowd of strangers,  not in NE.  Someone asks what I do.  I say, which is partly accurate as of this moment in time, I am trying to save a small non elite college.  I explain that despite the current protestations and accusations, I left it after 8 years in good shape and fully capable survival.  In the 4 plus years since I left, it tanked.  And it fell precipitously in the last 2 years. Someone said, that’s impossible.  Colleges don’t crater and suddenly announce they’re shutting.  Something’s wrong. Something happened in the recent past. I said, well, maybe but more likely something didn’t happen: fundraising, grant raising, admissions, athletic recruiting, poor acquisitions.  But, I explained I hadn’t seen financials or data or what was filed with accreditors.  The group looked at me quizzically and I just looked at them and said, beats me.  My job now is to try to save it.  Anyone here have 3 million and want a college named for them? A few laughs and no immediate takers but one fellow said:  I bet there is someone like that.  I said:  I know.  I am looking for him or her right now. Funny how life is, isn’t it? What if one of those people was that one? Folks:  if you don’t try to save a place it will never be saved.

A quick post.   Saving a small college (saving anyone or anything) isn’t easy.  And it doesn’t always work.   But I am not done trying to save Southern Vermont College.  The final nail is not in the coffin.  And I want a replicable and scalable model given all the small non-elite colleges failing. Yes, the Board withdrew the appeal and everyone in power is focused on closing.  A “good” closure is important but it is not a victory. I still have ideas percolating.  I am not scared to think boldly and innovatively  and I understand risk.  Doug Flutie knows about Hail Marys.  Many have seen last second three pointers —  and guess what, sometimes they win the game. You don’t and can’t count on Hail Marys or three pointers when the clock is at 00.01.  So plan accordingly but don’t give up.  There is no reason NOT to keep trying. Isn’t that what we teach and preach?  Don’t give up.  Open new doors. Try.  Try again, even in the face of naysayers. So, April the Giraffe is giving birth and thousands are fascinated as nature takes its course and nature’s beauty abounds.  People by the thousands are glued to the giraffe cam. Unlike April, I am not patient and the birthing is filled with hurdles and mistruths that can’t be cured by the peppermint and pickles April is getting.   But, I’m not giving up. If April gives birth today, that’s a sign perhaps of another birth today.  Both the new giraffe and college will need nurturing and stability and care.  Both can get that. title: Revolutionize Your MUSIC With These Easy-peasy Tips
content:
Something is drastically wrong with college accreditation, both in terms of who is getting and maintaining accreditation and who is losing it.  Bennett College was cited for lack of resources; it had an opportunity to raise $$ before the appeal.  The goal was $5 million but over $9 million was raised. The accreditor was unimpressed apparently and said: this was not enough. It’s like moving the standard higher when you hit the mark.  How does that work?  Now consider the for profit college accreditor which was removed by the prior administration  for failure to identify quality educational gaps in the institutions it oversaw and playing favorites.  Under the current administration, this decision is being reversed.  Does anyone see the irony, the inequity, the unfairness to small private non profits? Since when can we reverse decisions or move the goal posts with such ease?  I’m worried about small college accreditation.  You should too.  I am worried about for profit accreditation.  You should too.  Does the fact that Bennett is an HBCU cut against them?   Just asking if big corporate educators can crush small historic places that serve students not shareholders. Someone  is up a creek with no paddle — because it was taken while someone else was given a paddle.  Hum.

title: Get Rid of FASHION DESIGN Once and For All
content:
Here's a lesson for leadership in a time of crisis:  When things go wrong, a leader needs to own the wrongs that have occurred.  It's easy to cast blame on others who held power in the past. But anyone holding a leadership position for more than a year or two has to take responsibility for current messes/mistakes. And, new leaders, this is hard and I know from experience and my own errors: you can only blame your predecessor and institutional bad acts for so long.  Once one gets the lay of the land, a leader owns the institution's past. Ownership is key to trustworthiness, the ability to live with oneself and to take real action.  Blame gets you nowhere. Why do I raise this now? With all the institutions struggling with one crisis or another, particularly in education, we can see the value of being forthright.  Stand up and own what went/is wrong. And, then take the steps needed to remedy the situation. Think Georgetown owning its slave past. Remarkable. Think Penn State not owning its silence. Troubling.  And, by the by, PR folks would agree: It's best for institutions moving forward if their leaders step forward. I wonder if we can get it to others who think about wrongdoing and the price we pay, and it also gives us insight into the feelings of immigrants and their children who are detained --- in their case, the only crime being seeking a new home without legal permission in most cases.  Hardly the equivalent of murder.   "Carruth’s poem began: Think about how many times you’ve been to the zoo Ever wonder how it would feel if one of the animals were you? I just want to say as the sun rises again that I feel sick to my stomach.  Truly sick. I can't even turn on TV or eat or listen or read. The debacle of yesterday -- and I missed the last hour --- will forever change how we view victims and those accused.  And we all know someone is lying. Both people who testified can't be truth tellers.  I know who I think is lying.  But, how people can obfuscate truth and play off emotions and act indignant -- professing that religion and religious schools carry righteousness in and of themselves -- is offensive no matter what.   I'd like to remind people that good folks can do bad things.  And bad people can do good things.  And, religion isn't like a vaccine -- religious people and doctors and teachers abuse children and when they do, those acts are buried and the victims' words discarded and truth is hard to find and even harder to address.   Everyone here can judge for themselves whether politics trumped truth.  That is my line for today: politics (whichever side you are on) trumped truth --- in every sense.

title: How To Win Friends And Influence People with ZOOLOGY
content:
I just want to say as the sun rises, what if Judge Kavanaugh had told a diff story about his GT Prep HS/ Yale days.  Suppose he indicated that, given his background, he was overtaken by the freedoms before him and drank and partied too much and in over-the-top ways. He was like an unstuck drawer. As he's matured, he has seen how his behavior was misguided (how much vomiting does one need to experience), and he hopes that his own children can grow up in a way that does not require that level of rebellion to find their way.   Now assuming no sexual assaults in this period (a huge leap of faith for me as I believe the victims), he would not have lied. He wouldn't have had former classmates crawling out of the walls; he wouldn't have had his yrbk words to defend; he wouldn't have done a FOX interview (when winning, silence is better; when offense is weak, put up a loud defense). He wouldn't be discussing his virginity (or anything close to intercourse), and he would have been honest. I repeat: he would have been honest. Painting oneself as a saint is a surefire method for people coming to destroy that image. Who's a saint after all? Once you lie, the lies keep growing. That's, sadly, the story of a lying nominee. He exhibited poor lawyering too. 
 
 
 …see more

title: The Secrets To Finding World Class Tools For Your MATHEMATICS Quickly

Assuming Dr. Ford testifies, I want to know how we can get people on the Judiciary Committee and in the Senate truly to listen. Could we put our R/D affiliation in a drawer and just listen and hear?  If the point of a hearing is to hear, then prejudging and announcing one's vote ahead of time or that Judge Kavanaugh will be appointed misses the point of a hearing. And why plow ahead?  We plow fields not people. I get the rush but do we do justice by rushing to find truth? One more thought:  Youthful indiscretion is not rare. What is bad here is: failure to own one's past; failure to apologize; lying. The Justices decide about real people; truth matters.  Truly matters.  So does integrity.  So does honesty.  Judge Kavanaugh is not being criminally charged (too late); but he bears burden of persuasion.  This isn't about innocent until proven guilty in a criminal trial. There is no trial. There is a hearing on fitness and integrity. Worth distinguishing and remembering. 
 
 
 …see more

title: Stop Wasting Time And Start GRAPHIC
content:
A recent article in the Boston Globe described the struggles of small colleges and their likely collapse in the not too distant future. Sure, some will close but I have a different take. Here's a part of my response: As the former president for 8 plus yrs of one of the colleges referenced, I want to share a more optimistic take on small colleges, including the one I led with a remarkable team over the years.  I want to begin with three questions: (1) Whom do these colleges serve? (2) Are their graduates better for having attended and graduated (and even those who stopped out, are they better for the experience)? and (3) If not small colleges, where?    Ponder these questions/answers. Small colleges, non-elite small colleges, help many first generation, Pell eligible students find their way.  That's powerful in and of itself.  Small colleges have faculty who actually teach, and teaching and pedagogy matter to them.  Small colleges produce people who help make the world go round: police officers, nurses, community based workers, social workers, teachers, small entrepreneurs, radiology techs, healthcare advocates, coaches.  Returning to the article: You bet there is a place for small colleges.  I'd put money on it.  I believe.  My question is really: why don't you?

I published a book of signs from the 2017 Inauguration.  It's called Teach Our Children Well.  The point was to show signs that represented our values.  I pictured the book as a coffee-table reminder.  Sadly, the book has new currency with the happening of two things: (1) the detention of children and families; and (2) the resignation of Justice Kennedy and the possible "packing" of the Supreme Court in a way that threatens Roe v. Wade.   I worry about all this and I looked at the book.  Many of the signs speak to these two identified issues.  Get the book. Remember what we value and what matters to us and why fighting peacefully has such enormous power.   The book contains this line, which remains sadly true:  "Whatever pathways and hurdles we face, we are connected -- as exemplified by these signs --to move forward, to use our individual and collective talents to teach our child and our children's children well."

title: 10 Tips That Will Make You Influential In SCIENCE
content:
It makes me sick.  First someone gleefully kills a rare giraffe. Then we imprison (detain) kids and/or families. Then a golfer loses his clubs and refuses to play. He quits.  How many of us have lost things (or people) and had to plow ahead.  Win or lose. How can a golfer simply step it up -- borrow clubs, learn about his game from the bottom up, show kids effort, try and try again.  What a pathetic role model when we need one.  I get winning. I get getting a spot. But gee, life dealt you a bad hand and lost your luggage. Don't wimp out for goodness sake.  Your character could have been an exemplar. Now you look like a spoiled sport.  Give me a break. You quit?  I get specialty clubs and sponsorships. I get import of getting a spot.  But, many real people lose things and manage -- with grace and humor and effort.  McDowell, you paint yourself as a poor sport and a poor exemplar for your sport.  Really.  For real. Sad. 
 
 
 …see more

content: In this heat, look at summer melt and summer slide and humor (which will help us all manage 100+ temperature.):

title: Want To Step Up Your ART? You Need To Read This First
content:
We are having a heat wave.  And we have summer melt and slide for kids who move backward in terms of skills over the summer months. Unacceptable really.   This is true for reading and I want to offer a solution.  JOKES. Yes, really.  OK, I just co-authored a children's joke book related to giraffes (who face extinction by the by).  Joke writing, joke telling and joke reading all build skills with a laugh2learn approach.  They involve word play and word use and creativity and puns and common phrases.  Jokes are not as easy to write and tell as they appear.   There is a guide on the website  www.ladylucysquest.com  and the book is Lady Lucy's Laugh Giraffe Journey.  Available @BNBuzz and @Northshire.com. Both ship for free. Amazon is apparently out of stock.   I will be writing a longer piece on this topic  and have even thought of offering a joke camp for kids in the DC area --- to improve their skills. 
 
 
 …see more

title: 10 Best Practices For DRAWING
content:
So, an article appeared in Inside Higher Ed on why leaders are failing to stop sexual harassers/abuse/rape on their campuses.  Here was/is my answer: I think there are many reasons. 1st, try campus culture, an issue that runs wide and deep. So do traditions that encourage bad behavior. Look at Prep Schools as exemplars. 2nd, the "hands-off" leaders have real trouble; it's good to delegate but....And, there needs to be a culture of transparency and an overt culture where bad news can and must be shared, not buried. 3rd, there are rose colored glasses as in: this too will pass. Nope. It won't. 4th, much of the training is poor, and people resent needing training suggesting they know all the issues. Reform the training. Bring in outsiders to do it and make it worth the faculty, staff, coaches and administrators' time. Poor training leads to poor outcomes. And resentment about waste of time. 5th, how we handle crises when they occur on campuses is weak and needs reformation. We make things worse, not better, because we aren't experts. Bring them in. 6th, to return to my favorite topic: Ask this. If there were co-presidents, could all this happen as it did on all these campuses? Speculating yes. But, pretty confidently, I can say that co-presidencies would curb this. 
 
 
 …see more

#MothersDay isn't easy for all. For some, they have lost their mothers recently or long ago. For others, their mother abandoned or abused them. For others, their mother is sick or dying or non-supportive. And for some mothers, their children have abandoned them or lost interest in them.  For some mothers, they are at odds with their children.  For some mothers, their children think they are too old or too burdensome or too difficult. And, some father's don't see any value in celebrating their wives as "mothers" -- sad too.   Let's celebrate w/ caution + sensitivity. Not everyone is celebrating.

title: 5 Romantic BANKING Ideas
content:
I just read this absolutely beautiful, honest and heart warming and heart wrenching piece written by the amazing Carrie Froese. It's titled the Magnitude of Motherhood.  Here's a link ( https://lnkd.in/d2SutnN ). Here's my response: What an absolutely beautiful piece. Heartwarming, heart wrenching and honest to its core.  I used to worry about my son dying -- for no particular reason. I just worried because life was and is filled with danger.  And, I could not imagine much worse fate than losing a child, except perhaps a child losing a parent when the child is young.  Now, my relationship with my adult son is strained for many reasons, some valid and others not.  But, as Mother's Day approaches I know this: there really is no love like a mother's for her child (or children).  And, one hopes that as a parent, one gives one's child both roots and wings as the saying goes.  And, one more thought on Mother's Day, for the children who don't have mothers or have mothers who don't care sufficiently or are psychologically absent:  don't despair. There may be no biological substitute but there are many of us more than willing to be "parents" or "mentors" or surrogate mothers if, as and when needed.  That's worth remembering too. 
 
 
 …see more

title: The Lazy Man's Guide To GST
content:
So, with the Cosby verdict, truth has finally emerged. I have been wondering if part of the problem is that many people saw Cosby as Dr. Huxtable, an example of conflating truth and fiction.  Ironically, both fellows dispensed meds -- only one was a doctor and not a real one at that.   We often confuse truth and fiction.  I think this is something as to which we can all fall prey --- not rape, goodness knows.  I mean we can mistake truth and fiction. We want to believe fictions -- they are often easier than truths.  We even enhance fiction sadly.  Just look at the Michigan State debacle.  Truth was buried.  We don't want heroes or doctors or presidents for that matter to fall -- so we psychologically distort truth.  Human flaw.  And now, the victims can see that truth does eventually show its face. Brava for their strength over all these years.  Fiction just got its comeuppance. #psychology #fiction #victims #truth 
 
 
 …see more

title: I Don't Want To Spend This Much Time On POLITICAL. How About You?
content:
How many young people need to be killed or injured in America's schools before we address this situation, including the access to weapons by those who seem to misuse them?  I get the 2nd Amendment.  Can't we restrict ammunition amounts sold?  Can't we look at other nations? And the aftermath for students, teachers and families is hard -- filled with memories that are etched. If schools and churches (and other religious venues) aren't safe, where is it safe? And, for the record, making schools armed camps is not good for anyone -- who can learn in an environment that looks and feels like a prison.  And, without security, there is fear too.   Were I guessing, we need many more counselors -- mental health counselors for troubled students and surviving students, teachers, parents and administrators. We must do better.  We have to do better.  As educators, we must take a collective stand. How sad, too, that it is Valentine's Day -- ruined for those there forever.

title: How To Lose Money With DRAWING
content:
So, after the fortune cookie message (glad many of you read about it), I am now starting Day 5. So far, I've had many realizations, some obvious; others less so. Here's a wee sampling: 1.  Nations may speak the same language (in this case English) but there remain remarkable cultural differences notwithstanding. And some terms are different too: Q-tips are cotton buds is a fun example.  Take Sunday. It is really a day of rest. Many stores and restaurants were closed on and off campus. A day of reflection. I see that cultural sensitivity is needed every minute.  2.  I am apparently hyper-sensitive to being an American given our politics and President. Case in point. I misplaced my hair brush in the move (small but impt. item). I decided a beauty salon was a good place to go to buy a replacement and found one a short car ride from campus.  When they rang up the charges, the brush was over $27 US. Trust me, it was not a fancy brush. I suggested something was wrong with the price and while they were re-assessing the price for me agreeing that it seemed high, I added: "I may be an American but I am not stupid." Really, I said that. Yipes. More as the stay progresses.  I am already seeing that the academic literature read across nations differs vastly. 
 
 
 …see more

title: Never Changing SCIENCE Will Eventually Destroy You
content:
Get this. I am here at UBC as visiting prof for five weeks. They deliver breakfast at St Johns College on weekends when dining hall is closed. Comes w/ a fortune cookie. Yes. For real. Here's mine: "Le moment es bien venu d'explorer."  How apt!!!!  Yes, I will spend a good part of the day today exploring campus to find my way around. And, I see first hand how hard it is for new students, decades younger than I am, to transition to a new institution. Will write on that soon; it is an experience that reminded me of Racing Odysseus, one of the best books written by a former college President as he returned to college as a student -- ironically, the US St. Johns College.   Consider this a broader message for all of you trying something new, going to some new place and trying some new employment strategy. See Fortune Cookie on top in photo.

title: 15 Tips For FASHION DESIGN Success
content:
I just saw a quote by Annette Breaux that beautifully states what all teachers, professors and student life staff know or can benefit from knowing: "Remember, everyone in the classroom has a story that leads to misbehavior or defiance. 9 times out of 10, the story behind the behavior won't make you angry.  It will break your heart."   I'd change the word "classroom" to the word "campus"  or "school" --- and that expands the quote meaningfully and importantly.  I was recently on a panel where I suggested that we offer support to new minority faculty.  Another panelist said: why is that needed?  They can do it on their own.  I said: not everyone can or should be forced to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps.  What is wrong with helping others, even without their asking?  Let's be clear and candid: We all need help in one way or another. And, many of the rules of the game of the academy are not so clear and are not spelled out as another panelist pointed out so aptly.   And, if we can enable success, does it really matter as educators how we do it?  As long as success is there (real success), is there some reason we think those who don't ask for or get help are better?  Moral superiority for being able to work alone?  Please. 
 
 
 …see more

title: 2 Things You Must Know About OPERATING SYSTEM
content:
As I read this article posted below, in addition to my thoughts about the survivor and his courage, I kept thinking about the paramedic -- a veteran.  And the vet's skills saved Mr. Mika. For real. And, yet, we make it so so difficult for vets to gain degrees and license in health fields that use their battle won experience.  Wouldn't you want this paramedic in your ER?  We must do better enabling the transfer of skills from military service to civilian credentials.  And, ask: Would the VA hire this paramedic?  I think not because he doesn't have the right paper credential. He had the right credentials for Mr. Mika and he has them for me: experience in moments of extraordinary danger.  Surely we can do better and use the talents of those who fought for our liberty abroad.

title: POLITICAL Works Only Under These Conditions
content:
Watch for forthcoming piece with strategies for improving how schools and colleges handle trauma that students experience.  Concrete suggestions are provided. Key here is that traumatic experiences are an equal opportunity offender -- sadly.  While small t trauma is more prevalent in low income families, higher income households can have toxic stress, abuse and trauma too.  And Big T trauma such as that caused by person-made and nature-made disasters is an equal opportunity destroyer. The key: our brains are remarkably plastic and recovery is possible --- the key here is to move forward focusing on brain strengths not weaknesses, recognizing that one is forever changed. Resiliency is about bouncing back -- there is no back. There is only forward.

title: How We Improved Our DRAWING In One Week(Month, Day)
content:
Help me understand.   We have shootings in workplaces and that doesn't stop the way we treat violence and guns. We have shootings in an elementary school. Same outcome. We have shootings at a concert venue. Same outcome. We have shootings in churches (most recently in Texas). Same outcome.  We have shootings on campuses.  Same outcome.   Safe places -- work, worship, schools -- are now unsafe. Why aren't we doing anything about guns and gun violence?  Last time I checked, these guns were used to kill innocent people, not animals in the wild and not for self-protection.  Without some change, we will not see change in the violence is protected places. What kind of world is that? Oh, we blame mental illness.  Perhaps there has been mental diminution in those who have been the shooters. But, isn't there a link between access to weapons (their purchase and continued use) and gun violence? Might it be time to reconsider--finally --quality background checks, limits on numbers of purchases and a national database that works. What will it take? Post being shot, even Rep. Scalise was not against guns. 
 
 
 …see more

title: Who Else Wants To Enjoy FASHION DESIGN
content:
I am not against lists.  But, here's a thought with respect to them: they reflect the perspective (and bias) and orientation of those who make the list.  And, whatever the topic on which lists are made, there is no one list. So, when Branson's list of best books to read was re-printed, I looked at the list.  I noted its limited focus -- in terms of subject and in terms of authors and broad perspectives.  https://lnkd.in/eRXnipr This list may be good for Branson but I think many of us might have a different list.  Many moons ago, as part of my becoming a college president, I launched a challenge: if you were a new college president, what books would you reference in your Inaugural address.  I listed mine (and promised to include them in my remarks). Other presidents chimed in.  So did faculty and provosts. There was a radio show too. Ask here: what 8 books should everyone read and WHY. The why matters. I'll work on a list. I can assume you already it will include women writers and diverse writers and fiction including poetry. 
 
 
 …see more

title: 101 Ideas For PAINTING
content:
Pieces like this make me crazy. I commend Carlton, an elite selective private college.  Good job and their president is wise (and I base this on personal experience with him too).   But, many non-elite small colleges have focused on careers for decades. The Chronicle seems to treat this as "new."  For decades, small non-elite colleges were criticized for not truly being liberal arts colleges because they also had a career focus in addition to a liberal arts curriculum and core.   Funny how the tables turn but the non-elites still get little recognition for decades of effort. Just as an example: consider nursing programs at liberal arts colleges.  Consider criminal justice degrees a liberal arts colleges.  Come on.  Let's give recognition where its due -- or overdue.

title: HR MANAGEMENT Made Simple - Even Your Kids Can Do It
content:
Excited to head to L.A. Care, a large public health insurer for dual eligible individuals and families in Los Angeles. We are doing a project linking healthcare and education as a way to break the cycle of poverty. Will be using Lady Lucy's Quest and Activity book in English and Spanish -- accompanied with a training session for the teachers/social workers in the Resource Centers. And every kid gets a book of their own. I will be reading on Thursday and Friday of this week to groups of 30 kids and parents. This is a remarkable project and one about which I feel deeply proud. John Baackes, CEO of L.A. Cares in a visionary leader. Watch for longer post on the this replicable and scalable project on Wednesday/Thursday of this week.  Reading matters.  It matters for many reasons: good health and educational progression.  There is hope --- I know there is.  I can feel it -- even in our crazy world with person made and nature made disasters abounding. 
 
 
 …see more

title: 5 Best Ways To Sell DRAWING
content:
Headed momentarily to Democracy Prep School in Las Vegas on Andre Agassi Campus. Exciting to read and share Lady Lucy's Quest with elementary school students. Reading has real power; it allows for the development of thinking and coping skills -- much needed in view of the disasters in our world -- both person made and nature made.  In short reading matters and Lady Lucy's message of strength, endurance and courage is most fitting -- sad but true. Doing a presentation on Oct. 17th at Columbia Teacher College on strategies teachers, parents and administrators can use to help kids deal with trauma and toxic stress.  My adult book develops the concept of lasticity which can  be deployed with success.  (It is in children's book too.) title: Succeed With POLITICS In 24 Hours
content:
W/ all the tragedies surrounding us (hurricanes, earthquakes, Las Vegas massacre among them), I simply don't understand how the Cabinet Secretaries are behaving. They're "flying high" as if intoxicated by power.  It is costing taxpayers, taking time and attention away from real problems and solutions.  Consider these examples: visiting Mermaid sculpture in Denmark, attending the Women's Final at Wimbledon (w/ one's wife + others), cruising down rivers, seeing the Eclipse (but not admitting that goal), flights on private/gov/military transport. Tell me: why is this acceptable? Why has only Dr. Price resigned? Apology anyone? How would wounded Vets feel if they knew what Dr. Shulkin was doing abroad for 10 days? How would Vets whose families fell apart post-deployment feel knowing their leader was, on gov. dime, enjoying time w/ his spouse abroad? How would those w/o food, water,  roads and bridges in PR feel about Secretaries using improper transport? I think we need to deal w/ this racket. Seriously, let's have a "Take a Racket to Work Day." Everyone in and out of government brings a tennis racket to work, symbolic of Dr. Shulkin's tennis boondoggle and the absurdity of how Secretaries are behaving amidst real crises in the world.  A protest w/ power.

title: 10 Funny BANKING Quotes
content:
Here's an idea linking needs in Puerto Rico with wrongs done at University of Louisville in men's basketball.  Assume Louisville actually owes money to its now on leave Coach, Rick Pitino (how that would be so is a different issue).  Let's say money is paid.  Then the Coach can donate the money to assist Puerto Rico and the many Americans in need there.  A form of penance.  And, it seems like Pitino could do with some charity service -- and outreach to others rather than enabling taking.  And, what a good swap. $ from bad go to $ for good.  Just a thought.   Hey, I know it won't happen but consider the messaging were it to happen.  Good coming from bad.  And role modeling.  And, yes, the money is from a non-profit but better that it go to Puerto Rico if it has to be paid.  Imagine writing that settlement agreement.  Need better lawyers than those who wrote original contract.  Creative lawyering. Creative settlement.  Doing right.

title: Believe In Your FASHION DESIGN Skills But Never Stop Improving
content:
So, here is the question that is puzzling me.  Can someone, whether they are a President or anyone else, redeem themselves and cure omissions by later clarity and specificity?   In other words, can one refine one's comments on White Supremacy and racism that were too vague and too weak by ramping up one's outrage later?  Do we treat the later comments as a reflection of the real feelings of the person speaking and ignore earlier flawed rhetoric or do we look at the first words spoken and treat them as "truth?"  Does it matter if it is minutes, hours or days between the first comments and the improved comments?   And, one more thing: to what standard do we hold our leaders with respect to their obligation to speak up and out out on topics such as discrimination, racism, sexual assault, violence?  High -- the question is how high the bar is and should be.

title: Fear? Not If You Use MUSIC The Right Way!
content:
So, I recently learned that my mom and dad often danced in the den of their home when they go home from a dinner out or some event. They did this into their 70's and 80's. They rolled up the rug, enjoyed a drink and danced to close out the evening.  What a romantic notion --- a tradition I never knew about and one that seemed so so warm and loving.  My dad passed away in 2008 and my mom recently remarked that she had not danced at night since then and missed my dad and dancing. She is now 89.  So, I recruited my partner and he agreed to dance with my mom this week-end --- rug rolled up, drink in background and old fashioned music. Tradition revived for a night.  A gift to my mom and one amazing partner I have who is willing to allow time to stop for just a moment to remember the past and create a memory.  Thanks MW. 
 
 
 …see more

All you legal eagles out there, here is a non-partisan question: Can a US president self-pardon?  Not looking at precedent in particular; interested in the legal scope of the pardon power that is housed in US Presidents.  What is the legal distinction between pardoning others and self-pardoning or isn't there one?  Where does the pardoning power reside and who or what can diminish or expand that scope?  Answers and thoughts welcomed --- serious answers not politically motivated or snarky ones please. (OK, a touch of cynicism)   And, I am not asking what one can do in a generalized sense. I am asking what is legally permissible.

See this new article on Princeton and women in leadership. I think it re-hashes what we know (mentoring matters) and misses culture change and self reflection.  My comment follows link:  https://lnkd.in/dTZf4wG I am struck by the total focus on mentoring for women; this is important to be sure and it is not new. What is striking is that there is almost no mention of institutional culture and the need to change that. How important is it to create an environment in which women can thrive as leaders. Were I to institute a look-see at Princeton, I would look at culture first -- what is it in the culture that enables men to seek and thrive in leadership posts. Hard to look inward and admit that there may be cultural biases and impacts and auras. Hard to face a male dominated past and current culture. Hard to be honest about what is inhibiting success. Mentoring matters for real. But, it is not enough. No indeed.

title: I Don't Want To Spend This Much Time On HR MANAGEMENT. How About You?
content:
Here's a suggestion. This July 4th and every July 4th, read the Declaration of Independence to your children.  Even for infants, the words have a meaning; the document almost sounds poetic when read aloud.  And, this is, of course, the document that creates our freedom.   For the many years our now adult son lived at home, I read this document to him --- from start to finish -- on July 4th. (We read the I Have A Dream speech too on Martin Luther King Day).  I hope and think it helped him become the person that he is -- filled with a desire to help those in need and preserve what is valuable in and to our nation.   Create a new tradition then in your own family  -- whether you are a new parent or a parent of older children: Read one of our nation's founding documents and be proud of the message it sends.  And, if your children are grown, just re-read the document for your own sake. In these troubling times, it messages positively and powerfully.

title: Open The Gates For POLITICAL By Using These Simple Tips
content:
You know the expression: Truth is stranger than fiction?  Sadly, that describes the American presidency at present. If you made up what was happening over the past 10 days, people would tell you that your story was too far fetched, too far from a real situation and to revise what you wrote so it was believable.   My question: what do you do when, in fact, truth is stranger (and worse) than fiction?  How do you change the course of an off-course tanker truck?  How do you restore belief in justice and fairness and the rule of law.  Whatever that path is, we need to find it -- now.  From lies to leaks, from disclosures to drama, from cover-up to conspiracy, how do we bring back balance to our nation and its people?  Think.  We need answers.

title: 7 Rules About MATHEMATICS Meant To Be Broken
content:
Here is what is worrying me (among other things): recommendation letters. There is a history of such letters being written for teachers to get new positions despite the fact that these teachers have abused students.  We often are less than honest (if omission counts) when we write letters of recommendation.  We assume receivers of letters can read between the lines and know that we are not truly recommending someone but we are being cautious to avoid charges of defamation, libel and other legal risks.   So, posit this hypothetical: write a recommendation letter for Bill O'Reilly.  What should it say? Would all references to sexual abuse/harassment be absent from such a letter?  Ponder this conundrum; recommendation letters are commonplace. 
 
 
 …see more

content:
I've had a couple of hours to process, I'm struck by how that many people can be in one place (in my case DC) without incident. Babies, kids, adults, teens, students, older people including those pushed in wheelchairs by (grand)daughters. People of all races, ethnicities, religions, customs. How is it even possible that more than a million people co-existed in a tight space w/o panic when the exit route was overcrowded.And nothing bad happened. A sea of people wanting more for their nation and for the world. Democracy.

The tension levels are high. Kids are copying tone and rhetoric.  This is hard on teachers and parents.  Time to look at how we are impacting a generation --- and we should worry. For real.  Now. title: Avoid The Top 10 POLITICAL Mistakes

Here is what worries me: kids are listening to the news and the way people are treating and talking to each other. Then, they are carrying this into schools and into their homes. We are role-modeling poorly.  What are our kids copying?  Harassment, bullying, offensive rhetoric, fighting, hidden agendas, mini-purges. No wonder classrooms are all a flutter. Distrust and distain and disrespect are surrounding us. Time to push back -- for decency, dialogue that is respectful and drama-free human engagement that focuses on respect and what binds us together. Time 4 calm.

Four tough issues for kids post election that need to be explained by someone (whether at home or in school or after school:  (1) why do we have an electoral college?  Kids think you get the most votes, you win (not a silly idea); (2) Why would someone be nasty to so many people and get away with it? and (3) Why does he keep changing his mind? and (4) Will any of my friends be sent away from the US -- or not allowed to work?  Sadly, voting is not enough and does not answer these important questions.

We can and must fight for what we value but we also need to role model democracy at its best: respectful disagreement and non-violent protest. We must keep our commitment to those in need and bring our best selves to the table to work despite obstacles.

title: 15 Tips For PHOTOGRAPHY Success
content:
What is it like for a South Los Angeles native to be living in Florence, Italy, but teaching students at New York University Shanghai? A profound and extraordinary experience. I've got to share some photos of the fieldwork that students in Shanghai are carrying out. Perhaps educators here can use this assignment as a project because many of us are struggling to convert in-class work to the virtual. These are 1st year students. Their job was to do some fieldwork at a teahouse in the city. Blew me away.  Their commitment to the class makes me wonder how wonderful we would be in the US, if we gave more resources to schools across the board, more respect to teachers and more honor to students. Now we're facing unimaginable gaps. US folk, we are behind the curve ball, the corner pocket, the corn field and the corner sto'. Teachers, please be safe, sane and as productive as you can be during this time.  #teachers   #china   #internationalteacher   #educators   #collegeteaching   #pandemicteaching   #schools

Years ago I worked in an office in the summer for LA Parks & Rec before the swimming pools opened where I was a managing lifeguard. One day, I came into the office with cornrows. The secretary told me that she was embarrassed by my hairstyle and that, that wasn't ladylike. So, she sent me home. When I went home, I told my mother. Mom told me to go right back to that job with my natural hair and tell her to call her if she has a problem with her daughter's hair. That woman never spoke to me again. Hah! Unfortunately, this woman was vocal, many people silently discriminate in the work place against hair outside of the mainstream and especially if its a coily mane like mine. Employment, hair & politics. For a person with coils who once had locks and now rocks cornrows and headwraps, hair in the office space can get really ugly. CALL FOR PROPOSED STORIES for Ark Republic's fourth major collaborative project on gentrification. PAID CONTRIBUTOR OPPORTUNITY Inner cities experiencing dramatic shifts in its landscape that are best defined as gentrification. While some describe it as a welcomed renewal of urban terrain left neglected, others see it as a takeover.  This is why we ask, “Whose block is it, anyway?” For Ark Republic’s fourth Major Collaborative Project (MCP), we call for your help tell multimedia stories of gentrification: a contested space of ideas, cultures and economies.  Please submit all CFPs and questions to the following email:  majorcollabo@arkrepublic.com  with the subject line: Gentrification.  Please submit proposals by July 1. Passion is one of those qualities you CAN’T spot in a CV.  We sourcers have to spot it ourselves.  Some activities suggest passion: Being active on professional forums Writing blogs or speaking in events   Relevant hobbies connected to your profession And sometimes it’s just the way you talk about what you do that makes you shine. Passion is that one quality we want ALL employees to have.  Figure out why you like what you do, and talk about it in interviews.  Lack of passion is deal breaker.   #personalbranding   #linkedin   #hr   #hiring   #career   #thoughtleadership

‘Talent Marketing’ I didn’t make that up. It ain’t ‘Marketing’. It’s not exactly ‘employer branding’. When talents get 7-10 job offers every single week.  When companies struggle with paying candidates what FB, Amazon, Microsoft and Google can easily afford. In this reality, you need more than just actively reaching out to candidates. In marketing, Lead-gen will get you that steady flow of leads every business needs. But Demand Gen will always get a much higher conversion rate. Talent marketing follows the same rule. You want these talents to be interested in you. You want them to approach you. You want them to WANT.  #hr   #hiring   #career   #marketing 
 
 
 …see more

title: Some People Excel At BUSINESS And Some Don't - Which One Are You?
content:
You ALL have unofficial recommendations We in HR do that all the time.  We get a candidate’s CV and you find out he/she was working with a friend of yours. Why not call that friend to get an unbiased opinion? As a sourcer, you have every right to use any (legal and legitimate) channel to gather information about a candidate. But how much do you professionally trust a friend?  How close was this friend to your candidate?   What do you do if the process is discret? There’s no wrong or right answer.  I treat recommendations like perfume - I enjoy their smell, but I’ll never drink them. The interview process is 5X more important than any recommendation, official or unofficial.  Yes, you should get yourself a good set of people who will gladly recommend you. But if you don’t heavily invest in your interview skills, the best recommendations in the world won’t help you.  #people   #hr   #career   #interviews 
 
 
 …see more

title: The Ultimate Guide To PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
Ghosting has to stop.  A company gets in touch with you, inquires about your availability, and then - poof. Vanishes. You go to a job interview, you feel OK/good about the process, they tell you they’ll be in touch. And then… crickets.  It’s not only companies. Candidates do that all the time. Answering and then ignoring, scheduling a job interview and not showing up, not returning any calls.  Ghosting usually saves you 1-2 minutes of inconvenience. But it brands you as a douche forever.  No one likes uncertainty. Whatever you are - a candidate, a recruiter or a sourcer - treat people like you want to be treated. Be responsible. Learn to say ‘sorry, but no’. Stop ghosting. #ghosting   #career   #hr   #people

But a person who publishes blog posts, talks in conferences or meetups, or shares insightful content on Linedikn proves not only his passion for what it does, but brands him as an expert in her/his field.   Passion, expertise, writing and speaking skills - talent hunters are looking for that. This means you’ll get more job offers.  It also means you’re likely to get offered a higher salary. Be active. Get exposed. It’s worth it. #personalbranding   #linkedin   #hr   #hiring   #career   #thoughtleadership

title: Are You Making These POLITICS Mistakes?
content:
Do you accept every LinkedIn connection request?  You should.  When you publish any type of content, you WANT more people to see it. You WANT to increase your exposure.  Yeah, you might get spammed after accepting requests. it happens.  That shouldn’t stop you.  It also shouldn’t stop you from searching for like-minded individuals to actively connect to. It will benefit you in the long run. LinkedIn isn’t Facebook. Your connections don’t have to be your personal friends. They can just share some of your interests, work at the same company, or field.  When you reach over 10K friends, you can start worrying about the type of people you accept as connections.  Until then, unless the profile looks like a bot, you should accept all connection requests.  #hr   #hiring   #career   #linkedin 
 
 
 …see more

title: How To Become Better With ZOOLOGY In 10 Minutes
content:
If you're interviewing for a job or just looking for a job - know whom you’re talking to. It matters. Big time.  Different positions, different responsibilities, different impact: Talent sourcer - creates a recruitment pipeline, from job posting to personal headhunting. Similar to scouting in sports. Talent Ops - enables the talent organization to work more effectively. In charge of scheduling and the interview process. Talent Acquisition Specialist - manages the entire hiring process, from screening to contract.  Talent Marketing Specialist- develops the company's Employer Branding and Recruitment Marketing strategies. In charge of evolving recruitment, so the company can attract top talent. HRBP - Responsible for you from the moment your onboarding process ends. HR analytics - collects and analyzes HR data, and applies it to make recommendations related to recruitment, retention, and legal compliance. In smaller companies, one person can cover a few of these positions. But these are DIFFERENT positions.  HR is NOT recruitment. title: 7 Easy Ways To Make PHOTOGRAPHY Faster
content:
Job hunt CANNOT be based only on feelings. Get data to back up your efforts: ☝🏼Organize it! Prepare an Excel/Monday/Huntr dedicated to your job search ☝🏼Document every company you applied for with the application date and position details. ☝🏼Document every rejection or process ☝🏼Track the source you applied through  Maybe when you apply to Team Lead roles you get rejected but for senior positions, you get to an interview? Maybe when you apply through friends you get to phone interview more easily?  Job search IS a job. And just like most high-tech jobs, data is crucial.  Don’t ignore your feelings. Of course not. Intuition goes a long way. But your gut instincts can mislead you, and intuition may fail you. It happens. Data’s job is to make sure you get it right. Any other questions one should ask himself when measuring their job search? Share them in the comments! #hr   #jobsearch   #people   #career

title: 5 Easy Ways You Can Turn GRAPHIC Into Success
content:
HR isn’t like all the other functions in a company.  It’s so different from all the business-focus positions - product, marketing, sales, R&D. It has its own unique qualities. You can’t compare to anything else. Really? Actually - NO. It’s not.  My role, for example, as an sourcer is very similar to an SDR:  	Linkedin is one of our main tools 	Reaching out to prospects is daily routine 	We do cold calls  	We try to create the perfect pitch 	We use templates, but personalisation is the key 	Small wins are big wins for us, one prospect at a time. 	We’re Competitive  We even share the same memes! Some of the best tips I got along the way, I got from  Justin Michael . He understands SDR like no other.  What HR people do is unique, but the job isn’t all that different from others. This opens the door to learning from so many more people. #HR   #SDR   #People

title: 7 Ways To Keep Your PAINTING Growing Without Burning The Midnight Oil
content:
How to use your friends as personal recruiters when you look for new opportunities? One of the best tips I have for job seekers is to use friends and professional networks but, how to do it effectively? 1. Lookup for all of your 1st connections on LinkedIn, then organize them by- people that know you personally and can validate your work[from school, past companies, etc]  2.  Reach out to every one of these connections with a summary about yourself, what you are looking for, and ask them kindly to apply on your behalf to their companies. 3.  When they agree [Yay!], ask them to add a few words about your work together and to send it directly to the hiring manager. This has a lot of weight on the CV screening decision.  4.  When hiring managers have valid information about you from a friend they trust it and increases your chances to get hired. 5.  After passing the CV screening use your friend as your source of information about the company! Ask them about the culture, challenges, and projects, and prepare yourself for the phone screening! Just applying isn't enough these days, the game has changed and you need to do the best. #hr   #jobhuting   #linkedin   #recruitment

title: How To Buy (A) PHOTOGRAPHY On A Tight Budget
content:
The real story about on-boarding from home🏡 It's a difficult thing to on-board in a new place, getting to know your teammates, managers, the company culture, unwritten rules, and more. And now, we need to do all of that online- boom!💥 Yes, it's hard and the main thing everyone is focused on is the relationships and I understand.  Relationships are the baseline for everything and yet we tend to forget a very important thing- Workplace politics!🔵🔴 Its difficult to understand from zoom meetings and this is our job as teammates to explain to the new people on our team. ✔️The history of the team (don't disrespect, this is important!), projects, fliers and wins.  ✔️Relationships with other teams ✔️Social relationships between teammates  This is crucial information, and when you on-board via zoom you don't always manage to get it. Did I miss something? comment and let me know what do you think. #HR   #workpkacepolitics   #onboarding   #people

title: Your Key To Success: MUSIC
content:
Everyone is focused on the employee experience. What about the candidate experience? This was always tough. This new reality makes it even tougher. A lot of companies are trying to gain an advantage with ‘goods’ - mainly sending gifts to a candidates’ home. That’s not a bad effort. That makes candidates feel special. It will never replace the human touch. Candidates deal with uncertainty. Waiting for answers, getting feedback - these are their core challenges. It’s great to get a fruit basket or a bottle of wine, but it can’t come at the expense of being there - providing interview feedback, being available for questions, giving answers - reducing uncertainty. All employees were once candidates. Never forget that. #hr   #interview   #career   #people   #recruiting

title: How To Sell GST
content:
Honestly -  Can you get a ‘feel’ of a new workplace from your home? Can you get a taste of a company’s work culture through Zoom? Can you figure out if your colleagues are cool and nice or something else, without meeting them?🙄 This is so hard to do right now. But at the same time, your satisfaction depends on these, much more than your salary. So what can you, before starting your new position? 👉🏼Explore the chemistry you have with your new boss. It is a MUST. 👉🏼Ask to meet your team even if it’s not included in the hiring process. 👉🏼Ask someone you personally know that works there 👉🏼Google it 👉🏼Glassdoor it. 👉🏼Instagram it. Yes. Culture is most visible there.   Salary is just one factor, and not the most important one.  #Never  join a company blindfolded.   #hr   #interview   #career   #hiring

title: How To Use ART To Desire
content:
Want to make a shift?  Switch to a new position? Venture into a new field?  DO THE WORK. Listen - talk to someone. A real person who’s been doing what you seek to do for a few years.  Understand what it takes to do their job - skills, experience, education, talent. This can validate (or nullify) your decision to pursue it in the first place. Learn - show interest.  Listen to podcasts, connect to professional groups, read articles. Get acquainted with the jargon. Know to speak the right language. It takes time.  DO - start your own project in that field. A blog. A podcast. Volunteer somewhere. Do something. This will give you plenty to talk about in interviews.  This is a MUST.  Write - post on LinkedIn or in professional groups/forums with your thoughts. Share your approach online. Comment to industry leaders. Engage.  Motivation is great.  It’s not enough in today’s market.  Do the work to gain an edge.   Job search IS a job. So is career retraining  #career   #hr   #people

title: DANCE Works Only Under These Conditions
content:
Want a better chance at that job you want to get hired for? ‘Translate’ your CV to the language the company is using. Focus on 2 elements in your CV: Title - make sure your title fits the job description. If the job description lists ‘software engineer’, don’t use ‘Backend engineer’ in your CV. If there’s a way to get a perfect match, use it. Keywords - read the full job description. Find what matters in that job. And put as many keywords as possible in your CV.  Pro tip - So many companies are using bots to screen CV. So use the EXACT same words. Use spaces before and after. Don’t let the bots rule you out.  Whatever you do, DO NOT LIE. Especially in the skill section, you will be easily spotted during the interview phase. Once you get caught lying, there’s no turning back.  Does it take time to match your CV with different positions? Yes, it does.  Getting hired is a full-time job.  #people   #hr   #skills

title: What Can Instagramm Teach You About CRAFT
content:
אפריל 2020, עוד רגע פסח, אנחנו בטוחים ששבועיים הסגר והופ הקורונה הכי מאחורינו.  פסט פורוורד ל5 חודשים אחרי ואנחנו? עדיין כאן. ממש ממש כאן.  ולמה אנחנו מספרים לכם את זה? כי אנחנו עמוק בתוך גל שני של הרשמה ליעוצים ובין לבין, בשיחה פה ושם מנועצים.ות שכן עדכנו ושמרו על קשר ספרנו * 108 (!) נועצים.ות שמצאו עבודה!!!* 😲🤩 זו עובדה כזו מדהימה כי אף פעם לא הגדרנו את המיזם ככזה שמשדך בין משרות למחפשי עבודה. כאלה יש המון וטובים. אבל "תוצר הלוואי" המשמח הזה, רק מוכיח את מה שידענו כשפתחנו את המיזם- תהליך חיפוש העבודה הוא ארוך. זה טיול, עם מקטעים וכל מקטע מלא בבאמפרים, לרוב כל כך פשוטים שאם רק נצליח להאיר עליהם זה ישנה לחלוטיןןן את תפיסה על חיפוש נכון. זה משפט אחר בראיון, מילה בקורות החיים, סקיל בלינקדאין, מבט אחד לכיוון אחר בקריירה-  שמבדיל בין חיפוש מאכזב לעליה בשלב נוסף בתהליך המיון. והנה זה קורה! חיפוש עבודה הוא הרבה יותר מהשורה התחתונה, אבל איזו גאווה שזו השורה התחתונה שלנו.☺️💪🏼 ואלו אפילו לא הנתונים המלאים, רק איסוף קטן של נתונים מההודעות שבהן נועצים סיפרו לנו שמצאו עבודה.  הסקרנות נדלקה ואנחנו ממש רוצים לדעת😼 אז אם גם אתם מצאתם עבודה או התקדמתם לשלבים שלא הייתם בהם קודם לאחר שיחה עם אחד היועצים.ות שלנו, ספרו לנו!  ולאלו מאיתנו שעדיין בחיפוש, לא לשכוח לשמור על אופטימיות- זה הצליח להם וזה יקרה גם לכם. בוודאות❤️ AdviceMe.Il

title: Never Changing PAINTING Will Eventually Destroy You
content:
Getting a new job today - that’s a whole job in itself. It ain’t what it used to be.  But I still see candidates use the same old methods. The most popular one is “spray and pray” - sending your CVs to any position, regardless of how relevant it is for you. It can’t hurt, right? Wrong❌ Applying for every single job out there shows Recruiters that you lack focus, passion, and talent. Not very good qualities. Worse than that - sometimes you’ll get in the system, in which case you’ll be marked as someone who was rejected multiple times. So what should you do? 📌Research the company you want to work for. 📌Research the people who work there. 📌Find a RELEVANT job description, one that 📌you have a real shot at.  📌Research that position and try to talk to people in that company who know what it means 📌Adapt your CV to better reflect that position Then - apply✅ *This isn’t 2005 anymore* Invest time and effort, and the chances of finding your dream job will dramatically increase. #hr   #people   #linkedin 
 
 
 …see more

title: 3 Ways To Master POLITICAL Without Breaking A Sweat
content:
Are you adding a message to the Recruiting person? You should, it’s worth the effort. If you do it right! The way you approach Recruiters is as important as your CV. There’s so much at stake.  Yet I still get pinged with messages that immediately disqualify the sender. Here’s how to do it: #DO : Personalize your response. Make it sound like it comes from you. Research. Give us a feeling you know what the company does, and how it relates to YOU. Be Polite. Mention any special ability you have that’s relevant. I’m always looking for a candidate with an edge.  End your message with a Call To Action. A simple ‘best regards’ isn’t enough.  #DON ’T: Use templates. I spot them immediately. Command us to do anything. You don’t work for me, I don’t work for you. Not yet at least :-) Ask us what we have to offer you. This is about offering yourself, not the opposite. Finding a job IS a job. Make the effort.   #hr   #people   #linkedin

title: 7 and a Half Very Simple Things You Can Do To Save MUSIC
content:
Have you clicked on the Search Appearances feature on your profile? 🤔 You get this notification weekly, some of you ignore it while I suggest taking a deeper look.  On your LinkedIn profile, you’ll see the number of searches you appeared in.  Clicking on them gives you some handy insights. Where it shows the job-titles of the people, this indicates if you reach the right audience. Take a look at whose search you appeared in and see if those are the kinds of searches you want to be showing up in. If the people you are appearing to are unrelated to your field I would recommend seeing if you could make some adjustments to your profile to better align with the searches you want to show up in. As you can see, in my case: 📌People from AppsFlyer search my profile- Hi guys you can reach out to me over slack although I'm more available here😂 📌Most of the people work as SW developers- which is good for me because this is the audience I'm looking to hire. 📌The keywords people search for Sourcer, Recruiter, HR, and Talent are also amazing for me because this is the kind of words I want people to search and find me. So, take a deeper look and try to learn and improve. This is a great QA to your profile. I think a good number should be 300-500 searches🙏🏼 #linkedin   #jobs

title: Why My BANKING Is Better Than Yours
content:
משבר תעסוקתי עולמי. ובכל משבר כזה יש תת משבר. ממה שאני חווה האוכלוסיות שנפגעו הכי הרבה הן ג'וניורים ללא ניסיון או אנשים בגילאי 40-50+ שלא הצליחו לעשות ריסקילנג ולהתאים את עצמם לעולם החדש. הדיונים למה דווקא הם יכולים להימשך ימים ובאמת שיש לי הרבה מה להגיד על זה. אבל מה עושים? אחת הבעיות הגדולות שזיהינו היא שלא מספיק מכירים תפקידים בהייטק, תפקידי לקוחות, שירות, אופרציה שלא כולם מודעים אליהם. וכשאתה לא מודע שיש תפקיד כזה אתה לא יודע מה לעשות בכדי להגיע אליו והאם אתה בכלל מתאים. כי אולי כל חייך היה שם תפקיד שמתאים לך בול ופשוט לא ידעת שהוא קיים? והעולם הולך לשם, צעירים בבתי ספר יעבדו במקצועות שעדיין לא קיימים. גם אני אגב לא ידעתי מה זה סורסרית שהייתי בגן. ולכן, ביום חמישי 23.07 אנחנו מארגנים מטעם שדולת ההייטק והחדשות וביוזמת ח"כ עידן רול יום אוריינטציה למקצועות וחברות בהייטק. "הייטק למתחילים", בחצי היום ישולבו הרצאות על חיפוש עבודה בהייטק ואוריינטציה עם מנטורים וחברות המובילות בהייטק הישראלי. יש כבר מעל 1,000 נרשמים וזה בדיוק הזמן להבטיח את מקומכם. כמובן שהכל מתקיים באונליין וזו רק ההתחלה של הפעילות שלנו למענכם. מוזמנים להירשם! לינק להרשמה בתגובה הראשונה:)  Idan Roll   Dor Blech   Guy Baron תודה לכל החברות שמשתתפות ואם תרצו לקחת חלק כמנטורים או כחברות בכנס הבא דברו איתי

title: Everything You Wanted to Know About POLITICAL and Were Too Embarrassed to Ask
content:
Do's and Don'ts in your job search I see a lot [!!!] of mistakes in the past few months and in this kind of arena you should be in your best shape! These mistakes cost a lot. #Don 't- Upload a LinkedIn post that says you've been looking for a job in the past 6 months and that everyone rejects you/ treats you unfairly in the hiring process.  #Why ? You are your own brand! If you are a brand you should emphasize your professional skills by sharing interesting content and showing interesting projects. You can get empathy from friends but LinkedIn isn't the place for that. #What  should you do instead? Ask a friend to upload a post about you as a reference or focus on side projects and show them on LinkedIn. #Don 't- Use the "Open to work" LinkedIn frame  #Why - Although it seems like a cool feature, I know recruiters who say they decline to connect requests from people with the frame in order to prevent inconvenience because they do not have jobs to offer. #What  should you do instead? Open the "let recruiters know you are open to new opportunity button", it's discreet and won't show up to recruiters at your company. And yes, marketing-wise it looks much better. All of this info is based on my thoughts research and experience. Feel free to share your opinion. Good luck!  #Jobs   #HR

title: Got Stuck? Try These Tips To Streamline Your BANKING
content:
Finding a job used to be about finding a great PLACE to work in.  The culture, the environment, colleagues - for most of the people I sourced, those were more important than their salary.  Job seekers are looking for something totally different now. The focus is now on the work itself. You feel it with every candidate’s question. It’s less about feeling like a part of a community, and more about the job itself, how interesting and satisfying it can be, and how comfortable you feel doing it from a distance.  Physical distance from the office is almost irrelevant now. It opens possibilities for everyone. The world is changing. So is what people seek in their future job. #HR   #People  This is me, working 6 hours away from the office, I♥️my job. 
 
 
 …see more

title: 7 Easy Ways To Make POLITICS Faster
content:
A lot of people ask me to share some of my LinkedIn secrets. So, I've decided to do a small experiment, based on this I'll share some of my tips. I uploaded 2 different posts, both of them "Self Branding" posts that tell the same story- me during corona. Both posts were uploaded at the same hour, same picture and subject (You can check the numbers) and yet one of them gained much more exposure (post A).  My explanation is: • Post A is much more personal, I shared my personal goals, feelings and this is what people are looking to read. Tip- don't be afraid to share your feelings and thoughts, you will get much more exposure. • Post A tells a story, compared to post B which is super short and generic. Tip- tell a story and be a storyteller of your career, try to start with a problem and finish with how you solved it. • Post A ends with calling to action, a question. Tip- when you finish with a call to action people will get involved and comment-Boom- more exposure. What do you think? Do you want me to share more of my secrets?:)  #linkedin   #tips

title: The Next 3 Things To Immediately Do About OPERATING SYSTEM
content:
Let's talk DATA! I have exciting data about the industry, 3-months post corona. I will give my insights. The basis for the information is from  AdviceMe.Il   so of course, you can not generalize it to all populations. Nevertheless it's interesting. First - the average age of people who asked for our advice: 26-33. I can explain it mostly by experience, 26-33 usually are employees at the beginning of their careers, and companies prefer to keep the seniors because they're more expensive to hire and of course, more valuable. Second, 1 out of 5 people is a software developer! Well, I was amazed by this one. I would think that SW people who are in high demand would be the last to get fired. I can explain it with 2 ideas - first, most of them are juniors /from small startups that had to close, second, AdviceMe's branding was especially oriented for tech people. Another interesting piece of data- 80% of the people who asked for our advice had at least an undergrad degree. The higher education was the fewer people there were. I guess companies won't let go so fast of people with high education. Also, 90% of people with 3rd degree had a managerial experience which is not a surprise. I want to thank  Or Hazbani   for all his help and great insights. And, 3 months later, I'm back in the office!

title: Savvy|Smart|Sexy People Do SCIENCE :)
content:
The new key factors candidates will look for in their next job post-corona. Pre-corona candidates decided to sign with companies based on 4 key factors: daily commute, the people, the role, and of course, money. Companies actually developed techniques and selling points in order to sell the positions based on these factors, and now we have a game-changer!  After some research on my side, I can tell that things are gonna change. Here are the new 4 key factors that will be considered in the post-corona era: **Financial stability of the company (the company fired staff during corona, or sent employees to unpaid leave) **Work-life balance (did the company take into consideration work hours for employees with kids, WFH)  **Social responsibility (companies that helped during the corona with donations, volunteering, and technology)  **A place to stay for the long term (according to salary, perks, and people). WDYT? What will be the new key-factors? (In the picture AppsFlyer Cares van came to cheer up our medical heroes). AppsFlyer  #covid19

title: Could This Report Be The Definitive Answer To Your POLITICAL?
content:
Why are we looking for “adaptive to change” people?🤔 Adaptive challenges refer to situations where there are no known solutions to the problem or cases where there are too many solutions but no clear choices. Adaptive challenges are by nature, adaptive, which also means they are fluid and change with circumstances. The coronavirus situation caused a lot of uncertainty, suddenly companies had to change everything in a second without base knowledge.  The companies and people who won’t adjust fast will fail. And this is why we hire “adapters”. We are 3 steps ahead of everyone else, with new creative ideas because of it.  While most of the companies try to understand how to WFH this is so last week for us😂 Well, the new routine is ahead..good luck for all of us!  I'm wearing my AF t-shirt to feel at home🏡   #wfh 
 
 
 …see more

So, here are some tips for all of you who work from home: *Build a Permanent Work Space *Set “Work Hours” *Discover Your Peak Productivity Periods *Make To-Do Lists *Don’t Work in Your PJs (although it’s fun) *Don’t Work in Front of the TV *Eat a Healthy Lunch or Snack *Take Short Breaks Are you WFH? title: Who Else Wants To Enjoy PAINTING
content:
יש שנות כלב ויש שנות לינקאדין (הסבר בתגובה הראשונה). אז היום לפי שנות לינקאדין יש לי שנה בAppsFlyer🎉 מצד אחד אני מרגישה שאני פה מאז ומעולם ומצד שני כאילו עדיין לא הספקתי כלום. אני זוכרת שכשהייתי בתהליך  Oshrat Feldman Binyamin   אמרה לי-החברה בגדילה ואת תגדלי ביחד איתה, זה צעד נכון לקריירה שלך. והיא-צדקה. בשנה הזו עשיתי המון. כולם חשבו שאשבר מהמרחק והנסיעות, שאני לא אצלח תפקיד ראשון בחברה רחוקה מהתחום אליו עשיתי סורסינג לפני אבל זה רק דרבן אותי. מאז-וואו, עשיתי פרויקטים, גיוסים, כלים, הרצאות, הפכתי לDani the Sourcer, יש לי פילטר באינסטוש ***אבל*** הכי חשוב- וזה מה שכל אדם שעוסק בגיוס חייב להבין-שיניתי לאנשים את החיים! בתפקיד שלי אני פונה לאנשים ולא מציעה להם משרה, אני מציעה להם להתקדם בקריירה, להיות יותר נינוחים בבית עם הילדים, להשתדרג כלכלית ומקצועית, להכיר אנשים חדשים, לשנות אווירה וזה כיף לי. כיף לי ללכת במסדרון ושאנשים אומרים לי תודה, שטוב להם, שכיף להם. ולי-לי כיף איתם ביחד ושמפרופיל בלינקאדין הם הפכו לחברים שלי לצוות. אז, תודה AppsFlyer, זו הייתה שנה מופלאה♥️
