title: Why POLITICAL Succeeds
content:
Amazon's acquisition of PillPack is fascinating on multiple fronts:  1) It's one of the very few real success stories and unicorn exists of recent digital health companies. (sadly, many of the digital health companies don't have the right business model which hinder them from scaling). 2) Value creation of over $1Bn in only 5 years is so amazing and rare, especially for a business that deals with regulation and logistics (scaling Instagram is very different than scaling a drug delivery business).    3) Now with the scale of Amazon, it's interesting to see how the pharmacies will be disrupted by PillPack's offering. I guess $17.5 billion loss in market values of CVS, Walgreens, Walmart and a few others today is an indicator of what's ahead. #pillpack #acquisitions #pharmacy #digitalhealth

title: Rules Not To Follow About BUSINESS
content:
2 Million users engaged with Fitbit's Female Health within the first month of launch! That's pretty amazing! So proud of Fitbit and our teams who made Versa & Female Health possible. Launching Female Health category was one of the most exciting (and possibly most challenging) work my team did at Fitbit. Women's health, menstruation, fertility, and pregnancy are not the easiest topics to discuss day in day out in the executive meetings and with the male and female colleagues. I'm glad we did all of those and got the support needed internally to build something high value for our customers who really wanted the information about their cycles to be part of their overall health and wellness picture. Big congratulations to two members of my team  Chun Pan , who seeded this project, and to  Allison Wu , who laid out the vision and made it happen. #femalehealth #productsuccess #healthandwellness

title: Fall In Love With GST
content:
Today my Lyft driver was a total inspiration! He lost 140 lbs in 2017; he quit drinking, he got back to working out (he works out 4am to fit it into his schedule), and he reverted his Type 2 Diabetes as a result. 👌🏻👏🏻 His trigger for all these changes: his mother got really sick and asked him quit drinking and try to be healthy. He was glad to do it as he lost his Mother 9 months through these changes. What are you planning to achieve or change in 2018? Where could you find triggers that deeply matter to you?  My big lifestyle change I aim to achieve is to get back to meditation. I used to do it and lost the practice due to super busy lifestyle. As someone who study and research these topics day in day out, I know getting that 10-20 minutes back for meditation every day will allow me to be more mindful, more effective, more productive, and more relaxed. I hope all of us have clear 2018 goals and work towards achieving them throughout the year.  #inspiration #newyearresolution #newyeargoals #storiesworthsharing

content:
Healthcare Workers’ Parallel Pandemic: Chronic Stress It’s no surprise that  doctors and nurses who go to work in an active battle zone, will,  at some point, start to feel anxious, worried, and stressed. This battle combatant is a wildly contagious disease called COVID-19. Doctors, nurses, aides, medical techs, clerks, environmental service workers feel threatened for their lives by just doing their jobs. And it is not clear if Americans really appreciate the level of risk, exposure and selflessness that all medical workers do for all of us. When I worked in a busy inner-city ER, I felt rushed, stressed and at times, worried for my safety: every now and then, some patient would come after a nurse or doctor with a knife or gun. But in comparison to treating patients with COVID? No comparison—treating patients with a highly contagious disease and with patients that are really ill, is way, way harder. My heart goes out to all healthcare workers.  The way we can support healthcare workers is by masking-up and keeping our distance. Selected Except: “We put on our masks and come to work every day because we don’t have the luxury of working from home in our pajamas, but the apathy and ennui that’s taken hold of society just makes our job feel thankless. It’s so demoralizing.”

title: Find Out How I Cured My OPERATING SYSTEM In 2 Days
content:
Speaking Truth to Power In classical Greece, "speaking truth to power" was known as parrhesia. The tactic is similar to satyagraha (literally, "truth-force") which Mahatma Gandhi used in seeking independence from British India. It is never out-of-fashion to speak Truth to Power.  But as writer Noam Chomsky asserts: "power knows the truth already, and is busy concealing is.”  It is the oppressed who need to hear the truth, not the oppressors. And who can argue with this?  As 2020 marched along and COVID-19 continued to worsen, all of us ‘regular’ people knew the virus was spreading and getting worse and yet, those charged with prioritizing fact, science and public wellness, buried the truth...And many more Americans are dead and sick because of it. As the promise of 2021 opens, I’m hopeful that we will have more transparency and more “Truth-Force” in managing the pandemic.  Selected Quote: Dr. Fauci described the “liberating feeling” of once again being able to “get up here and talk about what you know — what the evidence, what the science is — and know that’s it, let the science speak.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: POLITICAL An Incredibly Easy Method That Works For All
content:
Hmmm. The Dream Team of Healthcare Talent Can't Score... Apparently Haven, a radically new healthcare company led by the CEO's of Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JP Morgan Chase has folded, just 3 years in... Turns out, this company, filled with the world's top brainiacs, had executed their own projects separately, with their own employees, obviating the need for their own joint venture! Why form a team if everyone is planning to score points on their own?  Could it be that these folks view themselves as so smart that they felt their plan was the best (and only) plan? Could it be these super stars couldn't compromise? Could it be that these titans couldn't appreciate that 'perfect is the enemy of good?' Or, could it be that none of them realized that 'healthcare could be so complex...'  Count me as sad. A dream crushed! I had high-hopes that new thinking would lead to new care. We certainly need new ways of doing old things--especially in health care delivery.  I'll look forward to following the story as it unfolds. Who knows...maybe soon there will be a 'tell-all' book!

title: Fascinating BANKING Tactics That Can Help Your Business Grow
content:
I’m actually jealous  It doesn’t happen often, and never when talking about medicine or healthcare, but I’m jealous of those citizens who are already receiving the COVID-19 vaccination. So says the first recipient: “I can finally look forward to spending time with my family and friends in the new year after being on my own for most of the year.” That’s the feeling I want to have—joy, relief, self-respect and duty to my country.  Good behavior with mask wearing and good citizenship are normal parts of my behavior when it comes to COVID-19, and it takes effort—I’ve got my many masks on me all the time, hand sanitizer handy. I’m weighing going (and not going) to stores, movies, not hugging friend, not going into their homes and on it goes. And I’ll keep doing all of these things but it is getting harder to do—I mean who doesn’t want to have a cozy meal with friends? I trust science and medicine—over the last 150 years, modern healthcare has done more to improve our lifespan than any other factors—clean water, clean sanitation, antibiotics, vaccinations, dental health, are the cornerstone to our collective health and why we now live past the age of 50. So when my time comes to get vaccinated, I’ll put on my Sunday Best, roll-up my sleeve and proudly get injected. 
 
 
 …see more

title: The DANCE That Wins Customers
content:
Creative Cascade at Scale  Certainly Covid-19 had been, on balance, very bad. It has, however, accelerated business goals and operations. Even in ways not planned before...like moving AA / NA meetings all virtual. Even though online rehab rose as an emergency stopgap measure, people in the field say it is likely to become a permanent part of the way substance abuse is treated.  And it turns out that ‘online’ is a highly effective tool to treat patients with behavioral health issues too. Being able to find a meeting to log into 24/7 has welcome advantages for people who lack transportation, are ill, juggling parenting or work challenges that make an in-person meeting tough on a given day and may help keep them more seamlessly connected to a support network If not for Covid, the “creative exploration” of online meetings would still have happened but much more slowly. I’m glad to finally see healthcare adopt more creative solutions, and I hope we continue to see more ‘creative cascades.’ But moving forward I sincerely hope it doesn’t another pandemic 
 
 
 …see more

title: What Make PROGRAMMING Don't Want You To Know
content:
Old-and-New Fangled Ways Help Thwart Suicides These are tricky times for sure, but it seems times have been difficult for awhile for many, if you view suicide rates as a direct expression of ‘difficult times.’ For more than a decade, health officials have watched in vain as suicide rates climbed steadily — by 30 percent nationally since 2000. Doctors have traditionally gauged patients’ risks by looking at past mental health diagnoses and incidents of substance abuse, and by drawing on experience and medical instinct. But doctors and mental health experts can’t crack the code when it comes to identifying which patients are in real danger. Turns out that AI programs explore more factors and allow healthcare professionals to identify more at-risk patients. Very good news indeed. But identify people is only half the equation...the other half—arguably the most critical half—is who is most likely to profit from an intervention...and be open to the help. Reaching people to communicate that they are not alone nor misunderstood, can happen whether the old fashioned ways or new-fangled ways... The critical element is to reach people...using AI and other predictive capabilities certainly can help reach more people and is the finest use of technology that I can contemplate.

Amen to this sentiment.  Nurses, doctors, respiratory therapists do not study hard, take exams and dedicate their lives to caring for others just to be mistreated, disrespected and not listened to by patients. I’ll say this again: healthcare professionals do not have to take care of sick people —they can refuse to care for a patient or stop working all together.  Our healthcare providers are becoming burned out and bummed out. Healthcare professionals receive profound satisfaction from taking care of patients. However, they too have limits and nothing rubs caregivers the wrong way more than patients who don’t show personal accountability for their actions and behaviors. “They tell you there must be another reason (besides COVID) they are sick. They call you names and ask why you have to wear all that ‘stuff’ because they don’t have covid because it’s not real. Yes. This really happens.”  “These people really think this isn’t going to happen to them. And then they stop yelling at you when they get intubated.” As my mother used to say: “It’s good to have an open mind but not so open that your brains fall out.” Amen

Every one wants to enjoy the holidays and who can blame us? It’s been a terrible year for infectious diseases (well, really only one...) and it’s wreaking havoc. Every single day, more than 150,000 of our beloved American friends and family members are getting infected. And every single day 1,200 friends and family members are dying. It’s sobering and it’s scary. But those of us that have the strength of body and mind can help reduce the fear, and help reduce the spread of this Killer (COVID-19) by showing their love and neighborliness by wearing a mask and keeping some distance—even during these times of gatherings.  (After all, a mask is just a mask...just like a broken arm needs a cast, it’s just a cast...) title: 3 DRAWING Secrets You Never Knew
content:
Got A Heart? Read This News About Blood Pressure Turns out there are “three B’s” we should focus on when we think about our heart health: Blood pressure, Blood glucose (sugars), and Blood cholesterol. People with high blood pressure are also more likely to have higher cholesterol and blood glucose levels. And this is important because heart issues still kill many more Americans than other diseases. Recent studies have found that for every 10 mm increase in systolic blood pressure, the risk of calcium deposits and cardiovascular events rose accordingly. The ideal strategy for optimal health is to focus on all risk factors — blood cholesterol, blood sugar and blood pressure.  This might be boring but it’s important: Maintaining a healthful diet, exercising, not smoking and consuming alcohol only in moderation is good for your heart health.

title: Cracking The FASHION DESIGN Code
content:
Dogs are people’s best friends…Especially Now.
 
 Studies show that they help us lower our blood pressure and deal with stress. But we don’t need studies to tell us what we know already! Dogs also help us get more exercise and spend more time in nature. They always love us and they are always happy to see us. In some ways, dogs show us what ‘goodness’ looks like in all of us too!
 
 Due to the ongoing pandemic, there has been an onslaught of negative news that can cause us to get mired in the spiral of depressing articles. However, it seems that a spike in dog adoptions during COVID-19 is one positive outcome that we can feel good about, as adoptions increased significantly in March and April. 
 
 So if you have a dog, or cat, or are thinking of adopting, make sure you have the  time--and love in your heart—to commit to them…Like they will commit to you.
 
 FTI Consulting’s Lindi Jarvis, CA, CFA, CPA CFF, and Vincent Flores, CFE contributed to this story. 
 
 
 …see more

title: It's All About (The) PAINTING
content:
Don’t We All Want To Be a VIP? VIPs get the best of everything—whether it’s the best table at a restaurant, or best seats at a ball game.  And when it comes to healthcare, VIPs get the best treatment, doctors, therapies and monitoring. ‘VIP-ness’ is a feature of American medicine.  Major hospitals throughout the country have private spaces for celebrities, the super-rich and the influential. These VIPs get the most vigorous care and therapies . . . even when there isn’t enough medicine—or even hospital beds—for the rest of us ‘regular Americans.’ In my days caring for patients, every one of them wanted desperately to be treated as a VIP. Everyone wants the best medicine and best doctors, nurses and therapies. Everyone.  Selected Excerpt:  “We know that VIPs get extraordinary care — our health-care system already distinguishes between people deemed worthy of the highest level of care, versus those deemed unworthy. And that is the fact and the reality in our society.”

title: Little Known Ways to POLITICS
content:
Feeling Stressed? Anxious? Can’t Sleep? Here’s a Prescription For You. Some doctors, nurses and therapists have been prescribing laughter to help people get through this seemingly never-ending pandemic, wild fires, unemployment, and political division.. Stress and anxiety are very real health concerns and magnifies the risk of  heart attacks and strokes. Medical studies confirm that those who tend to laugh more have a lower risk of major cardiovascular illness.  Possessing a healthy sense of humor is also associated with living longer—and having more fun while being alive! So try to bring a little more laughter into your daily life—perhaps watch a few videos of pets being silly, or children playing in a puddle of water—anything that helps you laugh! Having a good sense of humor is an excellent way to relieve stress and anxiety and bring back a sense of normalcy during these turbulent times.

title: The Death Of ZOOLOGY And How To Avoid It
content:
What Should Keep You Up At Night: No Obamacare  If the Affordable Care Act(ACA), (aka Obamacare), is struck down:  1. As many as 133 million Americans — roughly half the population under the age of 65 — have pre-existing medical conditions that could disqualify them from buying a health insurance policy or cause them to pay significantly higher premiums if the health law were overturned. 2. What’s a pre-existing condition? Common ailments such as high blood pressure or asthma, any of which could require those buying insurance on their own to pay much more for a policy, if they could get one at all. 3. And!... The coronavirus, which has infected nearly seven million Americans to date, could also be cut out of getting insurance coverage  4. And, 54 million people have conditions serious enough that insurers would outright deny them coverage if the A.C.A. were not in effect. Why every single American should care:  1. Under the A.C.A., no one can be denied coverage under any circumstance, and insurance companies cannot retroactively cancel a policy. What to do? Protect this policy. Make your voice heard. Your family will thank you. Your pocketbook will thank you. (Insurance companies will not thank you!)

title: Marriage And CRAFT Have More In Common Than You Think
content:
Girls, Women, Are People Too. ..And we own a large debt of gratitude to RBG for setting the (legal) record straight. When I was in grade school, girls were not allowed to wear pants—they had to wear dresses. Nor were girls allowed to be Team Captains for any games and we were not allowed to play certain sports. In college, I had heated discussions with my dad, an educated doctor, that it was infantilizing to call Women, girls. I would say to him that once a girl started to menstruate, she became a young woman.  (This was the era of The Woman with educational books like ‘Our Bodies, Ourselves.’) And when I started my professional life, I was aware of how the men got better assignments, and how my male peers were never asked to ‘prep a room’ for an upcoming meeting, or to take notes (because ‘girls have neater handwriting’). For so long, the Working World has been slyly, perhaps unconsciously biased against women. It is much  improved from where it was even 20 years ago. And it’s not because ‘opinions naturally evolve...’ Its because of hard work. Regardless of one’s political opinion, it is true nonetheless that all Americans—and businesses—have benefited from pushing equality and justice for those of all genders, races, beliefs.  After all, what more American that that?

title: The Single Most Important Thing You Need To Know About PROGRAMMING
content:
Anger as a Poison Anger is a trickster—it starts out like a warm hug, providing immediate reassuring feedback. But keep it around too long, and it becomes a toxin that circulates in the bloodstream, poisoning all organs and causing self-loathing and irrational hatred for others.  Trust me I’ve been down this destructive road. At first, and for some months, the hatred provided a sense of ‘righteousness’ and ‘rightfullness.’ But I only became more and more irritable and dark.  So it goes with all hate—the hater turns to loathing of everything and everyone.  It’s critical to turn your back on anger because nothing positive comes from it. One way to do that is by breathing slow and regular, and by mentally pinpointing the ‘core nut’ of what is causing the anxiety or anger. Once the core nut is identified then mentally think through how to address that problem in your own life—not how to solve the problem flat-out.  Life gets better with less worry, anxiety and hate.

title: 5 Problems Everyone Has With POLITICAL – How To Solved Them
content:
The Provider Will Dial-You In Now... Have you tried a telehealth visit with your doctor or nurse? Or have you (stoically) decided to have an in-person doctor’s visit? Seems like some visits are in fact better—or not worse—done online...And one of visit-types that do just fine online is talk ltherapy. The evidence so far from these equivalency trials, comparing face-to-face versus over video — every trial  shows no difference in clinical outcomes.  And, from clinical point of view, the clinician  can often learn more over video than in person, because you see people moving in their natural habitat, where they live, maybe how they interact with others. And patients like being at home. There’s a comfort level at home,  sitting there in bed with one’s dog, that allows the patient to talk about things they maybe wouldn’t have in the office, because of how painful the experience or memories are. If you are a person who might benefit from talk therapy, give it a try! If you hate it, you can always just hang up...

title: Essential FASHION DESIGN Smartphone Apps
content:
Virtual Visits: Friend or Foe? Technology-enabled healthcare is here to stay, and growing. No question that telehealth visits, remote patient monitoring, point-of-care testing is the  start of a much larger—and rapidly growing—area of development.  And while many are bullish on the vast benefits of digital care including reaching people who can’t access healthcare or where healthcare is scarce, or in conflict zones, it turns out to have very real limitations. Not surprisingly gaps in equity and access show-up even in this ‘virtual’ healthcare model too. (Gaps access and equity are well documented in ‘the real-world’ of health care.) According to researchers at UCSF, virtual  visits require patients to have the knowledge and capacity to get online, operate and troubleshoot audiovisual equipment and it requires internet service and cell phones or other devices.  But more than a third of adults over age 65 face potential difficulties seeing their doctor via telemedicine, with the greatest challenges experienced by older, low-income men in remote or rural areas, especially those with disabilities or poor health. Buyer beware... Selected Excerpt: “Telemedicine is not inherently accessible, and mandating its use leaves many older adults without access to their medical care.”

title: The Number One Reason You Should (Do) FASHION DESIGN
content:
How To Be The Most Unloved Person: Now a days it’s kinda of easy to raise the ire of fellow Citizens. Two ways that are in the news include common activities that force (by their nature) people to be in close proximity to each other. First is shopping in stores like Walmart and Costco and not wearing a mask. (What is it about Walmart?) Even though it is required to wear a mask, some individuals feel it is their ‘American Right’ to be sanctimonious, selfish and down-right mean. This is a ‘no-brainer’ way to become instantly unlovable. The second way is to board a plane and refuse to put on a mask. It’s just like if a passenger where to light up a cigarette mid-fight. Either behavior will get a person removed from a plane but nowadays, not wearing a mask during a flight will cause the pilots to turn the plane around. Wowza. Nothing could top that in turns of becoming The Most Hated Person. These types of pointless and unnecessary acts of ‘rebellion’ would occasionally happen in the hospital when patients would refuse blood draws or an X-ray. However, those patients only harmed themselves, not me. Here’s how to avoid being the most despised Person: Wear a mask, have respect for your fellow Americans and just simply return to being a decent human being.

title: Make Your PAINTINGA Reality
content:
Surprise! And Not In A Good Way.... You might think that when you go in for surgery at your favorite hospital, they have all the staff and expertise to actually ‘do’ your surgery...but you’d be wrong! Turns out—kinda on a whim—the surgeon can decide to add independent consultants to help him/her with the surgery! And those added consultants—called surgical assistants—don’t have a medical or nursing license...And, they are often not covered by insurance.  So the doctors and surgical assistants make more money, and the patient is stuck with a big bill. I can’t imagine going to a surgeon who needs to add outside help to perform any surgery—hospitals have very strong OR certified special nurses and techs who are experts in operating rooms...and they are covered by insurance! So what’s going on? Another way private equity companies are ripping off the Healthcare Patient.   Some of the larger surgical assistants Private equity firms often target segments of the health care system where patients have little choice in who provides their care. The private equity business models include keeping such helpers out-of-network so they can bill patients for larger amounts than they could negotiate from insurance companies. Take Away: Ask if ALL of your surgical team are in-network.

content:
Women Pioneers—Womaneers—Should Inspire All Who Aspire To Be Their Best Selves  The U.S. Navy has its first Black female tactical jet pilot, Lt. j.g. Madeline Swegle. First Ever—This is news all Americans should celebrate! There was another history-making military achievement this week. A female Army National Guard soldier graduated from the grueling Special Forces, making her the first woman to join the Green Berets. I was raised in a family where both my mom and dad told all their children that, with hard work and grit, we could be anything we wanted to be. These were Big Words coming from people who lived in an era when women typically stayed home to care for ‘the family.’ And when I met my husband, I learned that his Great Aunt was Emilia Earhart—a true and early—Womaneer! For those that aspire to be more, or do more, I say this: Take a breath, square your shoulders, and walk forward—and keep going till you reach your goal. content:
Habit and Discipline: Borrrring—But... No one likes to do things that are hard or uncomfortable or not fun! I mean, who likes to dental floss or diet? I get it. But people  who are able to think beyond ‘the here-and-now’ do it all the time.  They can put off something they want ‘now’ because they can think about ‘later.’  Often when I hear people talk about why they quit smoking or lost a lot of weight, it’s often because that person is thinking about being alive to see their child’s graduation, or because they have a personal goal of climbing a mountain or running a 10K. Wearing a mask is absolutely the same: doing something uncomfortable ‘now’ for some benefit that accrues ‘later...’ My advice? Pick a goal that is in the future and adjust your behavior to ensure you and your loved ones are alive and well to realize it... title: The Ultimate Deal On DRAWING
content:
In Healthcare, There Are Now Prices Listed Do you ever go to a restaurant or hardware store and buy things without knowing what it will cost? Absolutely not. There are always prices listed. Until now, when you go see your doctor or go to the hospital for a scheduled procedure, consumers never (ever) knew what it would cost. And if you ever asked anyone working there what something would cost, they could never tell you—because they didn’t know either!  Now consumers and patients get to see a price list for services before they are stuck with a bill! Just like absolutely every other thing— Under the rule, hospitals must list standard prices for 300 “shoppable services,” as well as the lowest prices they will accept from consumers paying out of pocket. Guess whose unhappy? The new price transparency rule is receiving tremendous pushback from the hospital industry. Guess whose happy? All of us that need health care services. And it’s especially  important if you pay out of pocket or have a sizable deductible. Finally some good news.

title: 7 Easy Ways To Make PAINTING Faster
content:
Do We Really Need All Those Doctor’s Visits? No... And it took a pandemic to prove it to all of us...again.  Experts have been telling us for years that at least 15-30% of healthcare and procedures are simply unnecessary. And not only unnecessary, but could cause other medical problems due to the chance of experiencing a medical error.  Why Is there so much unnecessary care? Because  care is driven by many forces: “defensive” medicine by doctors trying to avoid lawsuits; a reluctance on the part of doctors and patients to accept diagnostic uncertainty (which leads to more tests); the exorbitant prices that American doctors and hospitals charge, and the pervasive belief that newer, more expensive technology is always better. Consider this: Perhaps Americans don’t require the volume of care that their doctors are used to providing. Know what I say? Stay home to get better.

title: Cracking The GRAPHIC Code
content:
Recapturing Impulsiveness: Big Food Wants You Back There was a huge surge in sales of packaged food in mid-March including loads of snack foods like chips and cookies—and the Big Food Companies want to keep it that way.  Data from the research firm Nielsen that tracked Americans’ grocery buying from March to May bore this out. Campbell’s reaped a 93 percent increase in sales of its canned soup, General Mills, breakfast cereal jumped to 37 percent in the third week of April and Americans continue to by  51 percent more frozen waffles, pancakes and French toast from Kellogg’s. And so on. Tricky advertising will continue since the Companies are on the record: They want to ‘Recapture Impulsiveness.’ Which means getting the consumer to purchase fundamentally unhealthy and non-valuable foods. Don’t do it. Don’t allow these times of uncertainty get under your skin—literally. Highly processed foods are called ‘food stuff’ for a reason—because they are not real food. And these fake foods will ‘up’ your blood pressure, weight, and cholesterol if they become part of a daily diet. Eating well is another way  to protect your health. I say Recapture The Joy of Fruits and Vegetables!

It would be the second biggest transformative event of my youth—the first being a 10 day backpacking trip I went on at age 14, sponsored by my school. Ever since then, I’ve benefited wildly. Running and hiking have given me fresh air, time for reflection, and a better cardiovascular system.  And while I joined a gym years ago, the second the weather turns nice, I’m outside. So now that gyms are closed, I’m not sure I’m going back. Being ‘forced’ to spend time outside is, well, a gem.  Seeing blue skies, noticing how the grass shifts in the breeze, seeing new flowers is the stuff of real-life.

content:
Why America Needs The World Health Organization This might fall under the category of ‘boring but important,—‘ not every thing can be fun-and-games... The World Health Organization (WHO), founded in 1948, has a broad mandate to “act as the directing and coordinating authority on international health work” within the United Nations system. It is made of 1948. Sound like something we need right about now? When we have a Global Pandemic? YES is the answer. Yes. But the US Government is cutting funding and America is the largest funder. This is like if you fired your doctor because he gave you bad news. Sure, it happens but not to people who are critical thinkers and want to succeed. But this administration—and its talking heads— are pointing fingers, trying to blame them for—well, does it matter? Claims of slow response, failure to mobilize resources, failure to perceive the deadly impact of this global disease sounds like a complaint against this administration, not WHO. We need all the smart scientists, doctors and data now more than ever. In fact everyone is counting on them to develop vaccines and medications. We certainly are not looking to Talking Heads to develop these drugs and tests.  Keep funding WHO. Otherwise we are lighting a match to burn down our own homes.

title: How To Learn PROGRAMMING
content:
Traditionally, it’s been the CDC’s role to give the public and local officials guidance and science-based information during public health crises. During this one, however, the CDC has been sidelined.  But worry not! The CDC—which, let’s remember, stands for Centers for Disease Control!—actually has a detailed plan for reopening all aspects of businesses and social services!  And yet....The Trump administration shelved this very document created by our nation’s top disease investigators.  Let me ask, ‘When you get sick, do you call your doctor’s office for medical care, or do you call your politician for medical care?’ Why on earth would we care what a political organization has to say about a pandemic? There used to be a joke among those of us in medicine.  We would say that doctors always thought they were qualified do other—unrelated—jobs, like run hospitals even though they didn’t know how to open an excel file.  Trust me when I say that anytime someone extends themselves outside of their training and experience, it never works out optimally. My advice—as a trusted healthcare profession—is this:Find the CDC guidelines for reopening, print it or save it, and use it...and use only it to guide your every move.

title: Why Some People Almost Always Make/Save Money With ART
content:
“Personally I'm always ready to learn, although I do not always like being taught.” Winston Churchill   Take for example the ‘new thing’ we’ve all had to learn about face coverings: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says "everyone should wear a cloth face cover when they have to go out in public" to help slow the spread of the Corona Virus.  Mind you almost 70,000 Americans have died of this disease so far.   And yet, some people just don’t want to learn.  The response in the city of Stillwater Oklahoma which is requiring citizens to wear face coverings (like so many other states),  threatened store employees with physical violence and showered with verbal abuse.  Learning and ‘being taught’ new things is at the core of advancement—or ourselves and for our country. And to my way of thinking, learning new things is foundational to the American Experience and what makes this country unique among others.   So, when did American Exceptionalism turn into ignoring science, fact and honoring The Self over Others?    Here’s what I learned as a child that was hard-taught but that still works today: ‘Be kind and considerate of others, and don’t be a selfish idiot,’ and you will be loved by your family, friends, co-workers and neighbors.   Why is that hard to learn?

title: The Untold Secret To POLITICAL In Less Than Ten Minutes
content:
What Are Hospitals to Us? Most of us don’t think too much about hospitals, that is unless you need and use them. And when you do need them, well, you need them. And often you need them close to your home and in your community. But even as hospitals in cities like New York City and Detroit have been deluged with coronavirus patients, many rural facilities now have the opposite problem: their beds are near-empty, their operating rooms are silent, and they're bleeding cash. During these very irregular times, and unlike ‘normal,’ many hospitals are seeing way less patients than normal. Either because people are fearful of going to them for fear of catching  COVID-19, or also because all elective (non-urgent) surgeries and other procedures have been postponed. More than 150 hospitals and hospital systems around the country have already furloughed tens of thousands of employees. One reason why rural hospitals in some states have shut more hospitals than others: The states that refused to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act program have seen more hospital closures. Meanwhile, the pandemic has made it even harder for already financially vulnerable rural hospitals to survive. I’d be very sad if my local hospital closed. Especially if I worked there—

content:
Why I know Doctors and Nurses Will Save Us... Because Adam Sandler said so.  From somewhere deep in his apartment, Adam Sandler’s mind is summarizing why we all love these healthcare workers—and it’s because they humanly, calmly, do the daily work of ‘saving lives and stamping out disease.’  Saving lives and stamping out disease is what my doctor-father would say every day after work, when I’d ask him ‘How was work Dad?’ My father’s steady, no-ego approach to medical practice, and hearing stories over dinner about treating patients, formed my opinion (at a very young age) that healthcare and science were the most important careers one could have. This has been true for my entire life and it’s even truer now: all healthcare workers and those doing ‘first response’ work are our National Treasures. If you want to put a smile on your face, watch the video of Adam Sandler singing high praise to our doctors and nurses!

title: Take The Stress Out Of DRAWING
content:
A Few of My Favorite Things In the midst of this (hopefully) once in a lifetime pandemic, there are,surprisingly, loads of good-news stories including: -The story of the oft-shunned African migrants in Italy helping provide fresh vegetables to...Italians! —The story of a low-income-serving grocery store owner, giving away groceries to all his customers...and he plans to do it again. Why? Because he said, ‘It’s the right thing to do.’ —Many local stories of people sharing their bottled water, TP and other items with total strangers. —Stories of families singing together. Friends connecting virtually and neighbors helping neighbors like never before. This gives me hope and a warm heart.  That said, in my ‘Least Favorite’ column, there are still states that do not require ‘shelter-in-place,’ and churches encouraging large crowds of people.  Here’s the thing about diseases and viruses specifically: they are equal-opportunity infectious agents. If they had personalities, you’d find them to be non-partisan, non-sexist, non-racist, non-religious, non-anything. They love everything and everybody. And that’s the problem.  So let’s get more good stories of people (and leaders) being smart about social distancing and less stories of people believing they can rise above this virus.

title: Avoid The Top 10 Mistakes Made By Beginning PROGRAMMING
content:
These Are A Few of my Least Favorite Things: In times like these I’ve been uncertain how to feel...some times I feel scared, anxious and (to be honest), slightly paranoid. Perhaps my mood swings are due to a generalized uncertainty or because I feel that too few of our leaders are acting with confidence and facts. But I’ve found a tonic to my ills and his name is Dr.Fauci. And that is because he represents Science and Facts. And in these times, science and facts are the true messengers and Dr. Fauci and other medical professionals and researchers are helping us understand the viruses’ language. They are the people who represent hope, grace and goodness.  In times like these, we need to be singing from the same sheet music listening to only one conductor—think of it like this: We are all in the Pandemic Choir and Dr. Fauci is our conductor. Any one who wants to harm him (for whatever crazy reason), harms all of us.  There is no choir without him and people like him. Without science and facts leading the choir, we will devolve into a bunch of hyenas howling on our own rooftops.

title: How To Get (A) Fabulous BUSINESS On A Tight Budget
content:
Why Followership is More Important than Leadership. With everything going on (you know what I mean...) there seems to be an uptick on advice on Leading or Leadership. Topics like  ‘How to be a Good/Great Leader During Times Like These’ is everywhere.  Helpful thoughts certainly but I’d suggest what is really needed right now is advice on ‘How to be a Great Follower,’ and ‘what Does Followership Look Like in Times Like These.’  First off, without Followers, Leaders fail. Leaders without Followers are either phonies, extremists or untrustworthy.  The role of Followers is not talked about enough. Followers alone are responsible for the success of Leaders. Without followers there are no leaders. For any project or organization to succeed, there must be strong, ethical people who willingly and effectively follow.  In these times—and in the context of Global Public Health Uncertainty—Followers uphold moral, cultural and community rule-of-laws. We are the Effector Arms and Legs of all the right and correct actions that must be taken. But it means honoring social distancing. But it also means considering  our neighbors and community members by not hoarding or becoming rude, disrespectful or unethical. So go and do the right thing...And as my Dad would say, ‘Stay Out of Trouble.’

Federal officials on Monday released groundbreaking rules that will let patients download their electronic health records and other health care data onto their smartphones. “Patients should have control of their records, period. Now that’s becoming a reality,” said Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar. “These rules are the start of a new chapter in how patients experience American health care.” Who are the winners? Patients, people and medical providers who want to understand, manage and control their medical and healthcare needs. Who are the losers? Electronic Medical/Health Record (EMR/EHR) companies who want to own your data to make even more money off your pain and suffering. Finally patients will have all the information at their fingertips  to help them make timely decisions —a good first step for all of us.

Sloppy—and dangerous—Care is What Our Seniors are Getting. In recent years, the federal government has been ramping up the standards for nursing homes, but inspectors remain frustrated by the prevalence of sloppy or nonexistent handwashing.  4 in 10 nursing homes have been cited for an infection-control lapse. And these are at the ‘5 Star’ places. Workers are not washing their hands as they moved to the next patient, or failing to don masks, gloves and gowns when in the rooms of contagious patients in isolation. Why? Many of the nursing homes are privately owned or backed by for-profit owners who cut staff and pay low wages. So it’s hard to get well trained, dedicated staff. In my opinion nothing is more ugly than a country that abandons their responsibility for it’s aging citizenry.  Ensuring patients are safely cared for in a dignified manner is all of our responsibility. As family members visiting nursing homes you should ask the aides if they’ve washed their hands prior to touching your loved one.  Hand washing is the Number One best activity to prevent the spread of Infection so ask about it every single time anyone walks into a room. I’m dead serious.

And they have separate doors and decor, much like any professional medical office. Walmart Health is partnering at the facility with “several on-the-ground health providers to be a first-of-its-kind health center to deliver primary and urgent care, labs, X-ray and diagnostics, counseling, dental, optical and hearing services all in one facility,” the retail giant said in a statement.  Pricing will also be “transparent” regardless of a patient's insurance status, noted the company.  How do you feel about getting healthcare services from a non-traditional provider? I think the market has already spoken on this: the general public is already making decisions based on convenience and price. Loyalty to a specific brand (eg Mayo Clinic), and specific doctor, just doesn’t matter so much, especially to younger people. No doubt that healthcare services are getting baked into our shopping lives and blurring the lines between ‘medical’ services and activities of daily life. title: 10 Unforgivable Sins Of BUSINESS
content:
What Type Are You? Glass Half-Full, or Half-Empty? People who view life as ‘glass half-full’ tend to be more optimistic and believe ‘things will work out.’ Those of us who are ‘glass half-empty’ are always preparing for things to go awry... But an increasing number of recent long-term studies have linked greater optimism to a lower risk of developing cardiovascular disease and other chronic ailments and to fostering “exceptional longevity,” a category one team of researchers used for people who live to 85 and beyond. I guess this makes  sense...Optimists tend to take better care of their health. They’re more likely to exercise and eat better and are less likely to smoke, while pessimists bathe their bodies in damaging stress hormones! The good news is that we can change the way we think! The first step is to learn to catch yourself when thinking negatively—just that thought alone can can help turn ‘glass half-empty’ people into ‘glass half-full’ people! Selected Excerpt: “It’s never too early and it’s never too late to foster optimism. From teenagers to people in their 90s, all have better outcomes if they’re optimistic.”

Providers might be in their kitchen, wearing pajamas while virtually treating patients in the ICU...patients might be in their living room while getting medical attention. And honestly, I’m not sure how well ‘virtual assistants (or assistance) can hep with this! Unlike humans, computers do not get tired, bored or distracted toward the end of a long day of reading mammograms. And, they have great bedside manners! This list, in contrast, is useful!  I absolutely agree with the idea of making—and fostering—local, ‘lite’ friendships. (I disagree with calling these casual or lite friendships ‘weak ties,’ but we get the point.) I find that I really enjoy being “known” and feeling “part of the fabric” of my community and work place.  Making local ‘ties’ is really useful whether that is at work where you engage in chit-chat with other staff you don’t know very well, or at your local gym or coffee shop. The exercise is to ‘purposefully’ extend yourself to be better known and ‘seen.’ Key take away: try to extend yourself to others just a little bit more and in turn, you’ll feel more part of your work place and community. Be kind to yourself. Be aware of others.  And Happy Holidays!

You Are On Your Own (YOYO): Many of us were otherwise occupied listening to other news of the day (or decade), so its easy to understand missing this: the Affordable Care Act was struck down by a federal court. ‘Who cares?’ you may say...You care—regardless of political party. And here’s why: Without this program and protection, anyone—and I mean 50 million of us—can and will be kicked off or denied health insurance if we have a pre-existing medical condition (and who doesn’t?). Also anyone over 26 is YOYO—You’re On Your Own’ to pay those hefty insurance premiums. And flat-out, a cool 17 million Americans will lose their coverage. And yes I know that if you have a job and your company happens to include healthcare insurance in your benefits, this does not affect you—yet. Higher premiums are coming to you. And if you believe the politicians who say to you that they ‘are committed to ensuring  affordable, high quality healthcare is available,’ they are telling tall tales.  And here’s why: healthcare insurance companies are not in business to make less profits and people with pre-existing conditions are a total money loser for these companies.  I find it particularly ironic that many of us are receiving this ‘gag gift’ during the ‘season of giving.’

If you are ‘senior,’ and you need surgery, read this! Recently published in JAMA Surgery, has found that frail, older adults are more likely than other patients to die after even supposedly minor procedures — and even when the surgery goes well, without complications. Frail, older patients frequently undergo such operations, which surgeons tend to see as routine, simple fixes — but may not be. “Our data indicate that there are no low-risk procedures among patients who are frail,” according to new research. Screening patients for frailty may allow those facing greater risk to begin several weeks of so-called pre-habilitation, to improve their nutrition and endurance. Selected excerpt:  “Our data indicate that there are no low-risk procedures among patients who are frail,” study authors say.

content:
Pop-Up Barber Shops Help Memory Impaired! Finally some uplifting news—kind people doing generous things. Here is a story of a barber setting up ‘make-shift’ barbershops in nursing homes for people with dementia: Lenny White gathers up his supplies for the day: a red, white and blue striped barber pole, hair clippers and a table-top jukebox -- all the makings of a pop-up barbershop, catered to a very special group of clients. Mr. White is a barber who gives hair cuts to those with dementia—in the nursing home.  Dementia has been recognized as a public health priority by the World Health Organization, and for good reason. According to the WHO, there are 50 million people living with dementia around the world, with an additional 10 million being diagnosed every year.  There is currently no cure for dementia, so healthcare providers are turning to life-enrichment alternatives for their patients, meaning services like White's are likely to increase. Selected Excerpt: "It [helps] bring back memories of times gone by," White said. "Trying to bring a bit of positivity into the day that can be quite difficult for them."

According to the Georgetown University, the number of uninsured children increased by more than 400,000 and is due in large part to policies championed by the Trump administration and Republicans in Congress. Everyone—and I mean everyone—says ‘Children are our future.’ And it is often the rallying cry at the beginning of many debates and protests. Take education or climate change or infrastructure—When politicians or parents or policy makers talk on these subjects the reasons ‘why’ we should make changes and improvements is for our kids and grand kids. So how does it make any sense to then to allow these very same kids to go without proper medicine, and doctors visits and immunizations and medical check-ups?  How are they to live their best lives and ensure our ongoing success if they are malnourished, or ill from childhood disease? Honestly, ensuring kids have healthcare is not only a ‘no-brainer,’ it’s the only kind, decent, American (and spiritual) action to take.

Almost 8,000 households would lose benefits entirely and struggled to put dinner on the table.  3.  Those who live in cold northern states will be very cold this winter because of changes in the way heating costs will be calculated. If America wants to build a ‘Culture of Health,’ it needs to advance policies which support good health, nutrition and warm homes and safe streets... Wow. Many of us who follow ‘deep learning’ and AI markets have seen this in radiological images (X-rays), and now there is evidence that machine-based data accumulation can ‘crunch’ and analyze information to provide better diagnoses than a doctor who has seen hundreds (or thousands) of patients with a similar disease or problem.  Think of what this can do to bring more reliable diagnoses to patients and, think about how such technologies can help patients in under-resourced areas get diagnosed and treated sooner. Talk about Democratizing health care! This is a huge leap forward for Public Health. Now....how do we get Humans to trust Machines?? Selected Excerpt: “"Machines... can have a massive impact on problems in healthcare, big and small, but unless we can convince clinicians and the public of its safety and ability then it won't be much use to anybody..”

Bullies are bad AND, they are bad for your Health.  Harassment can cause anxiety, high blood pressure, sleepless nights, and job loss. What  defines a person as a true bully? If that person regularly makes you feel "oppressed, humiliated, de-energized or belittled."  Just like ice cream, bullying comes in different flavors but unlike ice cream, none of them tasty. There is verbal bullying and passive-aggressive and cyber bullying and of course, there is physical bullying. What to do? Here are a few strategies: Pitty them—assume they are screwed-up and try compassion.  Pick your battles—strike back verbally or through formal complaints. Psych them out—act irrationally like respond with humor. Get a posse—band together with others to demonstrate strength in numbers. But mostly stay safe and if needed report it, or leave. Surprise! Here’s Your Medical Bill You Didn’t Think You Were Getting...and Don’t Want! Key House and Senate panels have approved proposals that would limit patients’ financial liability if they visit an out-of-network hospital or are treated by an out-of-network provider during an emergency. Powerful doctor and hospital groups are stepping up their opposition to those measures and have mobilized lobby lawmakers and their staff against the effort. Sure, everyone needs to get paid for work done but when you go to the ER after being hit by a bus, you can’t know if the ambulance is taking you to an “in-network” doctor or hospital.   Which is what happened to one person who, after being hit by a bus, taken to the ER, then received a $27,000.00 bill—guess he went to the wrong place!! This could affect us all since it also applies to people who go to the ER because they think they—or their child—is sick. But if you do not need ‘emergency care,’ your insurance company will deny the bill and you will be charged out-of-pocket dollars. Truly scary since medical expenses are the number 1 reason for personal bankruptcies.

You Are What You Eat—Regardless Of Politics  We all know that the more processed the food, (meaning food that has added the more salt, saturated fats, sugar, refined flour) the worse it is for us, leading to diabetes and obesity.  It’s also clear that more red meat is no good for our heart, or blood pressure. Diseases such as atherosclerosis, heart disease, stroke, obesity and Type 2 diabetes are called Lifestyle Diseases because they are caused by eating processed foods.  The government is limiting scientific input to the 2020 dietary guidelines, raising concerns among, well every one like scientists, doctors, nutritionists and parents. So why limit what the USDA can study and recommend? Well, because there is one group who thrives off of high-sodium, high-sugar, high-saturated fat and highly processed foods and it’s the  large food companies. Sadly we probably cannot look to the Food Pyramid as our nutritional ‘North Star,’ so look to what farmers and grandmas have been doing—eat simple, veggie-based, whole-grain and beans foods more often than not and you’ll be in strong health! Selected Excerpt: “Half of American adults live with one or more diet-related chronic illnesses, and poor diet is the No. 1 cause of ill health in the country.”

title: 14 Days To A Better PAINTING
content:
Back to Work Blues? It’s a Real Thing. It’s Monday morning and Summer is over...You've got months before it’s Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays and Surprise!, you are feeling cranky. Doctors and mental health workers don't officially have a name for this. There's nothing specific in the official manual of mental disorders. But the Twitterverse calls your sadness  #backtoworkblues  or  #holidayblues . Kids get it too. You know the feelings—cranky, uninspired by a million emails, unmotivated to deal with trivial (or big) work assessments, uninterested in petty complaints by co-workers and all you want to do is return to your summer lounge chair! What to do?   First off, know that transitions between play and work are rough, so give yourself a little breathing room to be OK with it being a bit tough for a period.  Consider booking another short getaway you can look forward to, ease back into work, add something new into your life like a cooking class or new exercise. Remember, there’s always next summer to plan for! Selected Excerpt: "The stark contrast of the joy and freedom of family and friend time with the drudgery of answering a zillion work emails, can be hard on your emotional well-being,"

My sweet dog got sepsis and went into shock and was on death’s door. Happily, and surprisingly, she survived!! Sepsis, which strikes humans and animals alike  is a big deal and takes over 270,000 human lives every year.  Sepsis can be a life-threatening condition that arises when the body's response to infection causes injury to its own tissues and organs—think of an ‘infection gone bad.’  Common signs and symptoms include fever, increased heart rate, increased breathing rate, and confusion.  September is Sepsis Awareness month.  Please know the facts.

title: What You Can Learn From Bill Gates About POLITICS
content:
American Ingenuity: Get Healthcare in Mexico  So, American doctors, American healthcare organizations, American insurance companies and American employers are figuring out how to provide excellent healthcare—-Do it in Mexico!... Yup—if American healthcare has become to expensive (or greedy) then the market will self-correct to maximize efficiency ...this is capitalism at its purest. But in this case we end up undercutting our own selves... Sure, we can have our own employers allow us to  hire our own American doctors to perform surgery in American certified hospitals located in other countries because it will be less expensive, but doesn’t that just seem like a big work-around to a broken system? Not to be too simplistic, but why not just lower the costs and fees on everything here, in our own country, so we can stay here to get our care?? Selected Excerpt: “The high prices charged at American hospitals make it relatively easy to offer surgical bargains in Mexico: In the United States, knee replacement surgery costs an average of about $30,000 — sometimes double or triple that — but at the Mexican hospital , it is only $12,000...” ——— LinkedIn Top Voice Healthcare 2015, 2016, 2017

Truth in Headlines Please!   I saw this headline—and thought: ‘I didn’t know Uber is also a Health Care Organization!’  And then I read the article—Uber did not build a health care organization...they added ride services for patients. Two points: it’s great to have rides for people who need to get to and from their medical appointments.  But...proving rides does not equal being a health care organization!. Doctors, nurses, hospital administrators, risk managers, technicians and other dedicated health care staff who work diligently to help patients in their medical care, recovery and illness, work in a health care organization.  And running one of those organizations is hard work—patients and families rely on those people to be dedicated, accurate , evidenced-based, accountable and compassionate. When you are an organization like a hospital that understands and lives the daily stress and responsibly for lives lost-and saved—why then, and only then can you declare your self a health care organization! Until then, you are a ride hailing company that has an important population carve-out. —- LinkedIn Top Voice Healthcare 2015, 2016, 2017

title: HR MANAGEMENT: What A Mistake!
content:
Total Rip-Off Of All Americans Boring but important is the possible striking down of Obamacare, which will mean we can expect to be ripped-off for all our health and wellbeing needs... Why?  If it goes away, open your wallets because we each will experience  increasing deductibles, being charged more if we are over 35, and having insurance companies drop expensive categories of benefits, like prescription drugs.   But wait, there’s more: many generic medications would go away.  And for all you Innovation Geeks, say good bye to innovation projects funded through Obamacare—it made sense for the government to fund programs that tried to find innovative ways that helped patients and lower costs, but this is exactly opposite for for-profit Health care that needs patients to pay top dollars for services. Oh and say good bye to restaurant calorie labeling, having medical device companies disclose gifts they make, and requiring work time and privacy for moms who need to breastfeed their babies. Why would anyone want this? LinkedIn Top Voice Healthcare 2015, 2016, 2017 Sent from my iPhone

What’s Wrong With Me? You Might Be Lonely As we all knew, being sad, anxious, lonely is bad for our health. People who are lonely live shorter lives and are more at risk for chronic illnesses like heart disease, depression, and dementia.  Weirdly, even with so many on-line connections, a full fifth of Americans feel lonely. Ways to feel less isolated and lonely? Connecting into your  ‘real community,’ yet that can be challenging for many, especially older people or people who don’t have a lot of extra time. So health insurance companies are adding ‘togetherness’ care plans which help connect patients with services and, well, help them feel less lonely! Why are insurance companies doing this? (You know there is a bottom line reason ...) Turns out if you treat Loneliness like a chronic condition, you can reduce unnecessary hospital readmissions—hence saving the insurance companies loads of money. So this is a story of ‘doing well by doing good.’ Selected Excerpt: "For too long issues like social connection have been looked at as soft subjects—the stuff that we'll get to if we can get to it, after we get people the procedures and medications they need...”

In health care, we have one last ‘closet’ to open which is mental health. Not All Hospitals Are Created Equally.Not By A Long-Shot. This article highlights a very sad story of a poorly run pediatric heart program at a highly prestigious children’s hospital. Many of the problems at this hospital are similar to problems found at other hospitals that have specialized programs, including perhaps the biggest issue: not treating enough patients per year (or case volume) to develop the needed medical expertise to reliably get safe patient outcomes. Reaching adequate case volumes to keep up skills is a challenge because so many hospitals are competing for patients — these programs are an important driver of profits, so hospitals want to keep them going. Some geographic regions (and many countries) have creative ‘regional hubs’ so that an area could only have as many cardiovascular surgical programs as the population could support...Unlike what we see in this country where competing programs might only be a few miles apart. What to do? Look up publicly reported data (Hospital Compare is a good source), ask doctors for their complication rates and ask how they compare to other, top-notch programs... title: 10 Warning Signs Of Your POLITICS Demise

Who is Responsible For Our Old People? While riding public transit today I ran across this elderly man who was displaying clear signs of dementia and appeared disheveled. He posed no risk to himself or others. Not sure if he was on his way to or from somewhere. Not sure if anyone wondered when he’d arrive or worried if he didn’t show up.  He seemed utterly alone, which seems painful given his senior years and confused state. Maybe we don’t (collectively) care...but somehow it struck a sad cord in my heart as I watched him point to no one and talk to no one. At one point in time, he was someone’s child and might be someone’s father. Where are people like this supposed to live? Who is supposed to help them. Where is our humanity—and even absent that—where is our infrastructure which should exist in a democratic society which holds that all people are created equal and deserves compassion?

title: 10 Unforgivable Sins Of MUSIC
content:
Find it Hard to Concentrate at Work? Maybe You Are Neurodivergent. Ever wondered why its so hard to concentrate at work? Two reasons: firstly, cubicles and open spaces are noisy, distracting and communal-encouraging “drop-in” meetings and interruptions. And secondly because not everyone is ‘wired’ to handle so much chatter and unpredictability. Neurodivergence describes the variations in the ways our brains function, and encompasses people on the autism spectrum and people with ADHD or dyslexia. The term has been expanding to include those with anxiety, depression, OCD, and PTSD—anything that makes a person think a bit differently.  And this can make typical work spaces and work flow challenging. However there are adjustments in a work setting that can be made, include allowing more time working from home, adjusting neurodivergent workers  start time and end time.  Allowing for this flexibility in scheduling and letting people do what they need to do to cope with noise or environment—without judgement. Selected Excerpt: “Around 50 to 75 percent of autistic people with higher education are unemployed. The unemployment rate for people receiving public mental health services is approximately 80 percent.”

How Are You Feeling Today? According to historic research there are six basic emotions: anger, fear, surprise, disgust, happiness and sadness but  new research suggests that there are at least 27 distinct emotions—and they are intimately connected with each other. In contrast to the notion that each emotional state is an island, the study found that “there are smooth gradients of emotion between, say, awe and peacefulness, horror and sadness, and amusement and adoration. In general, people can be very bad at recognizing the emotions of themselves and others, which in turn leads to a lot of misunderstandings and missteps.  In some ways, professional and personal interactions would be a lot easier if everyone used a map like the one above to identify how they are feeling.

Tea or Coffee? I love coffee but recently I visited an area in China known for Pu’er Tea. In China, Pu’er tea, made from the leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant, is created according to a specialized process and many believe in it’s unique health benefits, such as improvements in heart health and reductions in cholesterol levels.  It’s also said that Pu’er tea can help promote weight loss, enhance eyesight, stimulate circulation, and soothe hangovers! Coffee however has been shown to lower the risk of some cancers, including endometrial cancer and nonmelanoma skin cancer. A study of more than 500,000 people across the world concluded that coffee drinking was associated with reduced risk of death from various causes Tea however gets the leg up for one reason only: the plethora of powerful antioxidants and polyphenols.  Yes, coffee has them, too, but tea often has them in higher concentrations. I’m still a devoted coffee drinker but have added Pu’er tea to my weekly hot beverage line-up!

Coping when you get sick or injured—it’s tough. My husband came home yesterday in a cast after tearing his Achilles’ tendon. And he was very irked and cranky.  Every day people break bones, sprain ankles, get diagnosed with pneumonia, chicken pox, get their hip replaced and many other ailments that require people “staying put” for a week or three. So what’s the best way to move past being mad or irritated or depressed during a period of injury or illness? Step one. Accept the current reality of the situation. Step two? Reframe the situation—For example if you are ‘bummed out’ you can’t play tennis for three months, think  ‘now an opportunity to read those books I’ve been wanting to read’ or to ‘learn to cook those four dishes that I’ve  just haven’t gotten around to...’ Truth is there’s lots that can be done during this ‘down time,’ so think ‘Crisis as Opportunity.’

Oops...Before you fall in love (with technology)make sure ‘they are true-blue...’ Turns out your Apple Watch has been cheating on you! According to a massive new study just published, turns out that the pulse sensor in Apple Inc.’s watch helped detect a heart-rhythm disorder in a small number of users but may have caused false alarms for others.  As is true when it comes to physiology—and pathophysiology—our body systems are always searching for homeostasis. Meaning, our bodies are always trying to function normally and within a small band of performance. Yet normal variation exists in performance that are no big deal... Like your heart doesn’t beat exactly the same all the time. And it’s fine. Normal variation! But the Apple Watch might be mis-characterize these beats, and label them as more significant than they are. This is called a false positive! So you need to watch out for being over-treated or mis-treated if you seek care for this ‘normal’ variations. Selected Excerpt: “The study’s mixed findings hinted at the potential of “wearable” gadgets to detect asymptomatic health conditions in people that might otherwise go unnoticed.”

Decrepit at 30? Or 40? I say bring on the “Olderprenuers!” This article talks about the “psychic unrest” of tech professionals feeling old in their 30’s and 40’s...really?  Turns out that In Silicon Valley, the hiring rate seems to slow for workers once they hit 34 and the median age of a worker at Facebook, LinkedIn and SpaceX is 29. Seriously? The bias against people beyond 34 it seems is the brainwashed belief that those of us older are less mentally nimble, With a lessen associative mind. Hogwash. Take this:  research suggests that businesses started by older people tend to have a 70 per cent chance of making it through the first five years, whereas among businesses started by younger entrepreneurs, the figure is only 28 per cent.  Come on people: realize that young creative, limber-minded people grow up to be old creative limber-minded people. Geez... Selected Excerpt: “The social narrative is basically, midlife is a crisis and after a crisis you have decrepitude, But you actually are much happier in your 60s and 70s, so why aren’t we preparing for that?” 
 
 
 …see more

title: Avoid The Top 10 Mistakes Made By Beginning POLITICAL
content:
State / Federal rights versus Individual Rights: Which Right is the Supreme Right? This comes up time and time again in health care. Think: woman’s right to choose as one example) and here we go again with pediatric vaccines. At least eight states, including some that have experienced measles outbreaks this year, want to remove personal exemptions for the measles vaccine. And some states would remove the exemption for all vaccines. Like all personal choice issues, the broad question of ‘How far should the state reach to over-ride personal choice?’ is a thorny one. Vaccines, indoor smoking, women’s right to choose, are just a few examples of how State or Federal agencies reach into personal health policy. And at times—depending on the issue—you might want the government to stay away from having any influence on type of personal choice and one another medical topic you might want the government to have a heavy hand.  We are a complex and inconsistent society. Selected Excerpt: ‘courts have repeatedly held that when a public health intervention is necessary to safeguard the public, individuals generally can be required to give up some personal liberty, particularly if that liberty is tied to a government benefit like school.’ 
 
 
 …see more

title: Proof That ART Really Works
content:
Did You Know? That as of Jan. 1, in the name of transparency, all hospitals are required to post their list prices on line? Yes it’s true. What’s also true is you’ll be hard-pressed to figure out, in advance, what a medical procedure will actually cost. Having a baby? If you do it quickly (fast birth) rather than a slow labor, you’ll save upwards of $7,000.00 according to this article...but that’s not all the fees! Also added to a regular birth are things like room charges for you and baby, medication charges and so on... But don’t let all this intimidate you—simply call the hospital and ask your questions and make sure to get a good answer. If you need guidance or advocacy, give me a shout— Selected Excerpt: “From a practical standpoint, I'm not sure how useful this information is, What an individual pays to [the] hospital is going to be based on what their insurer covers."

title: 3 Ways You Can Reinvent GRAPHIC Without Looking Like An Amateur
content:
Job Seekers: This Post Is For You. Recently I wrote an article about job hopping and finding one’s own path when building a career. I was surprised by how many people responded about wanting (or needing) work.  It’s clear to me that people need some sort of ‘public square’ to shout “I need a job!’” and, “I’m very qualified in A,B,C, so please contact me at...” It is for all of you job seekers that, during this Season of Outreach, Giving and Gratitude, I dedicate this post to you. So go ahead, if you are in the market for a job, invite people to connect and contact you.  It’s hard to be in a position to ask for anything—whether it’s for a job, or a piece of bread or a warm shelter. So if you are in a position give advice or a lead (even if to listen), please do so now. After all, it is the time of year when we extend our heart and soul to strangers.

content:
As we approach The Eating Season, remember a few things... There are no ‘silver bullets’ when it comes to dieting.  Just remember that everybody is different but every body loves fresh fruits and vegetables... So try  to include them into your holiday eating—trust me, your heart (and waistline) will thank you come January! Selected Excerpt: “Dr. George Bray, an obesity researcher who is emeritus professor at the Pennington Biomedical Research Center in Baton Rouge, La., sums it up this way: “Eat the diet you like and stay with it.”

title: Your Key To Success: FASHION DESIGN
content:
Why Are Animals Still Used by the FDA? Dogs and primates are still used as disposable test subjects, confined to small pens, in labs, subjected to all kinds of experiments. I’m very (very) happy to learn that the FDA is making important progress to find alternative approaches to studying and testing new drugs and vaccines. While I understand the historic role animals have had as “lab rats,” there are simply too many options available now (like sophisticated computer-based modeling) to warrant the use of animals in scientific experimentation. If we view ourselves as a kind and decent Society, then we must support the move towards banning animal-testing.  If animals could talk, what do you think they’d want? Go ask your own dog or cat how they might feel about being poked and prodded and kept in a pen their whole lives! Selected Excerpt: "The truth is that, for scientific, ethical and economic reasons, animal experimentation is incredibly wasteful and needs to go the way of the dinosaur," he said. "Technologies that replace the use of animals are more effective." 
 
 
 …see more

title: Why Some People Almost Always Make/Save Money With MATHEMATICS
content:
What’s The Deal? We say we ‘love’ nurses but we are not willing to pay for their technical and clinical expertise? To all the Health Care and Hospital CEOs: Do you value getting high scores on Quality, Harm and Patient Experience Publicly reported goals? Well guess who’s making those high scores possible?  Whether you are a hospital CEO or MedTech CEO please know that real—actual—transformation (better, more effective medical care at lower, delivered flexibly for the patient) can only be done through nurses. Nurses are not a commodity to be “price squeezed,” but an asset to be valued. Selected Excerpt : “Up to 14% of nurses who started their careers between 2006 and 2016 have a second job of any kind...Roughly one out of 15 of the nurses surveyed signed up for extra work within 18 months of starting their careers.”

title: How To Make Your Product Stand Out With HR MANAGEMENT
content:
Don’t Go Without Health Insurance. Enrollment is Open! The Affordable Care Act (ACA) is open for health care insurance coverage. And believe me when I say that you definitely want health insurance!  Especially when something as simple as your child’s ear infection treated by your doctor could set you back several hundred dollars...or, a bad fall off your scooter (or run-in with a car at an intersection) could cost you several thousand dollars in the ER! And here’s good news: It’s the first year premiums are dropping-the cost is lower this year! And that’s true  across the spectrum for the leanest health plans to the most comprehensive.  Selected Excerpt: “This means more low-income, subsidy-eligible Americans can find a monthly premium cheap enough to be entirely covered by their subsidy.”

title: 11 Methods Of PROGRAMMING Domination
content:
If you trust medical professionals enough to: Follow their advice on 1) when to vaccinate kids, 2) when to take antibiotics for infections, 3) when to get surgery for a bum knee or hip or bad heart value, 4) or when and how much insulin to take for your diabetes or, 5) when to get a mammogram, or....then you gotta listen to them when they say gun violence is a major health problem that needs treatment. And if you ever (and I mean ever) seek treatment from your doctors and nurses for your health care, then you must support them in these efforts.  I mean, for goodness sake, they are only trying to save your life. You should thank them for sticking out their necks into these muddy waters to help all patients... Selected Excerpt: “If you are unconvinced and need examples of why firearms are a health issue, here are a few. People with accidental gun-related injury nearly always require acute medical care, and many go on to have chronic injury-related health issues. ...What about applying pressure to bleeding bullet wounds? Emergency surgery to repair shattered bodies?...These responsibilities are not only in doctors' lane, they are our job. Consequently, so is advocating for policies that reduce firearm injury to better inform policies to keep our patients safer.”

title: The Best Way To HR MANAGEMENT
content:
Nurses suffer from violence at work. I’m not surprised to read that nurses are more often harmed on the job than cops. Working with people who are sick, injured and sometimes in trouble can bring out the worse in people. When I worked in the ER I was harassed, kicked, slammed against walls and gurneys. All health care workers deserve protection against harm when trying to save lives and stamp out diseases! Selected Excerpt : “In 2016, health care and social service workers suffered 69 percent of all workplace violence injuries, and were nearly five times more likely to experience violence on the job than the average US worker. They are more likely to get injured at work than even police officers and prison guards. Nurses suffer in particular.”

title: 10 Warning Signs Of Your POLITICAL Demise
content:
Up, Up and Away: Uninsured Americans Up since 2016: Uninsured working age Americans  Up since 2016: Health insurance rates among lower income Americans  Up since 2016: Uninsured Americans in states that did not expand Medicare  Up since 2016: Uninsured Americans aged 35 and older The marked gains in health insurance coverage made since the passage of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) in 2010 are beginning to reverse. If you have any pre-existing medical problems (like asthma, diabetes, heart disease, back pain, arthritis, ..), or if care about cost of medications or what you will need to pay out-Of-pocket, then you absolutely want to keep the ACA around. My message: VOTE like your life depends on it.
