title: How To Turn Your DANCE From Zero To Hero
content:
Older Patients Are People Too I’m so pleased to read about medical schools adding courses in geriatrics that include hearing from and engaging with healthy seniors. When you are a clinician, you only see people when they are ill, so it’s easy to believe that the only type of senior citizens that exist are sick ones. So it’s critical to realize that mostly people are healthy and living full lives—even people who are in their 70’s, 80’s, and beyond!  Dispelling the notion that seniors are ‘too old to treat,’ or ‘should expect to be tired, lazy or depressed,’ is critical to being a great doctor or nurse. Not long ago when my mother was ill and in a rehab unit, her doctor told her she only had a week or so to live. Her reply was ‘If you stay my doctor that’s true.’ She ignored his advice to get into Hospice care and she continued to live another 2 years.  Selected Excerpt: “Unfortunately, most education takes place within the hospital,” he told me. “If you’re only seeing the hospitalized elderly, you’re seeing the debilitated, the physically deteriorating, the demented. It’s easy to pick up ageist stereotypes.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: How We Improved Our POLITICAL In One Week(Month, Day)
content:
I say ‘So Long, Sayonara and Adios’ to Skilled Nursing Facilities. One-in-three patients in skilled nursing facilities suffered a medication error, infection or some other type of harm related to their treatment—much higher medical error rates than hospitals. And 60% of the errors are preventable according to physician reviews. The injuries and deaths were caused by substandard treatment, inadequate monitoring, delays or the failure to provide needed care (According to CMS) With over 70% of the Skilled Nursing Facilities (SNF) operating as for-profit, and with pressure from company owners to maximize revenues, it should come as no surprise that ‘word on the street’ is to stay away from SNF unless there is a very rare exception. (Yes, I know there are some ‘good ones’ out there by data will tell you it’s about 5% of the market.) The rise in post-acute options like Home Care is hopeful, and promises more personalized, technology-enabled, timely care...all while in the comforts of home. It is time for this underperforming and antiquated sector to fade away. Selected Excerpt: “Thirty years ago, 90 percent of Medicaid dollars for long-term care. Now only 43 percent of Medicaid’s long-term care expenditures. It’s good news for consumers — but not so good for nursing homes.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: What Alberto Savoia Can Teach You About POLITICS
content:
Since When Do We Play ‘Quid Pro Quo’ with Basic Healthcare? No job? No Health Care. Sorry. Our U.S. Administration does not care if you are an American. Can’t pay? Can’t work? No Health Care for you. Your screwed. Bummer for you.  “Community engagement requirements (meaning—you have a job and  you are working) are not some subversive attempt to just kick people off of Medicaid," Seema Verma, head of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services...” and yet 4,300 people were denied their medical coverage in Arkansas alone in one month—because of this rule. So I would submit a counter-point: “Uh...apparently it is.” Arkansas became the first state, in Medicaid's 53-year history, to strip coverage from beneficiaries for not meeting work requirements.  And next up is Indiana and New Hampshire (What happened to the State’s motto of ‘Live Free or Die?’ Maybe the revised state motto should be “Forced to Work or Die from Lack Of Health Care.) If you don’t feel a chill down your spine then you don’t grasp the far reaching nature of this governmental over-reach.  What’s next? Gotta prove you don’t have a pre-existing condition or that you don’t over eat? Yikes.  #healthcare   #paytolive 
 
 
 …see more

title: How To Find The Right PROGRAMMING For Your Specific Product(Service).
content:
Oops Wrong Conclusion: This is Why Its Hard to Advance Medicine and Public Health  Remember when “low-fat and high-carb” diets were all the rage, only to be proved (years later), to lead to weight gain, diabetes and heat disease—in part because of all the sugar added to processed foods? Or remember the buzz that oatmeal will stave-off heart disease? (Or eating only meat will not cause heart disease?!!)  And I can’t keep up—is coffee good or bad for us?? Well now we can add the lowly and pure aspirin to the list of things that don’t actually help stave-off heart disease (assuming you are just fine). With so much hyping by the food industry, academic research centers and wanna-be food celebrities pushing ‘nutrition’ and wellness, it is almost impossible to figure out what’s actually ‘good for you’ (and I mean from a longitudinal, epidemiological, medical-evidentiary manner...). Selected Excerpt: “The message for the public is that healthy older people should not begin taking aspirin. “If you don’t need it, don’t start it,” Dr. McNeil said.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: Old School POLITICAL
content:
Trust. What does that word even mean anymore? Rules. Doesn’t anyone respect them anymore? If you can’t trust Sloan Kettering Cancer Institute to uphold the absolute highest ethical standards in cancer treatment, then what’s a clinician to do? When your “star doctor” lies about taking money from drug companies and breaks the rules regarding disclosure, and you pay him $1.5M a year to be your “face” of cancer care, then what’s that say about the Hospital? Believe me or not, but Healthcare—all the way to its core of using science and evidence in the medical treatment of patient guidelines—is corrupted by big pharma, device manufacturers and for-profit incentives to physicians (and hospitals). It breaks my clinical heart every time I read a story like this. Selected Excerpt: “...One of the world’s top breast cancer doctors failed to disclose millions of dollars in payments from drug and health care companies in recent years, omitting his financial ties from dozens of research articles in prestigious publications... ...He put a positive spin on the results of two Roche-sponsored clinical trials that many others considered disappointments, without disclosing his relationship to the company. Since 2014, he has received more than $3 million from Roche in consulting fees...” 
 
 
 …see more

title: Why ART Is The Only Skill You Really Need
content:
Cough, Cough, Wheeze, Wheeze Clean Air? Who needs it—oh wait... I need it, you need it, all asthmatics need it, all people with lung problems need it. Oh—and so do the young and the old...these people need to breath clean air too. But forgot about it.  It’s not a political thing—our air passages are pure physiology: breath in, breath out. The more junk in the air, the worse it is for our lungs... Regardless of politics, we all need clean air. Selected Excerpt: “As a corporate lawyer, William L. Wehrum worked for the better part of a decade to weaken air pollution rules by fighting the Environmental Protection Agency in court on behalf of chemical manufacturers, refineries, oil drillers and coal-burning power plants. Now, Mr. Wehrum is about to deliver one of the biggest victories yet for his industry clients — this time from inside the Trump administration as the government’s top air pollution official.”

content:

content:

Best Buy is now a health care device sales site—Want a good deal on a TV and a device to monitor your heart while watching The Bachelorette? While I’m a big fan of focusing on our “health” even when we are not in the doctors’ office, I’m not sure I trust all vendors (like Best Buy)! So, if Best Buy is now a health care company (at least in part), who else is getting into the game? Costco? Movie theaters? 7-11? Not sure about you, but I’m not that trusting...for now, I’ll stick to traditional players (doctors, hospitals, clinics) and trusted crossover brands (like Apple or Amazon).

title: Learn How To Start MATHEMATICS
content:
Your Prescription Medicine Might Be Harming More Than Healing—Off-Label Prescrbing. What’s on-label versus off-label use of medicines? It’s when a drug is prescribed for other reasons than what it’s ‘officially’ made for.  “Off-label" means the medication is being used in a manner not specified in the FDA's approved packaging label, or insert. Every prescription drug marketed in the U.S. carries an individual, FDA-approved label. Selected Excerpts: The F.D.A. had data showing that so-called off-label prescribing was widespread. But officials did little to intervene... ...The F.D.A. established a distribution oversight program in 2011 to curb inappropriate use of the dangerous medications, but entrusted enforcement to a group of pharmaceutical companies that make and sell the drugs.. ...pharmaceutical companies “actively subverting” the oversight and safety process... ...the pharmaceutical company pleaded guilty and paid more than $600 million in fines related to misleading marketing... ..drug companies have faced legal action for falsely advertising medications and have  paid over $400 million in fines... “It is not open for debate that the risk of these drugs among patients  is unacceptably high. It’s quite clear-cut,” said Dr. Alexander, at Johns Hopkins University.

title: How To Handle Every SCIENCE Challenge With Ease Using These Tips
content:
Warehousing Our Aging Parents and Grandparents. While the Healthcare industry has been very strong at making hospital admissions safe, we have not been nearly so focused on our nursing home industry. Quality, safety, and-yes even dignity and respect- should be absolute core tenets of performance in nursing homes. Nothing less should be tolerated. And yet just the opposite is true—and has been for some time now.  Frankly we should all be very uncomfortable knowing our senior citizens are receiving sloppy and undignified care in their final years. What does this say about our ‘Family Values?’ Selected Excerpt: “Medicare has lowered its star ratings  in one out of 11 of the nation’s nursing homes — almost 1,400 of them — because they were inadequately staffed with registered nurses... Researchers have repeatedly found lower staffing in for-profit facilities, which make up 70 percent of the industry.”

title: Read This Controversial Article And Find Out More About MATHEMATICS
content:
Yup-it’s True Whether We Like It Or Not: Money in Healthcare Lead to Profits Over Patients Sorry to sound like I’m a “one trick pony,” but I’m not the one making the news.  Studies by scientists at the University of North Carolina, Yale University, the George Washington University and Harvard Medical School, among others, show that when doctors are paid by pharmaceutical companies, they're more likely to prescribe drugs made by those companies. Of course many-if not most-clinicians are ethical and professional which means they have to work even harder to avoid being sucked into poor decision making due to perverse incentives from pharmaceutical companies and productivity/earning requirements within their own medical group....but it’s a struggle. Selected Excerpt: “A CNN analysis of federal data, shows that from August 2013 through December 2017, Bayer paid 11,850 doctors $2.5 million related to Essure for consulting fees and similar services. These payments are legal but very controversial.”

title: Learn Exactly How We Made POLITICS Last Month
content:
You Tell Me Profit Does Not Matter in Healthcare... This article could have been an earnings report for car sales (except car sales are not so strong), about Home starts (except Home starts are not so strong), about pharmaceutical companies (that’s possible but even a stretch for them)... I’m no ‘country bumpkin’ (or anti-capitalist) so I realize Americans are generally OK with Healthcare being a for-profit industry... Yet..it still makes me horribly uncomfortable to read the “good news” that HCA made so much money off of other people’s misfortunes of illness. Wouldn’t it be a better society if we could develop a business model where hospitals and doctors made more money by keeping us healthy and out of hospitals!  Selected Excerpt: “For-profit chain HCA Healthcare's net income jumped 25% during the second quarter of 2018... The company's adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization increased 6.6% in the quarter to $2.2 billion...” 
 
 
 …see more

title: The Ultimate Guide To PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
Talk about Service Recovery! What we all can learn from this flight crew. Flying on Southwest to Seattle but got grounded before we could take off. The Captain—a woman(!) who is taking the photo—offered to let people sit in the cockpit with the First Officer, while we were waiting to be cleared for takeoff.  What a treat. It made everyone on the plane feel happier about the delay because of the opportunity to do something special-get a picture inside the cockpit. Well done! What a great way to turn-around a disappointing situation. Kudos. 
 
 
 …see more

title: Best Make HR MANAGEMENT You Will Read This Year (in 2015)
content:
Vindicated! Paleo...Shmaleo. Here’s to Bread! For years I’ve expressed my utter disregard for those friends of mine who claim they believe in the ‘paleo diet’ as an actual (historically accurate) food diet.  I’ve always said it’s a fad diet and that people who choose to be on this diet should just admit to it. And like all fads, it’s made-up to promote some sort of mindset or ‘evolved’ eating approach. Which is why a friend of mine (who has no allergies or sensitivity to any food products) won’t eat any kind of bread, grain, legumes, dairy, sugar or any number of other things. (Meanwhile coconut and cow are fine...) I’ve tried explaining to this friend that none of the foods she is eating today were even around 10,000 years ago and not to mention that the average lifespan back then was 45, so that I’m not really sure why we are eager to reproduce that diet. Anyway, as a lover of bread, I was tickled pink to read this article about how bread is in fact ‘paleo.’  Does that mean all those paleo books need to be re-written??? Selected Excerpt: “As a final note, this study reminds us, yet again, that the so-called Paleo Diet isn’t an actual thing, or at the very least, not a coherent, unified diet that existed across multiple populations of paleolithic peoples.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: The Truth Is You Are Not The Only Person Concerned About POLITICS
content:
Being Human Hurts Patients. Being tired causes errors...it’s true whether you are a truck driver or a doctor. Medical errors are things like getting the wrong medication, being prescribed the wrong test, being diagnosed with the wrong problem. And it’s a huge problem as it is the 3rd leading cause of death. Medical errors happen for many, many reasons including doctors and nurses being tired, distracted, forgetful or simply out-of-date with best practices.  Only one of the  issues with medical errors is burn out. Lets face it, the bigger problem is that people are faulty instruments when it comes to high reliability, consistency and memory. That’s why I’m hopeful about technology-assisting advancements such as ‘smart’ (meaning automated) order sets, Smart radiological readings for x-rays, and ‘early warning’ technologies that diagnose medical conditions before they’ve advanced, just to name a few. The time is coming when the scope of what doctors do is narrower and more augmented by advanced capabilities. We should embrace this because honestly, right now, Healthcare is a very dangerous place for patients. Selected Excerpt: “There is growing evidence that physician burnout may be responsible for up to 200,000 deaths in US hospitals every year.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: Interesting Facts I Bet You Never Knew About ART
content:
I Am Not Different Than You Who doesn’t know about the boys who were trapped in the cave? It’s a funny thing—this is a story that opened the Evening News shows, and has been part of Americans daily talk news over the last two weeks. We’ve cheered for them, prayed for them, rooted for them. We gravitate towards stories that are suspenseful and hopeful—in our collective hearts we want everyone to ‘win,’ especially when it comes to the underdog, like these young boys appeared to be. (Who wouldn’t be an underdog trapped in a cave, two miles from freedom?) During their battle for survival, we learned that those boys are like our young ones: Sweet, resilient and hopeful. It reminds us that the human spirit to love others and our capacity to care about each other is something we all have in common regardless of where we live, the country we call home or the color of our skin. It’s an essential reminder for our times. Selected Excerpt: “What we want to say: The kids say don't worry. We are all strong. When they come out they want to eat many things.  When they come out they want to go back home immediately. Teacher, don't give us lots of homework!" 
 
 
 …see more

title: How To Handle Every PAINTING Challenge With Ease Using These Tips
content:
Which is better?  Paying $18.99 or $7.40 for an identical (in every way) medicine? If you had the choice of buying one banana and paying either $1.00 or $4.00, I’d guess you’d (definitely) decide to pay $1.00... especially when you know $4.00 is overpriced for that banana. We think:‘Why pay more for an identical ‘thing’ when choice is available?’ So it should come as no surprise that Amazon is selling medicines at a lower—and I’d argue a more rational—price...and guess what? Consumers are not silly—we buy the lower priced, identical item when options exist. This is not ‘rocket science...’ Want to be competitive? Provide easy value for consumers and we will become your best paying friends. Let this be a warning shot to conventional businesses: understand this new consumer market...or perish. Selected Excerpt: “84% of Walgreens’ and 72% of CVS’ house-brand drugs were more expensive than the (Amazon’s) Basic Care line (of pharmaceuticals).” 
 
 
 …see more

title: Open The Gates For OPERATING SYSTEM By Using These Simple Tips
content:
Who Owns Health Care? Doctors? The Government? Hospitals? Big Health Systems? Insurance Companies? Employers? Amazon? You—The Patient? Answer: None of the above. According to Modern Healthcare... Regardless of who ‘should’ own Healthcare (and trust me, it won’t be patients), the group that’s moving into the ‘top spot’ is Private Equity firms (PE). They are buying as much of Healthcare as possible ( doctor groups, hospitals, lab services...) Huh? Never heard of PE?  Private equity typically refers to investment funds organized as limited partnerships that are not publicly traded and whose investors are typically large institutional investors, or wealthy individuals. And you thought Healthcare was already complex (and impersonal) before... Selected Excerpt: “We have to decide whether the goal of a healthcare system is to increase profits, because private equity firms are selecting those parts of healthcare where they can see a profit because their goal is to make profit,” AMA President Dr. Barbara McAneny said. “The consolidation of various parts of the healthcare industry has been shown to increase prices and decrease choice, and if you’re lucky, quality stays about the same.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: The Lazy Way To MATHEMATICS
content:
Healthcare’s New Trifecta: expertise, humility and long range thinking... This is both ‘old’ and ‘new’ wisdom — and I’m glad to see these three values brought back to our central tenants of Healthcare. All of us who deliver care to patients can adopt these values within  our daily practice and within our organization immediately. And I believe if we did adopt this trifecta, we’d become our better selves. Selected Excerpt : "We said at the outset that the degree of difficulty is high and success is going to require an expert's knowledge, a beginner's mind and a long-term orientation," Jeff Bezos, founder and CEO of Amazon, said in a statement.” 
 
 
 …see more

title: Why My FASHION DESIGN Is Better Than Yours
content:
Women-to-Women: Life (and Career) Advice. My mom recently passed and I found a card from her which, honestly, I don't recall receiving...but reading it again, I think it is full of wisdom. Here it is: If I were your age again, I'd spend a lot less time examining what's wrong about me, and a lot more time enjoying what's right about me. Because you know what? You're already perfect enough. So, live life on your own terms. Be who you are and love what you love. Reserve the right to be wrong. If things take an occasional turn you hadn't planned on, don't be tempted to call it a mistake. Just call it life and tuck the experience in your back pocket for safe keeping. Pretty soon you can take it out, share it with someone else, and call it wisdom. I'm not kidding. That's how it works. So, hey--enjoy the life you're in. Be as happy as you can. And feel how deeply and completely you are loved....

It's Time To Look At Suicide Squarely In The Eye Suicide is all around us.  While all other causes of death are declining, suicide is rising. I bet you know someone who has had issues with serious depression, anxiety, schizophrenia or bipolar. Or has taken their own life. My first experience with it was in high school when my good friend started to tell me things like ‘Paul McCartney stole my music. He took my songs from the freezer.’ (She was a budding musician). And one day she came to my house and started saying things like this around my dad, who was a doctor. After she left, he said, ‘You know Julie, your friend has schizophrenia.’ I had no idea even what the word meant. Years later one of my family members took her own life and mental illness became real. Real, tragic and deeply personal. It is time to address this growing cause of death in our society. Speak Up. Speak Out. Selected Excerpt: Increasingly, suicide is being viewed not only as a mental health problem but a public health one. Nearly 45,000 suicides occurred in the United States in 2016 — more than twice the number of homicides — making it the 10th-leading cause of death. Among people ages 15 to 34, suicide is the second-leading cause of death.

Culture Eats Consumerism for Lunch   While ‘Consumerism’ is all the range in healthcare, moving beyond the slogans to the real-world of strategy development and implementation—and measurement—is still in its infancy. Why? Even though many technologies are mature enough to demonstrate real value, getting people within organizations to change from their old ways is hard. The biggest challenges to innovation is not the technical aspect of intraoperability or, realizing a return on investment, but rather on the necessary adoption, implementation and change management that goes hand-in-glove with innovation.   I do a lot of change management so I consider myself to be an “Organizational Culturalist.” As an Organizational Culturalist, I function like a medical anthropologist helping  organizations develop and implement technology adoption roadmaps.   If ‘culture’ is the biggest barrier, then it’s time to think of culture like anthropologists rather than technologists.   Selected Excerpt:    "Everybody thinks the only way you can innovate is to have some technological advance," he said. "We're finding a lot of innovations can occur without the use of technology but with changing the team and changing the thinking."

New Rules include: Needing to know what’s wrong with you before you get to the ER; Getting billed for the whole Cost of Care if your problem is not serious. I fully realize that many ER visits are for basic health care needs (in part because our primary care system is broken and many people do not have regular doctors) BUT, this practice by insurers of using ‘hindsight diagnosis’ is unethical and well, cruel. title: 5 Things To Do Immediately About BANKING

Health= Body + Mind... Not Just The Body. The Bio-Medical Model Of Healthcare focuses largely on the germ theory as the dominant diagnoses and treatment approach: Got an infection? We’ve got an antibiotic! Got a laceration? We’ve got sutures. All great stuff for the body. But the mind requires a different sort of medical model—one that includes enough resources (and humanity) to have time to evaluate, diagnosis and treat.  And unlike physical ailments that can be treated with sutures or antibiotics, these patients need a holistic approach which often includes stable housing, good counseling and a network of support. We continue to separate out the Body from the Mind at our own, collective expense... Selected Excerpt: “Nationwide, hospitals are struggling to provide services to people with psychiatric emergencies. Between 2006 and 2013, ER visits increased by more than 50 percent for psychoses and bipolar disorders and depression, anxiety and stress reactions according to the Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project. title: GRAPHIC: What A Mistake!
content:
Healthcare. It should be more like Vegas--Always Open--But It Is Not. Is healthcare 'always open?' You might think it is, but it is not. In fact, it operates much more like a banker's hours than you'd think...or want! Did you know that in the hospital, many services end at 5pm? Like the team that insert special IVs for patients that cannot tolerate regular IVs? Or that social services closes? Or that discharge planners leave at 5pm too?  And if you were ready to be discharged from the hospital on Friday but arrangements for your rehab center (whether physical rehab or behavioral health rehab) hadn't been finalized yet, then most likely you have to spend another two--or three--days in the hospital until arrangements can be made... Talk about a waste of money and, talk about the increased opportunities to 'catch something' like a hospital-acquired infection. Hospitals and healthcare organizations still operate on a model of 9am-5pm, yet patient care is a continuous experience, requiring an entirely different operating model. One that is Always Open.

title: 3 MATHEMATICS Secrets You Never Knew
content:
Thinking of Starting--or Re-Starting Working Out?  It's Springtime and which means its time to think about bicycling, upcoming trips to our beautiful National Parks, summer picnics. Which means feeling physically fit, 'light' and well, happy. I've started, stopped and re-started working-out too many times to count over the 40 years I've been exercising. Here's what I've learned: 1. Re-Set To Zero: Know you will start, stop and need to re-start exercising many, many times. I think of this as 'resetting to zero.'  2. Get into the Work-Out Mindset: Be kind to yourself and set winning 'goals' at the beginning of your 'work-out season.'  3. Feel Successful Each Time You Work-Out: It’s about the process of ‘doing’ so applaud yourself for ‘doing’ rather than judging ‘how much or how little’ you did. 4. Figure Out ‘Why’ You Want To Exercise: This becomes important to staying fit. 5. Develop a Personal Matra: By coming up with a ‘saying’ that you can repeat to yourself when you are working-out, that helps a lot. When I used to train for marathons, I would repeat to myself ‘The Mind Gives Out Before The Body.’  This is a good, comprehensive article on tips, ideas, strategies to help everyone start—or continue along their healthcare journey.

title: 3 Ways To Have (A) More Appealing MUSIC
content:
What trauma doctors and nurses know ...the issue is NOT guns, but rather it’s the type of gun that will kill you. Just like how all viruses do not pack the same “killing punch,” it’s the same for guns. Years ago I worked in an inner-city trauma center and saw gun shot victims every shift. And you know what? Most lived. But that was before there were many high velocity weapons used in the streets. Just like viruses differ in their ability to inflict morbidity so does the “strain” or type of gun. Selected Excerpt from The Atlantic: “Routine handgun injuries leave entry and exit wounds and linear tracks through the victim’s body that are roughly the size of the bullet. If the bullet does not directly hit something crucial like the heart or the aorta, and the victim does not bleed to death before being transported to our care at the trauma center, chances are that we can save him. The bullets fired by an AR-15 are different: They travel at a higher velocity and are far more lethal than routine bullets fired from a handgun. The damage they cause is a function of the energy they impart as they pass through the body. A typical AR-15 bullet leaves the barrel traveling almost three times faster than—and imparting more than three times the energy of—a typical 9mm bullet from a handgun.”

We have a pandemic of gun violence and like all pandemics, we prepare for them, we isolate the infectious agent, we vaccinate when possible, we treat or cut-out the disease. Doing nothing—taking zero action—is no long a legitimate stance. Do No Harm does not mean Do Nothing. This is NOT a political message. This is a public health warning.  I am a Healthcare Professional calling all other Healthcare Professionals to take a stance and write letters, push local polices to stamp out this virus of gun violence. Just like we do with ebola, bird flu, or Influenza, we take action. Pestering, Nudging or Noodging—it all seems to work. My grandmother used to pester me to wear a sweater when it's cold outside; to save my appetite for dinner or to look both ways when crossing the street . So I giggled at reading someone won a Noble Prize for recognizing what my grandmother—and probably yours have been doing forever —nudging or noodging or pestering people helps them to make the smart choice. Perhaps the solution for improving health care safety and quality is to hire all our grandparents and embed them in our hospitals, clinics and nursing homes! I'm 1000% sure they will make sure providers wash their hands and patients take their medications ! Selected Excerpt : “Nudging – a term coined by newly honored Nobel Prize laureate and economist Richard H. Thaler – is based on the idea that people don’t always make rational choices based on their own best interest. Rather, people are influenced by their emotions and personal needs, resulting in choices that may not lead to the best outcome. Thaler suggests that people can be “nudged” in the right direction by simple processes, and these nudges can help people take actions that benefit them. “

I'm intrigued by ‘the promise of’ new technology, biotech science and emerging products within the healthcare space... However The promise of-and delivery of-basic, error-free, non-sexy primary care  is still at a “C” grade. Why? Because there is still not a solution for enabling healthcare providers to see patients “as a whole person” over long periods of time.  I'd like to issue a separate ‘moon shot’ challenge to all those at the conference : Create a unified patient “narrative platform “ that allows  providers across Care settings to have patient specific information, and which allows for frictionless communication and knowledge exchange....(and it's not the EHR) Only after the above is completed can we then look to behavior change and social determinants, gene splicing etc, If we are truly interested in moving entire populations towards better health . Selected Excerpt : “While the biggest commercial opportunities in health care have traditionally come from providing treatment and developing new medicines, can we create new business models that focus on wellness and helping people to thrive? Can the health care industry tackle the vexing issues of behavior change and environmental factors that we know are the biggest determinants of health? “

My father spent his entire physician career at KP and I've worked and consulted to KP. Yet I'm not really seeing or experiencing anything within the system which reflects your above view. So I really am interested in knowing more...  I live here in Oakland and would like to suggest that you invite me to meet you at your office to discuss my experiences and views of Healthcare in 2018! Is it possible the down sides are not clear or are we humans only "wired" to deal with the "here and now..." come what may? Just as we are bad with dieting or exercise perhaps the same is true when it comes time to take our meds. Selected Excerpt: "A thorough review published in The New England Journal of Medicine about a decade ago estimated that up to two-thirds of medication-related hospital admissions in the United States were because of noncompliance, at a cost of about $100 billion a year. I say sunlight --transparency and accountability ..and having each others' back as we take action to rid this nasty germ. title: Fear? Not If You Use FASHION DESIGN The Right Way!
content:
Do we care? Do we care that health insurance coverage is dropping ?  Anyone on LinkedIn going without insurance?   My guess is most people reading this have coverage and don't worry about falling off their bike, or a nail through the foot, or a fever in your child at night, or routine medical checkups, or cholesterol levels, or pneumonia or.... BECAUSE you've got insurance . But for those who go "bare," every one of those things I mentioned are fears you harbor or desires you can't fulfill --regular medical exam--get ready to pay $300-1,000.00 bucks. Sick child? Don't even think about it because you'll need to sell your house if they need hospitalization. Those of us with coverage should care for no other reason that WE pay the bills for all those who go without ... not to mention it's a decent and civil thing to provide our fellow Americans. Selected Excerpt : "Experts expect the cuts and confusion over whether the law is being repealed will further depress enrollment - which could cause the rate of people without insurance to rise further."

title: How To Earn $398/Day Using GST
content:
For many years I worked in a high-volume, urban ED. I treated people--who became patients--for everything you could imagine: a fork stuck in an eyeball causing an ocular rupture, a nose bleed that put a person into volume shock because of how much blood was lost, abdominal pain that turned out to be an ectopic pregnancy, an achy leg which turned out to be a fractured femur...and on and on and on. Sure, I also saw people seek 'emergency care' for heartburn, lice, sexually transmitted diseases, skin lesions, mild sunburns and on and on and on..... But how on earth can we expect the 'lay public' to know when to seek emergency treatment and when not to?  Honestly--think about this..many people do not have primary care doctors so they come to the ED...many people do not want to wait weeks for an appointment to see a doctor so they come to the ED...many people don't know if they are truly sick or not truly sick...so they come to us. Until there is more access to care in communities where people live, then we will always have people coming to the ED--whether they should or not...and we need to cover the costs.

That said one comment stuck out at me not only for what they said but who said it...  Below is an excerpted comment from a LinkedIn member to the main post. This fellow is an official at The Joint Commission ...and I called it out  because it is kinda, well, radical! Especially coming from someone who represents hospitals! "I agree with Warner's comments. Additionally, healthcare entities will need to become engaged with communities in a more effective manner to promote changes in behaviors, community priorities, and resource allocation. Want to really know if your hospital is safe? Ask the doctors and nurses--privately and "off the record"--and you might get the truth. One key question to ask them:'Would you go here for your surgery ?' Selected excerpt : "The Wall Street Journal dug into Joint Commission inspection reports from 2014 through 2016. In 2014, about 350 hospitals with Joint Commission accreditation were in violation of Medicare requirements that year, and about a third of those facilities went on to have additional violations in 2014, 2015 and 2016. About 80% of U.S. hospitals are accredited by the commission."

title: PAINTING Smackdown!
content:
Here I am again cheerleading for an "Outsider" to come to Healthcare's aide!  I've been a consistent advocate for new entrants with bold ideas driven by creative, optimistic leaders, to provide CPR!  Like Apple and Amazon. My belief is that  "The Healthcare Institutional Mindset"  (including hospitals, nursing facilities and delivering systems) is one which is fundamentally risk-adverse, backwards-thinking and myopic.  Within these organizations you will not find "skunk works" or "innovation labs" or "stealthy teams" working on new approaches to patient care. In healthcare we are designed (and hire) for being slow, cautious and repetitious ... even if doing the same thing over and over leads to the same mediocre and disappointing results. Again I say "Apple, come find me! I'm just up the road and am here to help improve care delivery for patients !" Selected excerpt: "The iPhone, which turned 10 this summer, already aggregates some health data in apps. But most of that is patient-generated. If the company can add information from doctors offices and clinics—test results, visit summaries, medication lists—the iPhone could become an important healthcare tool in achieving interoperability, which has for so long frustrated the industry."

title: 5 Things To Do Immediately About BUSINESS
content:
I'm mixed about this piece: on one hand I say "Hat's Off" to anyone  or any formalized group of people trying to 'think about making dying better.'  For whatever the reasons, we do not like talking about The Dying Process....and yet we all go through some form of death--and die. On the other hand, we know not all death can be planned-having worked in a busy ER, I saw people die daily even though their plan for the day was to get to work, or drive to school, or go hang out with friends...what about this "death and dying process?" And, once you "package and brand"  (or should I say "re-brand") The Dying Process, how will you make sure all this new wisdom moves out of the fancy world of Silicon Vally and into  the hands of every day people? I wish you well AND I hope you routinely share--for free--all the tools and knowledge you are acquiring... because as you say, this affects us all and as such, any "solution " should be viewed as a public good.

Our Wild Lands Make America Great Right Now--So Protect Them Now. An excerpt from the attached article: "After weeks of speculation, Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke finally told President Trump which protected public lands he wants to open up to mining, logging, and drilling. But he won’t tell us. In a shock move that no one in the environmental or fossil-fuel sectors expected, Zinke declined to make his report public, releasing only a vague, two-page summary and leaving everyone guessing which lands, exactly, he wants to hand over ."

Me? I love it and giggle at the thought of how many healthcare providers and hospital systems will be annoyed because 'these companies are trying to practice medicine.' And, incidentally might migrate patients away from them.... But that's NOT why I love it--I love this because healthcare insiders won't change and the change must come from outsiders...and Lord knows, we need change--if it's an improvement ... because we all know that not all change is an improvement , but all improvement requires change!

I'm a fan of disrupting ideas and being from Silicon Valley, and being a healthcare "implementationist," and change management expert, I hear from emerging biotech firms who want "a real world" view of their product or service or technology. So I will give the same advice to Amazon as  I give to the companies I speak to which is this: building a new--and better--technology or service is NOT enough to cause disruption. (Who doesn't feel they have built a better mousetrap ?) What successful organizations do is realize that  new "things" or ideas need to be adopted... which requires dealing with the age-old (and not super sexy) change management...working with and through people and politics.  Trust me Amazon: people make or break the best of ideas--especially in complex organizations like clinical healthcare settings.  So remember this: Culture Eats Strategy For Lunch... unless you focus on the people-side of change management!

What's great about this news is raising awareness (yet again) that simple, non-expensive tools can do so much good--if used! And that's the rub... making sure such checklists and protocols are routinely used by everyone and not allowing "more senior" doctors or nurses to ignore them. As a huge animal rights person,  II think the "no-kill" shelters do a great job and would rather see an unwanted dog or cat go there than abandoned in the street.... title: The Biggest Lie In BANKING

I hope Amazon does take over healthcare... personally, I like on-time delivery and friendly customer service and being asked whether I was satisfied with the service I received. And sure, I know (I know!), healthcare is not like package delivery. But let's face it-many aspects of care delivery is about delivering the correct good or service to the right person/patient, at the right time. It is also about caring and doing the right thing. And while individual healthcare providers do the right thing all the time, the collective effort of the health care enterprise routinely fails  to deliver the right service at the right time to the right person in a customer-service orientation . So Hats Off to Amazon and any other "big dog" who wants to completely re-do a broken industry . And Amazon--if you are reading this, please call me because I want to help realize a vision of customer -oriented, high value health care!

It seems clear from your post that your three year old son has a medical condition requiring him to learn anew how to safely swallow food... basic human need--to safely eat and drink without concern of choking ... and yet the Occupational Therapy services and "associated tools (e.g., food)" were not included as a covered benefit with your insurance.  Let me ask--how was your 3 year old son supposed to get better without the help of  trained health care professionals ? What bothers me in so many of these healthcare posts is an undying sense of pettiness, and disregard for people's medical problems... wether that disregard is coming from insurance providers or the public.  Healthcare should be held above  all other industries to be caring, loving and selfless. Which I know we all want to experience when our time comes to deal with doctors , nurses and insurers.

Too often when you call doctors /nurses with a problem, they offer to see you in their office or tell you to go to the ER... We need to move away from jargon and say what we mean and do what we say.  Otherwise we will never be held accountable for improving care for those we love!

content:
A collection of the TOP A.I. studies published this week. Links in the comments!    A.I. contributing to longevity medicine: Finally it's not only about medications related to ageing but also about how A.I. can help bring healthcare to patients better.    An imaginative scenario about a critical care physician at a medium-sized urban hospital who has to implement an A.I. coming from a local start-up that claims to automatically interpret chest X-rays.    While treating breast cancer, physicians use a quick, inexpensive tumor-tissue stain test to diagnose the illness and a slower, more costly one to determine treatment. A new study just presented a neural network that could help. The stain in the test for treatment highlights a key visual clue to the choice of therapy that’s otherwise invisible to human pathologists. Researchers built it to detect that clue in the diagnostic test.    The question of who should get access to COVID-19 vaccines first has varied from state to state in the US too, with some governments prioritizing those with high-risk conditions and others lowering the age of eligibility. Sanford Health is using a machine learning model to identify which individuals are at greatest risk of having severe COVID-19 outcomes.

title: Don't Fall For This PAINTING Scam
content:
Are you familiar with the Gary rule? As many are still mixing up ‘health IT’ and ‘digital health’, I published an editorial in the Journal of Clinical and Translational Research and introduced the Gary rule to help clear up this misconception.  Here’s how it goes: If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue.  If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health.  #study   #tmfi   #research   #themedicalfuturistinstitute   #garyrule   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

title: Want To Step Up Your OPERATING SYSTEM? You Need To Read This First
content:
Mount Sinai researchers just released a study indicating that consumer wearable devices can help flag new cases of COVID-19 prior to molecular diagnosis.  They analyzed Mount Sinai Health System workers with an Apple Watch and a custom study app and found significant differences in a heart rate variability (HRV) metric during the seven days before a PCR COVID-19 diagnosis and the seven days after. While it could also indicate that other heart rate trackers are capable of the same feat, the study only had 297 participants so we cannot draw that conclusion yet. Yet it shows promise how wearable digital health devices could contribute to the early diagnosis of COVID. #applewatch   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy

title: DRAWING Is Essential For Your Success. Read This To Find Out Why
content:
I've done 50 keynotes in the last 6 months so I’m reflecting a bit on what keynotes will be like in the new “never normal”. My take so far: Virtual keynotes don’t work at large expos with 1,000s of people and exhibitors. At such events, we’d like to immerse ourselves in a different world. We’d like to see and experience the venue, thus bringing such events to a single screen (with break-out rooms or not) is a complete waste. Whereas it’s not worth organizing events in the physical space with 150 attendees or less. I believe these won’t be coming back and I’d strongly agree there’s no need.  I can’t wait to hop on a plane for large-scale events all over the world, but I’ll be happy to continue giving smaller keynotes from the comfort and professionality of my new studio: it’s cozier, it creates a more honest environment and I even get better questions! What’s your take about events in the new never normal?  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

title: At Last, The Secret To PROGRAMMING Is Revealed
content:
If you’d like to travel by air, be aware of these developments. Depending on where you live, you might get a paper certificate that you got the vaccine or maybe this gets inserted into your digital records. But you have to prove it when you want to board a plane. So companies started to work on digital vaccine passports worldwide. However, as it seems, there won't be a single solution. We’ll all have to become experts on which app to use at which airport and airline. Similar to how we used to check the different criteria for baggage allowance. Welcome to the post-COVID globalized world.  I’ve been invited to a few medical events to attend in person in the summer of 2021. I guess (hope!) there’ll be consensus by then about what apps I should use to be able to travel (if I’ll have received the vaccine).  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

Men’s health has a number of challenges, from hard to access services to embarrassing conditions that many rather not talk about.   I’ve interviewed  Sam Shah , Chief Medical Strategy Officer of  Numan , who is taking a different approach by taking some of the stigma out of conditions  – such as erectile dysfunction. Sam also used to be the Director of Digital Development at NHS in England.   “Gender-based health inequalities are widening – but not how you’d think. Men are less likely to seek healthcare compared to women, and by helping men engage with our service, we can help solve some immediate problems. But more importantly, we help to diagnose other underlying conditions such as diabetes or testosterone deficiency.”   To read the complete interview with Sam, join our Patreon community:  https://lnkd.in/gJet4TS     #patreon   #digitalhealthcommunity   #interview   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

title: Ho To (Do) CRAFT Without Leaving Your Office(House).

This is a completely wrong assumption, as usual.  The article argues that a large percent of the work psychologists do can get simply replaced by A.I.  Assessment of a client’s strengths and difficulties and designing interventions are simply made by algorithms and the authors assume that psychologists are just there to share the results of the machine. Such narratives are not only false but even dangerous. If healthcare professionals (wrongly) think that advanced technology is here to replace them, they will reject those even more. While in fact, such technologies will support what professionals do and only replace the repetitive components of their job. We analyzed this and the impact of automation on 20 other specialties here.  https://lnkd.in/gbaWjBm #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

As chronic patients will be cared for at home or wherever they are, critical care patients will require a larger percentage of hospital space in the future. What will the patient of the future be like, what contact will they have with their doctors and most importantly how can you create products that fit these future scenarios? Delivering medicine by drones is not the future. It’s our living reality, and  Zipline  is bringing the technology into the vaccination efforts. We wrote extensively about Zipline's efforts in using drones to deliver medical supplies in Africa. It’s great to see them joining the vaccine fight too. “More than 100 million people in America — in both rural and urban areas — live in pharmacy deserts and lack adequate access to the medicine they need to stay healthy,” Zipline co-founder and CEO Keller Rinaudo told CNBC. “Building this 21st century infrastructure will not only create more high tech jobs in rural America, and create more green, zero emissions logistics options, but it could revolutionize the way millions get their care delivered.” #zipline   #vaccination   #drones   #ai   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

title: 2 Ways You Can Use GST To Become Irresistible To Customers
content:
*Is Printing Out Medical Equipment Cheaper Than Manufacturing?* Revolutionary technologies bring a healthier future. In my book, “My Health Upgraded”, I’m sharing the most exciting questions (and providing answers) about the future of medicine. In the upcoming month, I’ll share with you one question from my book each week and provide a short (but sweet) answer. Question 4: Is Printing Out Medical Equipment Cheaper Than Manufacturing?  In short: YES. And not only that, it’s much more customizable. 3D printing works by additive manufacturing, which means that a digital model is created of the object we want to print out, and the machine adds each layer one at a time. That way, a personalized, 3D printed cast could get ready in 2 minutes and would cost around $50.  Wealthy companies will turn to 3D printing because of its potential for total customization. Companies in poorer regions will turn to it because it makes prototypes inexpensively.  Grab your paperback to become more conscious about your health as a patient from the future! http://amzn.to/1LRAp3t #myhealthupgraded   #3dprinting   #3dprinter   #3dprinted   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #technology

title: How I Improved My MUSIC In One Day
content:
Attention. Time. Empathy: 3 essential things e-patients expect from healthcare and medical professionals. These are also the fundamental values of healthcare, which seem to stay with us infinitely. Our interviews have shown that cooperation between technology and healthcare is not enough on its own: the most decisive factor is the return of the human touch and reciprocal communication.  All of these suggest that technology is an important ally in the ‘renaissance of medicine’ that starts to treat patients as it should have always had. Our vision is to be able to provide this for patients in the future, while being surrounded with cutting edge, invisible technology.  This publication backs up our vision, feel free to read our research and findings!  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

‘Futurologist’ and “Self-defined geek”: just some of the titles I get announced with at several events. When I give a keynote or take part in a discussion as a speaker, the hosts are very careful to use the word “Futurist”. I’m not sure why, as it’s a profession and also a scientific field (futuristic studies). So here you go: I started using this visual more and more because it seems to explain my profession much better: We’re exploring the future just as archeologists explore the past.  For archeologists, it’s fossils, dinosaurs, relics and historical data that help create visions about what might have happened (in short), whereas for futurists it's trends, data, scenarios and foresight that helps depict visions about the future (also in short). title: Why PHOTOGRAPHY Is The Only Skill You Really Need
content:
3D bioprinting has recently seen some setbacks, especially due to Organovo's announcement about changing the company's course.  But this is something to provide hope again. A novel type of ink enables bioengineers to print bone-like material at room temperature with living cells. It's a big feat considering the fact that bone is a mixture of living and inorganic compounds in a highly structured mineral matrix. The team is trying to print larger samples and has begun small animal tests to see if a print can repair a large wound. In the US, the FDA has already signaled that 3D-printed bone technologies are eligible for FDA clearance. I’ve explored what 3D bioprinting can do today and what it promises for tomorrow in various parts of my e-books on The Medical Futurist. title: How To Teach POLITICS Better Than Anyone Else
content:
Bias in A.I. might be the biggest challenge ahead in making A.I.-based technology truly useful for medical purposes.  But there’s a new paper in Nature Medicine that proposes to train algorithms to become better at predicting patient outcomes rather than to match the performance of their human counterparts. The paper presents this theory through a real-life example. Decades ago, a system was developed on white, British patients to determine their level of knee pain based on certain radiographic features of their X-ray.  This system systematically scores black patients far below the severity of pain that they self-report. When they trained a deep-learning model to predict the patient’s self-reported pain level from their knee X-ray without using data from the old system, they found that the model was much more accurate, especially for black patients, thereby reducing the racial disparity. Learn more about A.I. in healthcare to be able to understand, anticipate and control it. I knew of this issue and similar biases in A.I., also highlighted in The Medical Futurist e-book ‘A Guide to Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare’. I’m really glad Nicole Mpofu reached out to me and raised my attention to how they’re trying to tackle this issue  Codethink . Their team is working on designing a fully open-source research device for experimenting with shining light into skin and detecting the light that reflects, gets absorbed and passes through. The kind of technology that is widely deployed for measuring heart rates. Have you heard of any similar issues and solutions? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy

Two thoughts on the COVID immunity passports: Israel is by far leading the vaccination race with more than 20% of their population already vaccinated. Issuing an immunity passport is a smart act, and let’s face it: a must have. Why not go digital though? The “green booklets” issued by the Ministry of Health are analog paper-based documents people have to carry around. title: Master (Your) GST in 5 Minutes A Day
content:
The  FDA ’s new A.I. action plan just got published. Here are the main points: 1. Tailored Regulatory Framework My take: As the draft guidance about this with details will come out this year, I hope adaptive algorithms will be covered. 2. Good Machine Learning Practice My take: The FDA wants to harmonize such practices across a range of international organizations. I'm not sure it’s possible, since their detailed plan is still not ready. 3. Patient-Centered Approach My take: I would’ve expected the digital health arm of the FDA to appoint a patient engagement advisory board, as promoting a patient centric approach without actively involving patients sounds like a risky business. 4. Regulatory Science Methods Related to Algorithm Bias & Robustness My take: This is why we expected that the FDA would take over our open access database of A.I.-based medical devices that we published in Nature Publishing Group's npj Digital Medicine paper. However, they confirmed to me that they won’t. 5. Real-World Performance  My take: The FDA should promote the importance of prospective studies when it comes to analyzing algorithms' performance in medical tasks.

title: What Can Instagramm Teach You About POLITICS
content:
I’ve read and enjoyed these 3 books over the holidays: - Life 3.0 by  Max Tegmark  - The author is the founder of the Future of Life Institute, of which I’m a great fan. In life 1.0, both our hardware and software evolved; in life 2.0. we design the software, but not yet the hardware. In life 3.0 we design both the hardware and the software.  What implications does this have on our world? - Math of Life and Death by Kit Yates - It describes some interesting scenarios through the language of mathematics.  However, I missed the HOW when it comes to implementing its conclusions into my everyday life. - Greenlights by Matthey McConaughey - Some great principles on how he’s been searching for greenlights all his life: those signs that help him take the right turn or jump forward. I personally find them in data. We could all be looking for greenlights. It’s a great book to help us understand how. #themedicalfuturist   #artificialintelligence   #sciene   #future   #technology   #book   #reading   #read

title: Everything You Wanted to Know About BANKING and Were Too Embarrassed to Ask
content:
Let me share with you a personal story with the  FDA . Our online database with  The Medical Futurist Institute  on artificial intelligence-based FDA-approved medical devices and algorithms was published and peer-reviewed on Nature’s digital health journal, npj Digital Medicine. I’ve been trying to get it accepted by the FDA, offering it to them for free. After numerous emails and using my best connections, I managed to pitch this to the FDA Digital Health Division.  Their answer was that they’re not interested in the database, but are happy to connect me with an A.I consortium.  My only question remains: if they don’t want our Nature-published, peer-reviewed database, where is THEIR database on A.I.-based, FDA approved medical technologies? title: If You Do Not (Do)PHOTOGRAPHY Now, You Will Hate Yourself Later
content:
BREAKING NEWS:  Haven  is shutting down. The masterplan of the big three,  Amazon , Warren Buffett's  Berkshire Hathaway  and  J.P. Morgan  Chase, got crashed as Haven was just announced to end its operations at the end of February. What it means for us in digital health: * Big money alone cannot break into the healthcare business as they simply lack the expertise, experience and knowledge about the regulatory environment (among other things). What it doesn't mean for us: * That tech companies will still play a major role in the future of care with the products they can bring to the table (instead of creating a different form of healthcare like Haven attempted). Just look at Amazon's recent efforts with providing remote care for their employees in Seattle, owning online pharmacy PillPack, and launching plans to ship prescriptions to Prime members. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

title: Why Most People Will Never Be Great At PAINTING
content:
Believe me, I’m waiting for COVID-19 to end as much as you.  However, in order to get back to our lives, we must vaccinate at least 60% of the world. There’s no other way. I find the example of Israel outstanding, where 12% of the population got vaccinated within 2 weeks. They’re defrosting the vaccines in 6 hour blocks with a vaccination plan. If any vaccine gets left behind because of a no-show, a volunteer can go and get that shot, thus minimizing wasted vaccines.  If I worked at a hospital, I’d run to grab my vaccine TODAY. We’ll continue to live with COVID for a very long time if we don’t do so. #getyourvaccine   #getvaccinated   #vaccineswork   #stopmisinformation   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

title: Who Else Wants To Be Successful With SCIENCE
content:
In my latest video, I’m elaborating on these 4 things that give me hope for 2021: SCIENCE - The scientific public has reacted to the news of the virus at an astonishing rate. Have you ever thought that the genome of a virus can be sequenced within 24 hours?! GOOD LEADERSHIP - Strong and clear-minded leaders like the PMs and presidents of New Zealand, Canada, Iceland, Singapore or Germany could safeguard their people more than others.  HUMANITY - People dancing on balconies and really caring for each other like never before; and messages of hope, love and support soaring to medical personnel all over the world.  HEALTHCARE - Today, decision-makers have realised that no society can live without well-operating healthcare. Maybe we needed a global stressful event that is a warning big enough for us to notice. title: The Ugly Truth About DRAWING
content:
What a year 2020 has been. The industry I work in vanished in a week, I worked three times more than ever before, didn't travel at all for the first time in my life. I learned to live with all kinds of insecurities. Made many professional mistakes and got totally exhausted by the end of the year. This year has broken me a little bit. I lost some hope in humanity and myself too. But all my family members and friends are healthy. I spent a lot of time with my wife and daughter. I witnessed the rise of science in the era of fake news. I bought a studio and launched a new business.  The Medical Futurist  broke all records. I made new friends through sports and online gaming. I broke through some barriers in my chess journey. However, I cannot wait to start a new year. I don't expect it to be better because it's new. It's going to be better because we make it so. I'm ready to work, serve my community and continue to learn even more in 2021. And if I have to go through all that suffering again, let's get into it. Now I have some experience. :) The COVID era will end when we are all vaccinated. I cannot wait to get mine and as The Medical Futurist, I will keep on fighting against misinformation. That's my pledge for 2021. I wish you all the best for 2021 too!

title: What Can You Do To Save Your OPERATING SYSTEM From Destruction By Social Media?
content:
My last book recommendation for 2020: Quiet: The Power of Introverts in a World That Can't Stop Talking by  Susan Cain . The book describes how the 20th century was for the good-looking extroverts, the ‘sales’ types of people.  Whereas the 21st century is all about the introverts: the Bill Gateses and Elon Musks, the Big Bang Theory genius geeks.  However, the future is for “the mix”.  It made me note both the introvert and extrovert personality traits I have: I’m very introvert in my life, in disliking social events, when I’m immersed in reading, even when driving a car (no radio or podcast on, just complete silence). Whereas I also feel amazing when giving a keynote to 1,000 people.  Without going too much into the scientific reasoning behind this (read the book for more details!) What's important is that we should do our best to balance our introvert and extrovert personality traits to make them collaborate rather than conflict with each other. Have you read this book? If so, let me know your thoughts! #bookrecommendation   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #book   #reading   #read

title: 3 Ways You Can Reinvent BANKING Without Looking Like An Amateur
content:
When drawing blood, a robot won’t just assume they know where your vein runs – they actually see it.  Its hands never shake, it is never overworked, it won’t get tired – and it frees up valuable nurse time. Nurses would still need to be present to provide empathy and support to the patient. Still, we humans seem to be sort of afraid of them. And this is even the case if they can do a better job than humans – we don’t want them to do so. This is a burden we must overcome as another cultural shift on our route towards digital healthcare. Read more on how robots can draw blood and what it means for the healthcare of the future. #robotics   #blooddraw   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: Why You Really Need (A) GRAPHIC
content:
‘Webside’ instead of bedside: a new, digital way of communicating with patients. I keep highlighting the need for a cultural transformation in healthcare to catch up with the digital transformation (rapidly accelerated by COVID-19).  Kaiser Permanente’s new curriculum is a wonderful example: instead of only teaching students the necessary bedside communication skills that each medical professional learns, they now integrate the “webside” manner. They want to prepare students for a clinical practice likely to be far more virtual than ever before, as there’ll be less bedside visits and shaking hands, and more virtual interactions. Still, communication and creating a connection with patients is such a key element of medicine, and since digital communication is something different, it needs to be learnt.  Well done!  Interested to learn more about how medical professions will need to prepare for the digital transformation? Grab your copy of my e-book “The Technological Future of Medical Specialties”  https://lnkd.in/gF5gd62   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

title: Use PROGRAMMING To Make Someone Fall In Love With You
content:
Which vaccine will I want to get? This is one of the questions I get the most. In the UK, the first 130,000 people got vaccinated against COVID-19. The Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine just got approved in the US, and we’re waiting for the authorization of the Moderna vaccine as well. I expect to get the vaccine around May as luckily I’m not considered to be part of the high risk category. So what’s my answer? I’ll get the vaccine about which I can read a study. Since I see the studies for both the Pfizer-BioNTech and the Moderna, I could choose either.  Whereas I don’t see any for either the Russian or the Chinese vaccine. A decision about a vaccine should never, ever be about which political power is communicating about it louder than others.  It has to be a competent pharma company with a study, peer reviewed and published in a medical journal, approved by a regulatory agency. We all understand the rush and the pressure, but despite all this, medical clinical evidence is a must. And I stand by this forever. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

title: 3 Ways You Can Reinvent BUSINESS Without Looking Like An Amateur
content:
A.I. will bring the real era of the art of medicine. We all know that the art of medicine requires attention, time, and empathy from physicians while they are treating patients. Whereas currently, lots of administrative tasks need to be handled, and there’s a constant pressure from payers impacting physicians. Thus even the chance for the art of medicine vanishes.  However, the use of artificial intelligence could help facilitate it. Using advanced technologies, medical professionals will be able to care for their patients better, and their challenge will not be in finding out how to do it but instead to understand why certain methods work and others do not.  As an example: Imagine that A.I. will come up with a drug combination that works, and a medical professional needs to figure out why and how it came up with it. More about this in my paper:  #study   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #TMFI   #research

title: DANCE Adventures
content:
*Where To Invest? The Trends And Technologies To Look Out For In Digital Health* While working on my e-book “Invest in Digital Health” for  The Medical Futurist , I reached out to  Frank Kumli , Head of Innovation & Entrepreneurship and Member of the Management Board at Basel Area Business & Innovation. I asked him how they decide which healthcare startup or company is worth investing in. He listed their criteria: a) Is the value proposition interesting enough, does it create impact? b) Is the value proposition differentiated from other products existing in the market? c) Is the team capable of developing the company? d) Is the investment bringing them to a stage that will enable follow-up investment? e) Does the company have first customers or a proven intent from customers to buy the service/product? Are you interested to learn more? title: Find Out How I Cured My CRAFT In 2 Days
content:
Google gets into the medical research game, and it’s mixed news. Google is launching a new research app for Android phones, which would allow anyone with a device to participate in medical studies.  Participants in the study will use the app to report any respiratory symptoms, the precautions they’re taking to prevent disease, and whether they’ve been tested for COVID-19 or the flu. The app will collect demographic data, like age, gender, and race as well It opens up two worlds: one into a better world of clinical trials and studies with more and more relevant patient data; and one into a dystopia where privacy is significantly flawed. I can't yet decide which one this will lead to but I'd opt in to participate in studies as I see more benefits from those, compared to how much of my privacy I’d lose. Too bad it won’t let me download or tell me why. Probably it’s US only? #techgiants   #googleresearchapp   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: 4 Ways You Can Grow Your Creativity Using ZOOLOGY
content:
Let’s see what a patient from the future like me talks about with his primary care physician. I’ve just had my annual check-up with my GP,  Reka Vernes MD, DipIBLM . Each year, I bring some of my health data to her so that we can discuss the preventive plan we have for the next year.  Here’s a summary: - I do high-intensity training for 25 minutes a day on average, which is 2 minutes more than last year. I exercise at least 15 times a month, sometimes 18.  - I’ve lost weight and now weigh 78-9 kg, which means a 24.1 BMI. The goal is 77-78 kg with a 23.5 BMI.  - My resting pulse is 60-65, and 54 on average while sleeping. - I did an alcohol-free month, and I’m planning to do 3 more like this in 2021, as I was really pleased with the results.  - Because of having a higher risk for melanoma, I will regularly attend a check-up with my dermatologist and use @SkinVision.  - I’ve got a high cholesterol but can’t take medication because of being sensitive to it (based on my genome sequence test), so I have to adjust my diet. For that, I also need a new microbiome test.  I’m so blessed to have her in my life and being able to consult with her based on my digital health data. Have you had an annual check-up with your primary care physician? If so, did you take your data with you?

title: How To Start A Business With POLITICAL
content:
Let’s get this straight: A.I. doesn’t replace doctors. It empowers them. That’s why this study is crucial to mention. Normally, breast cancer detection by looking at mammograms is done by two doctors, one of which they switched to A.I.  They worked side-by-side for 7 years, and the outcome? No significant change with the results, and that’s what we’re looking for here. Researchers concluded that using Mia together with one human reader could help to address the radiology workforce crisis in breast screening, and provide a solution for dealing with the backlog of cases due to COVID-19.   #mia   #breastcancerdetection   #mammograms   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: The Biggest Lie In POLITICS
content:
Here we go again: Big words in the headline while the study was retrospective. A study from Northwestern University concludes that DeepCOVID-XR, an A.I. algorithm they’ve developed, detected COVID-19 on chest X-rays with performance similar to a consensus of experienced thoracic radiologists. However, when you look into the details, you see it was trained on data retrospectively.  Whereas a physician diagnoses and treats a patient real-time, and doing that retrospectively would yield very different results and efficiency. I think study authors should only compare an algorithm's performance to that of physicians if both used the same method to diagnose or treat, prospectively. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: 5 Reasons MUSIC Is A Waste Of Time
content:
We’ve all read similar news before, but those efforts failed (think back to the Novartis-Google: digital contact lens in 2017). Let's hope it makes it to the market this time! Why is it important? Tears are a promising source for biomarkers, as they often contain levels of various analytes that are similar to those found in the blood. Examples of clinically relevant indicators found in tears include sodium, which can indicate dry eye disease, and glucose, a marker of diabetes. As tear collection can be a challenge, biosensing contact lenses could come in handy.  #hydrogencontactlens   #biomarkers   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy

title: Some People Excel At CRAFT And Some Don't - Which One Are You?
content:
Interrupted sleep is terrible! Interrupted sleep while being in a hospital can straightaway slow your recovery. Now an artificial intelligence based algorithm can help avoid that. Many patients get woken up at night or at dawn to have their blood pressure measured or blood tested. When all they should be doing is to rest.  Researchers of this paper mean to avoid these unnecessary overnight monitoring, using a clinically based deep learning model. They’ve checked millions of data from a multi-hospital health system to train an algorithm that creates an early morning patient score: this shows who are those patients that really need to be woken up due to a risky condition. Their result? From 10,000 cases, the algorithm was wrong only 2 times.  This is exactly the kind of clinical problem where we need to start A.I. research and implementation. This is so very convincing that it could enable the adoption of artificial intelligence in other areas as well.  #deeplearning   #research   #hospitalcare   #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #machinelearning

title: 14 Days To A Better POLITICAL
content:
A.I. has already penetrated every aspect of our lives, even if you just think of simple tools you use on a daily basis: the algorithms in Google, Waze, Spotify learn from your decisions and habits, and end up guiding you.  It also has an enormous potential on the future of healthcare: it will enable us to move from the “one size fits all” medical solutions towards targeted, personalized therapies.  However, much work needs to be done until we reach the full potential of A.I. in healthcare.  It needs a lot of data, as well as a major cultural transformation among patients, medical professionals, institutions and regulators.  I’m eager to help this transition. title: 10 Warning Signs Of Your PROGRAMMING Demise
content:
You know how much time and effort I dedicate to choose what to read next? (That’s right, a LOT).  So who doesn’t love a good old “Best of” book list? 🕮 Here are my top picks of non-fiction from 2020. What was your favorite one this year? Human Compatible by  Stuart Russell  - Provides the perfect context and historical background to understand where A.I. is coming from.  The Logic Of Failure by Dietrich Dorner -  Learning about how and why we fail and more importantly, why it is understandable in many situations to fail is a new experience.  You Look Like a Thing and I Love You by  Janelle Shane  - It showed me what A.I. is really capable of today (and what it’s not). Rebooting AI by  Gary Marcus  - A clear view about the big picture of A.I., how it will impact our lives and what we can do to protect what matters: our life, privacy and freedom.  Possible Minds: Twenty-Five Ways of Looking at AI by John Brockman - A collection of essays about different aspects and fields of A.I.  The Revolt of The Public and the Crisis of Authority in the New Millennium by Martin Gurri - A new angle on our society today.  How Virtual Therapeutics Will Revolutionize Medicine by  Brennan Spiegel, MD, MSHS  - Everything that matters on VR in healthcare.
