title: 7 Easy Ways To Make GST Faster
content:
Finally, the study we’ve been waiting for since the beginning of the pandemic is out! It obtained data from wearable trackers from over 30,000 people to find out whether the data can be used to differentiate between asymptomatic and symptomatic COVID patients. They also aimed at spotting pre-symptomatic individuals early. "Our results show that individual changes in physiological measures captured by most smartwatches and activity trackers are able to significantly improve the distinction between symptomatic individuals with and without a diagnosis of COVID-19 beyond symptoms alone." They will keep on expanding the cohort but it’s already a staggering result and shows a bright vision for digital health.  Can you imagine a world where the health technologies we use alert us about upcoming health issues similarly to the warning lights in your car? I can.  Let me know what you think!  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus   #wearables   #covid19prediction

title: The Death Of PAINTING And How To Avoid It
content:
Fitbit  just lost one of their most enthusiastic customers: me.  How did they manage to do so? Read my story: * I was among the first to order the new Fitbit Sense in August. * They couldn’t find my order for 2 months then confirmed to have lost it. * I spent ~4 hours with customer support. * They offered me free shipping if I placed the order again but it would cost around 30% more. * Even though it’s unfair, they don’t seem to care or will do anything.  It’s simply the worst experience I’ve had since Google acquired them and I won’t buy any more products from them. Why is this especially sad?  * I used to be a true brand ambassador: * I’ve had about 10 Fitbit trackers from the very beginning (since 2009) * I always highlighted that it was the first device to include a smart sleep alarm, the Holy Grail of health tracking * I continuously spread the word and many bought Fitbit products because of that My suggestions for improvement: Fix your customer service 🙏🏻 Getting a tracker is a matter of trust and without proper customer service, there can be none.  Can you suggest another health tracker I could try? I need a smart sleep alarm, good battery time and standard health tracking features such as fitness and heart rate. Your suggestions are much appreciated!

title: 5 Ways You Can Get More POLITICS While Spending Less
content:
Far the most cited paper of  The Medical Futurist Institute  in recent years is this one: The role of artificial intelligence in precision medicine. It describes that through the cultural transformation called digital health, the hierarchy of traditional medicine is transforming into an equal-level partnership between patients and caregivers. Besides many disruptive technologies, A.I. has the biggest potential to support this transition by analyzing the vast amounts of data patients and healthcare institutions record in every moment. By taking away the repetitive parts of a physician’s job, it might lead to being able to spend more precious time with their patients, improving the human touch. However, A.I. can only fulfil its mission if it remains a safe, efficient, and proven aid in treating patients and improving healthcare. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #TMFI   #research

title: 5 Ways To Get Through To Your ART
content:
Digital health has shaped my life.  It helps me exercise 30 minutes on average every single day. It makes me keep working on my performance. It helps get a better picture of my overall fitness and daily physical activities. It helps check my resting heart rate. It has helped me improve my sleep and wake up at the best time every morning. It has helped me lost weight and then keep it. It has helped me design a preventive plan with my physicians. This is the summary of what I have learnt while using around +100 digital health technologies over the last decade. Unless you a fitness guru with a unique intrinsic motivation, you will be like me: needing external motivation. Data can bring it to you. Technologies alone cannot change your lifestyle, but you can change your lifestyle with good technologies. Have you used digital health technologies to shape your lifestyle? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #wearable   #health   #healthy

title: Avoid The Top 10 Mistakes Made By Beginning PAINTING
content:
Today is the day that for exactly 6 months, I have not travelled anywhere. Since the beginning of the pandemic, like so many others, I've been homebound. A few things I have learnt over this short period. 1) Virtual keynotes not only can be as useful as in-person talks, but the visual opportunities are endless and I cannot wait to show you a few examples of what we have done already. 2) It feels good not to contribute to global warming by flying and traveling less. 3) I can work more than ever. Literally, 10-12 hours, no weekends, this is a vicious circle. You keep on finishing tasks but you never finish the list. 4) Consequently, I have to put much more emphasis on my mental health. If you spend all your time in a swimming pool, all you can do is swim. This is what happens to me now. 5) The logistics of virtual keynotes is twice as hard as for in-person keynotes (I would have not believed you if you had told me this 6 months ago). What have you learnt over this turbulent period? #covid   #covid19   #keynote   #speaker

title: Why Most SCIENCE Fail
content:
Recently, I shared a report that stated: "It takes roughly seven patients presenting after an abnormal pulse alert to establish one clinically actionable cardiovascular diagnosis." I described that you cannot expect one digital health technology to solve a medical issue in itself. And you cannot avoid using such technologies in healthcare to provide sufficient care. This is why digital health is a cultural transformation where you can't just drop a technology into the system and expect everything to get better. You need both patients and medical professionals to be on the same page, discuss the expectations and side effects and work together by using that technology. This is the topic that we address in the newest article on  The Medical Futurist .  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology

While only 6% of patients have used paid medical apps in the past, almost 60% would use these digital tools if their physician prescribed them and the costs were covered by the payer. One of the apps is Kalmeda which aims to help with tinnitus, and the other one is Velibra, a therapy programme for anxiety disorders. The German government passed the Digital Healthcare Act (DVG) last year and this is an incredible step forward into the era of digital health. title: What Your Customers Really Think About Your SCIENCE?
content:
Here is the scientific consensus about COVID-19 as of today. All these statements are supported by scientific evidence. 1) The infection fatality rate of COVID is several-fold higher than that of influenza. 2) There is no evidence for lasting protective immunity after getting the virus. 3) The virus is capable of re-infecting people. 4) Transmission of the virus can me mitigated by social distancing, hand hygiene and wearing masks.  5) The way many countries handled the first wave led to widespread demoralisation and diminishing trust. 6) Herd immunity is still unsupported by scientific evidence. 7) Countries like Japan, Vietnam and New Zealand, have shown that robust public health responses can control transmission allowing life to return to near-normal.  #covid19   #covid   #healthcare

title: Believe In Your POLITICS Skills But Never Stop Improving
content:
I gave the opening keynote today at the virtual event called "State of Europe". I was asked to set the tone for the panel led by Dr  Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus , Director-General of the  World Health Organization .  I focused on how the pandemic has shaped the adoption of digital health and what it feels like to meet so many new things and technologies on a daily basis. I also talked about how to predict the future of healthcare, especially during such challenging times, and what future we should look forward to in the coming years. title: Take 10 Minutes to Get Started With BANKING
content:
This is my favourite story these days. This is how you develop and deploy an A.I.-based algorithm for a clinical purpose. Sepsis Watch is the product of three and a half years of development (which included digitizing health records, analyzing 32 million data points, and designing a simple interface in the form of an iPad app).  It scores patients on an hourly basis for their likelihood of developing sepsis (when an infection triggers full-body inflammation and causes organs to shut down). It then flags those who are medium or high risk and those who already meet the criteria. Once a doctor confirms the diagnosis, the patients get immediate attention. It has dramatically reduced sepsis-induced patient deaths and is now part of a federally registered clinical trial expected to share its results in 2021. #healthcare   #aihealthcare   #digitalhealth   #artificialintelligence

title: Now You Can Have Your PAINTING Done Safely
content:
I was a co-author of this paper published in PLOS One. We aimed to explore the digitally engaged physician’s knowledge and attitudes towards digital health technologies and the transformation of the doctor-patient relationship. We did this by doing qualitative, semi-structured interviews with 11 digitally engaged physicians from 9 countries.  We asked them about the role of digital health and technology in the medical practice and their everyday challenges, the ideal physician-patient relationship, and skills and competencies needed for working with e-patients and visions about the future of the medical practice. The interviewed physicians state that digital health solutions could create a deeper doctor-patient relationship: knowledgeable patients are a huge help in the joint work effort and technology is the main tool for creating a more involved and responsible patient.  Medical professionals in the future might rather get a role as a translator between technical data and the patient; as a guide in the jungle of digital health. However, the interviewed physicians also noted that digital transition today is more beneficial to patients than to their doctors. #digitalhealth   #futureofhealthcare   #study

If you ever wonder where to start, here are three books that heavily impacted how I see A.I. 1) Human Compatible by Stuart Russels provided the perfect context and historical background to understand where A.I. is coming from. 2) You Look Like a Thing and I Love You by Janelle Shane showed me what A.I. is really capable of today (and what it is not). 3) Superintelligence by Nick Bostrom gave a glimpse into the far future of A.I. and described where it is heading. If I were you, I'd start with these three books. Then, there will be hundreds of others that are excellent. title: Use BUSINESS To Make Someone Fall In Love With You
content:
While I write often about the limitations of artificial intelligence and what it can really offer in practice today, sometimes I come across developments in A.I. that not only blow my mind away but also depict an exciting vision of the future of healthcare. Look at this: In some cases, patients need injections with an iodine-based dye (radiocontrast) to make their organs more visible in scans. But some patients can’t take the dye. So researchers developed a GAN (generative adversarial network) that generates labeled, undyed CT images of lesions on kidneys, spleens, and livers. They added these images to real-world training data to improve performance of a segmentation model that marks lesions in diagnostic scans. As it's really hard to get enough quality medical data to train the algorithm on and labeled medical data is even harder to find, GANs are making it easier and less expensive to create large, annotated datasets for training A.I. diagnostic tools.   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #aihealthcare   #digitalhealth   #futureofhealthcare   #themedicalfuturist

title: 3 Ways Create Better HR MANAGEMENT With The Help Of Your Dog
content:
EyeQue Corporation  was kind enough to send their latest kit, the at-home Vision Monitoring Kit after I reviewed their previous device. It includes the VisionCheck, an upgraded version of the Insight and the PDCheck to check your pupillary distance with a selfie. It’s quite like having a basic checkup at the optometrist right at home! We just tried the VisionCheck to get our EyeGlass Numbers which are similar to lens prescriptions. By attaching the device to your phone with an included rubber band, you can measure the refractive error of each eye by performing 9 visual tests on each eye through the companion app. These tests revolve around using the touch controls on the device to align colored bars on-screen. It’s quite user-friendly and there’s a helpful audio guide throughout the process. You won’t get the most accurate result at first (as the app mentions), but with more vision tests and less deviations obtained from the readings, you’ll get a more accurate EyeGlass Number. While it’s clearly not meant to replace your annual eye checkup, it allows one to keep track of how their vision changes over time. You can then share the data with your eye care provider for better insight rather than the once-a-year measurements traditionally performed. #digitalhealth   #eyecare

This is huge!  The US government’s largest national health insurance plan decided to reimburse hospitals for the use of a deep learning model that spots signs of stroke so patients can receive time-critical treatment (up to $1,040 per patient for each use). The app called Viz LVO is the first A.I. software to be covered under Medicare's New Technology Add-on Payment program. The program covers the cost of the accepted breakthrough technologies.  "Viz LVO classifies blocked blood vessels in CT scans of the brain with 90 percent accuracy. When it identifies a potential stroke victim, it automatically notifies a specialist to review the case, bypassing the usual radiologist review. The model screens out roughly 90 percent of scans, dramatically reducing the number that require a specialist’s attention. The app has been shown to accelerate diagnosis and improve patient outcomes." #ai   #digitalhealth   #artificialintelligence   #healthinsurance

I've been waiting for this moment for months!  Npj digital medicine, the digital health journal of  Nature Research (Publishing) , published our original research about artificial intelligence-based FDA-approved medical devices and algorithms. It's our first publication in such a high-level journal. We aimed at filling two gaps: 1) The FDA should assess and approve A.I.-based medical devices and algorithms differently from others. 2) There should be an accessible database of such algorithms and devices as the FDA's website doesn't make it possible. Our team put a huge effort into creating an open access database and as the paper is available to everyone for free, please use it and share it if you find it useful! If you find any new items or we have missed something, please send your submissions, we'll cross-check it and update the database constantly. Hopefully, the FDA will soon take control over the database as they have the right resources to keep it growing. Thanks  Pranavsingh Dhunnoo, M.D. ,  Stan Benjamens , and  Adam Moroncsik  for the gargantuan work put into this effort! #DigitalHealth   #AIHealthcare   #FDA   #HealthcareAI   #HealthcareAIDatabase

Well, it seems my pursuit is not in vain. After sitting for 8 hours at a chess competition (and those extra 2000 for preparation), I won a bronze medal at a local tournament. I took part in the same competition last year and barely gained a few points. At that time, I had about an 500-hours investment in chess. The 1000-hour difference shows not only on the final scores but also in my relationship with A.I. While I was simply flabbergasted when I saw Leela Chess Zero making an exciting move last year, I gradually start to understand these movements and their "motives" now. It's an incredibly exciting journey! And I really look forward to deepening this understanding even more after the next 1000 and 2000 hours! #Chess   #ChessAI   #AIChess   #ArtificialIntelligence   #AIHealthcare

title: Why Most People Will Never Be Great At POLITICAL
content:
Accenture released a report based on a survey that around 2000 participants filled out in the US. They conclude that before COVID-19, growth in consumer digital health adoption had stalled. While the cohort is small and only US-based, I understand the criticism around digital health tools and services. My main concern is that they call it virtual care. I have a great relationship with my GP, and when I share some data with her about a potential health issue and she helps via digital communication, I don't feel that it's different from when she attends me in person. Digital health in the eyes of its users and medical professionals will always look like something that doesn't want to work, while the solution's been here all along: whether you provide care in person or by using a way of digital communication, it's just care. Stop calling it virtual care, stop alienating this from everyday medicine and accept that digital health will bring a cultural transformation. This is the new norm where the use of technologies is inevitable in caring for patients. This misconceptualization derails the whole study. Instead of emphasizing the differences between virtual and in-person care, it should examine ways to improve care in general. And that question is independent from technologies. 
 
 
 …see more

Verily Life Sciences  launched Coefficient Insurance last week. So Google takes a hand in the health insurance business too. As Google knows literally everything about us, we can imagine what advantages it has in risk management. What concerns me more is how the future of health insurance looks like where our provider has all our health data from search inquiries to our fitness trackers (Fitbit's been Google's for a year now). Tech giants are unavoidable actors in healthcare by now. This enables way more effective care, but we also have to be aware of unprecedented privacy issues. You can better understand the motives behind and potentials in each tech giant's move and how a healthcare dominated by them looks like from our ebook, 'Tech Giants in Healthcare', which we recently updated with COVID-19 relevance. Neuralink finally showed something. It, being one of Elon Musk's companies, promised to create a viable technology as a brain-computer interface. There have been doubts about this, just like about his rockets or electric cars, but those at least work. Well, the announcement didn't tell much. We saw 3 pigs, one with an electronic brain implant, one that had an implant and one that never had one. They demonstrated how they can obtain signals with the first pig when its nose touched something. But we are very far from practical uses. What striked me the most was how Elon tried to make every scientific claim dive into the realms of science fiction. One scientist described how such an interface would let patients with retinal issues see again, and Elon immediately started talking about giving people supervision. I love a bit of a hype myself, but putting microchips into people's brains is no rocket science, it's something much more complicated. #Neuralink   #BrainComputerInterfaces   #Neurotechnology   #DigitalHealth   #Neuroscience

Since I've started talking about this to some people I know and work with, now 8 people decided to do something similar with me. Some of them will abandon alcohol, others will stop smoking or drinking energy drinks for a month. It has become a community project. title: Why Most People Will Never Be Great At DANCE
content:
I asked Dr.  Ádám Schmidt  to test  StethoMe® , the A.I.-enabled digital stethoscope in his pediatrician practice, and here are his observations: "StethoMe is probably a dream device for parents and for doctors to follow up on pulmonary and cardiac diseases. The device is portable, mostly for home use, is sleek and has no buttons to confuse the user. The StethoMe app gives the user comprehensive advice on what and how to do during the examination. The auscultation is recorded with the device and sent via Bluetooth to the phone app, which uploads it to the cloud and is analyzed by the StethoMe AI algorithm. It can be time-consuming and difficult to complete a good enough examination, especially when a child is crying. The StethoMe AI algorithm can’t filter the surrounding noise, and the device itself is quite loud too - because of that, home use can be tricky. Overall, I like the device and find it useful. It can be used at home to decide on the status of your patient. I find it very useful that you can record and play back previous recordings, creating a timeline of data to monitor the evolution of the disease. As an addition, with this function it is easier to teach medical students and educate patients. Looking forward to the progression of the device." #DigitalHealth

If there's one thing I do as a futurist, it's thinking about the future. As for the future of my presentations and meetings, I settled for virtual at least until Summer 2021. If you took part in Zoom meetings and webinars, you might have realized that switching to virtual has its difficulties and annoyances, with a lot of muddling and amateurism - to say the least of it. To avoid this, we have to learn an entirely new profession (that extremely few do): of online streamers. As I've studied streamers for this purpose for months now, I've drawn enough lessons for an article about what medical events could learn from them (it's coming next week).  Of about 20 virtual presentations by now, I concluded with delight that my possibilities for delivering my messages have multiplied! I can merge the potentials in YouTube videos, streams and keynotes at the same time: enhance the show with new graphics, switch between shots for emphasis and show what's otherwise not visible. Maybe I'll feel more anxious and defenseless before I present in person for the first time. I just received this death threat about how this person wants to break into my home, steal my data, and kill me for the topics I cover on  medicalfuturist.com .  I know similar things have happened to many of us, including Eric Topol and recently Anthony Fauci too. It, of course, shouldn't be part of a researcher's job and I have never heard my scientific peers and supervisors complain about this.  So either it's happening now because of how some of us live our professional lives online, OR because of how many scientific and medical issues have been politicized lately during the pandemic. When people turn science into politics, they authorize themselves to turn facts into opinions. Maybe with the popularity science is gaining also comes the mistrust that politics receive? This is more dangerous than any death threat from a lunatic. The question is, what should we do?

title: Beware The BANKING Scam
content:
Last year,  Peter Kuhar , founder of  Azumio Inc. , reached out to me with some preliminary data showing Type 2 diabetes detection with just a smartphone. Now Nature Medicine published their study. To me, it shows how to turn a promise into a proof, also giving a boost to digital biomarkers. I had a quick chat with him. - Can you please summarize the findings of your study? We've developed an algorithm that can detect diabetes using heart pulse recorded by a smartphone camera. Enabling an early detection of Type 2 diabetes with just a smartphone. - How do you expect the field of biomarkers to change based on studies like yours? Digital biomarkers are easy and low cost to measure and have a potential to allow early detection of diseases that would otherwise not be possible. One of the main problems with Type 2 diabetes is late diagnosis. Our algorithm will help catch this chronic disease faster. - Do you think that the hardware of a general smartphone would be enough to add insights to diabetes management? Absolutely. The hardware with this capability is available since 2014 on iPhone, and lately more and more and more Android devices are getting this capability. #DigitalHealth   #DigitalBiomarkers   #T2D   #Diabetes

title: Find A Quick Way To PAINTING
content:
Being digital and portable doesn't guarantee that a device will be useful. I usually show services and devices that I heartily recommend, but now here's a friendly warning about gadgets you should be cautious about - they might be just (digital) dog and pony shows! 1. Calorie count from photos. You take a photo of your food and the app tells you the nutrients it contains. It's not even accurate when you weigh portions of your food and add those to an app like MyFitnessPal, so imagine how accurate those could be, using only photos. 2. Cheap tools to measure heart rate and sleep quality. If you want to take your tracking endeavors up a notch, you can't succeed with a single app or device just above the very basic level. 3. Pulse oximetry apps. You can install them for free on your phone, but unfortunately they are inaccurate - even studies show. 4. Genetic ancestry tests. It's thrilling to take one. But don't try to gain any medical insights from it. And definitely don't try to prove anything with it at your visa application. 5. Multifunction devices that can measure your vital signs, earthquakes, and the mood of your family. Maybe even killing mosquitoes. If something sounds too good to be true, it is. Which  #DigitalHealth  service didn't live up to its promises for you?

title: 5 Ways Of PROGRAMMING That Can Drive You Bankrupt - Fast!
content:
Our holiday-related Instagram quiz sparkled a lot of interest. Is it really true that such a patch exists that alerts you before you get sunburnt? What's the name of the device that buzzes for dehydration? And so on. So here you are, my hitchhiker's (and vacationer's) guide to holidays! About wristbands that measure water in your blood with infrared light: I don't believe they are accurate enough (if they're not accurate for heart rate, forget about proper hydration levels). Apps that regularly remind you to drink water to avoid dehydration: You might be surprised, but I don't think we need a device for every drop of fluid, every blink, and every breath we take. But, challenge me if you know any concrete cases one needs a ding-ding for each glass of water. Wearable patches that measure sun exposure and notify the user when they are about to get sunburnt: I haven't seen that in practice - as far as I know,  L'Oréal  only came out with it as a pilot. I would gladly try them though! Dermatology apps that identify rashes and mysterious insect bites: I have tried  First Derm by iDoc24  and I've had a good experience with them. It definitely won't hurt if you download it before setting off! #DigitalHealth   #Holidays   #DigitalHealthApps   #HealthTech   #FutureOfHealthcare

title: What Alberto Savoia Can Teach You About ZOOLOGY
content:
If you've never had back pain, don't read on. If you sometimes do, you are probably looking for some relief for it. Something that's easy to manage, portable, user-friendly, and durable. And most importantly, it has to reduce pain. I just tested Reliefheat, a device that promises exactly these. This is my experience with it: - The belt is easy to use, comfortable and portable. - The device operates on an app where you can set the basic features via Bluetooth. It heats and changes temperature in seconds and even learns your preferences. Charging is quick and battery life is long. - But: you need to figure out first if heat works for you or not. Everyone reacts to the same treatment differently. Heat might alleviate your muscle and joint problems, but for inflammation you should stick with something cold. - ReliefHeat is designed for the lower back area and although I tried to use it on other body parts, like knees and shoulders, it didn’t work out well and was uncomfortable. - The product is only available in the US and Canada. All in all, ReliefHeat delivered on its promises. If I had chronic back pain that reacted to heat, it would be an instant buy. But if the pain is elsewhere, or heat did not make you feel better, I would recommend you finding another option.

title: The Ultimate Guide To FASHION DESIGN
content:
This is a great illustration of how significant the cultural transformation with digital health is. Lancet Digital Health published an editorial addressing the issue of race to end health inequalities. They stated that racial and gender bias represent a significant problem in digital health, and even digital health approaches have contributed to these disparities by not considering race or ethnicity. "For example, melanoma diagnostic apps trained on images of white skin have difficulty detecting cancerous skin lesions in darker skin. Even failing to sufficiently account for variables that are correlated with race, such as health-care expenditure, can create a wedge between health needs and care received. When race clearly plays a causative role in health outcomes it should be incorporated into digital health approaches to prevent bias." And here, at pointing to a serious flaw, science stopped so far. What practical ideas would you give us and Lancet to fight racial injustice in digital health? We, at  The Medical Futurist , support these efforts, and I hope that we could come up with relevant analyses or research soon. Source:  https://lnkd.in/erEMKea #DigitalHealth   #RacialBias   #AIBias   #BiasInHealthcare   #GenderBias

title: 10 Things You Have In Common With MUSIC

All these medical conditions need a complex skill-set to manage them daily. Professional and personal alike - and experiences that medical records can't store. So, she created a one-pager where she included bits and pieces about her personal and professional life. Fallow listed what technologies and social media she uses, trackers such as Fitbit, Garmin or Strava. She even entered all the resources and assets that help her manage her condition, starting from her supportive partner until the medical alert dog. She described what symptoms she struggles with and what her current goals are regarding managing her illness. It is clear, concise and might be very helpful to doctors. title: The Biggest Lie In PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
This is the surprise of the year for me. I wouldn't have thought I would use (and need) a CO2 monitor daily. These days, when the A/C is on quite often, this device makes me realize that my concentration slips not because of the heat, but because the room lacks fresh air. When the CO2 concentration is above 1000 ppm, it enters the yellow zone, which is not critical, but I realize it's already too high for me. So, whenever you are feeling drowsy at work, open the window first before turning up the air-con! You might just need some fresh air - no matter how hot it is. We even wrote about this issue, including the device I tried, check it out: https://lnkd.in/eBtqe8b #DigitalHealth   #AirQuality   #AirQualityMonitor   #CO2Monitor   #OpenTheWindow

title: It's All About (The) MUSIC
content:
What a coincidence. I just had an interview with  The Wall Street Journal  about my forecast whether there would be an NBA season this year. I concluded that I can't imagine NBA's future without digital health devices. And now this. The WNBA and NBA are teaming up with digital health companies for the coming season. They'll provide  Oura  smart rings to every team and staff member, and also supply players, coaches and staff with the MightySat fingertip pulse oximeter. This is how Christy Hedgpeth, the COO WNBA, commented on these steps: “Protecting the health of players, as well as team and league staff, is paramount. title: The Secret Of GST
content:
Another great step from the  #DigitalHealth  arm of the  FDA . They just issued a guidance about regulating medical products that contain several functions. Some of those functions are subject to FDA’s regulatory oversight as medical devices, while others are not. I read the whole thing so you don't have to. When they regulate a medical device, the so-called "other functions" may jeopardize the cybersecurity, reliability or accuracy of the device. So they want to make sure that those other functions are also regulated, and the industry is aware of the dangers and risks so the FDA can have a better oversight over such devices too. As technologies get more advanced with artificial intelligence-based analysis, using smartphones or other connected devices, it was time to address this so patients and medical professionals can still use such technologies with trust. The best example they mention at the end is about a smartphone app that detects skin cancer from photos of suspicious lesions of moles. They describe that the quality of the photo a phone camera can make significantly shapes the outcome of the analysis. The manufacturer of the app should document how the camera impacts their app's accuracy. Excellent step forward! #FDAregulation   #HealthcareRegulation

title: DRAWING Expert Interview
content:
After  OpenAI  released its first commercial product - a rentable version of a text generation tool - recently, I've seen examples that point to a world where we people will constantly struggle to find out who we are talking to: a person or a bot. It can be so sophisticated, so human-like that we will develop common techniques we will share with each other that help determine whether the entity at the end of the communication line is indeed a robot. Just look at the conversation the bot had with a person about his holiday plans (image below). It's been used to write music lyrics, poems, news articles and many more. I first talked with a chatbot named Eugene in 2015 and it amazed me how it tried to trick me into thinking it was a person. I remember giving it a math test about apples and it asked whether I really wanted to talk about apples. When companies like Woebot offer chatbots for dealing with COVID-19 and related mental health issues, it's particularly important for these chatbots to function properly. Otherwise, they can do a lot of damage. In short: get prepared to bots tricking you into thinking they are human. https://lnkd.in/ejY7VCB #AI   #chatbot   #DigitalHealth

title: How To Learn ART
content:
Researchers at the University of Tübingen tried to train an A.I. to learn to identify a specific fish called tench on pictures. When they looked into the A.I. to see how it tries to identify that fish, they found out that the  #AI  was looking for human fingers against a green background as most of the tench photos in the training data featured a fisherman holding the fish in their hands after catching it. Can you imagine how useful it would be in medicine to point out such things before an algorithm is developed? This way, we could avoid so many false negatives, false positives and bias built into the algorithms. For example, radiologists looked at the ChestXray14 dataset of X-ray images and discovered that many of the images of patients with pneumothorax had a chest drain on the image as treatment already started when doing the X-ray. A  #MachineLearning  algorithm tasked with identifying X-rays of pneumothorax would probably look for the drain in the images as a perfect sign of the condition (they have to perform as well as humans would do, not learn to diagnose the condition), this way, missing patients with the condition who have not been treated yet. Can you think of an example in your practice (medical or not) where such subtle observations exist?

Instead, managers have to explain what it will give us - e.g. if you can download an app for your medicine, or if you can measure your health data wherever you are. This urged me to share the five words that I deliberately erased from my vocabulary long ago, and I recommend you to erase them too. Because you express nothing with them (at best), or only that you don't have a clear picture about it at all (at worst). title: Can You Really Find BUSINESS (on the Web)?
content:
There is an excellent new study that focuses on the intersection between medical A.I. and human trust. It describes very simply why both over and under trust represent barriers in adopting A.I.-based medical technologies. If you have over trust, you accept whatever decisions the A.I. would make without questioning that (and that's never a healthy option). If you under trust it, you'll need a lot of unnecessary resources to deal with its decisions as you will want to re-check everything. They conclude that: 1) The efficacy of human-A.I. collaboration is not only about the underlying mathematical process behind the A.I. system but also human factors, including trust. 2) Recent approvals of A.I. algorithms reveal the limitations of existing regulatory standards (at The Medical Futurist Institute, we have a study coming out about this soon). They also mention that the increased patient involvement in a patient-centered healthcare model changes the status quo. And "if A.I. systems are an essential part of this shared decision-making process between patients and clinicians, trust relationships between patients and A.I. systems deserve further in-depth research." https://lnkd.in/e9Hf8QF #AIresearch   #AI   #ArtificialIntelligence   #medicalAI   #HealthcareAI

content:
Dante Labs , the Italian company that sequenced my whole genome last year, offered me to try their COVID-19 antibody test. As I usually travel quite a lot and I expect to travel again from around Q4 this year, it would be great to know whether I have any antibodies against the coronavirus. They use the ELISA technology, which means it's not a rapid test, so I have to send the sample back. They claim that the test is good for population screening but is not appropriate for diagnostic testing. They also say that the analytical sensitivity is so high that the results are guaranteed and validated with an amount of blood that is as low as 5 drops of blood. I will test this too as I struggled to get enough blood into the tube. Maybe I'm a robot after all. #COVIDtest   #COVIDAntibodyTesting   #COVIDScreening   #COVIDTestKit   #COVIDTesting

title: CRAFT Is Crucial To Your Business. Learn Why!
content:
I just came across a great paper describing the difference between anonymization vs pseudonymization. Both represent important methods for protecting the privacy of patients whose data take part in studies and are analyzed by artificial intelligence. Currently, these are the most widely used privacy preservation techniques for medical datasets: 1) Anonymization is the removal of private data from a medical record. Simply, they delete parts of data such as name, gender or age. 2) Pseudonymization is the replacement of sensitive entries with artificially generated ones. They simply replace data such as name, gender or age with synthetic ones. It's harder than it sounds. Interestingly, the paper concludes that "De-identification by naive anonymization or pseudonymization alone must therefore be viewed as a technically insufficient measure against identity inference." But authors don't leave us in the dark, but recommend techniques that can indeed enhance patients' privacy. Check it out: #ArtificialIntelligence   #privacy   #anonymization   #pseudonymization   #HealthData

title: Beware The MATHEMATICS Scam
content:
We can already measure so many vital signs and health parameters with wearables. But EEG (cc. brain waves) has always been an outlier. The company Muse has been the leader in this space, but no matter how much work they have put into their device, signal strength is an issue due to the nature of measuring EEG. Even while I meditated with it, if I blinked one, the signal strength changed. Muse did help me learn how to meditate better, but I stopped using it eventually because I couldn't reach mindfulness with a device on my head. Now  Brainlink International, Inc.  was kind enough to send their device to me. Their headset has a relaxation and a focus training component too. I plan to test both, but obviously, I'm much more interested in the focus training. I used to test the  NeuroSky  headset with a drone so when I reached a certain level of focus, the drone started flying around. There is no drone now, but there is definitely a place on the market for a focus training, EEG-based device. I'll keep you posted. (My face? This is what I look like when I'm about to meditate with a headset.) #EEG   #EEGdevice   #EEGheadset   #MentalHealth   #DigitalHealth

title: Proof That PROGRAMMING Is Exactly What You Are Looking For
content:
Finally, the results of Verily's Project Baseline Health Study are out! The study's original purpose was to build the world's most comprehensive omics database of people and their medical conditions to discover new insights, create new hypotheses about how these different systems are interrelated and lead to developing diseases. They collected almost every kind of health parameters, vital signs, physical examinations, and biomarkers. From radiology imaging to pregnancy tests, from psychological evaluations to data from sleep and fitness sensors several times over the course of the study. While going through the details of how they designed the data collection process, how they will make the data available to researchers worldwide, and what they expect from these, I could only think of artificial intelligence.  No human being will be able to oversee that much data, that many layers and systems. This is the future of healthcare research, and we will be doomed without A.I. And, it's a brilliant example of why you should stay in the loop with A.I.'s capabilities in healthcare! Reading our e-book on the topic is a great start. https://lnkd.in/gzEVGGN #ArtificialIntelligence   #AIResearch   #DigitalHealth   #AIInHealthcare   #HealthcareAI

title: You Will Thank Us - 10 Tips About PROGRAMMING You Need To Know
content:
I finished Rebooting AI, a book that provides a sober image of the status of A.I. and expectations for the near future. My favorite part was when authors Gary Marcus and Ernest Davis describe what you could do to survive a robot apocalypse. They came up with quite surprising pieces of advice. 1) Close your doors and lock them: robots cannot open mechanical doors. 2) Paint your doorknob black because robots cannot see against a black background. 3) Go upstairs. Most robots cannot climb the stairs. 4) If none of these work, hop on a table and wait. Its battery will soon run out. These are humorous but true recommendations. They show how long the path is ahead for robots and automation to catch up with what we can do. I'm not afraid of a robot apocalypse (partially because I'm always kind to any technology around me), but I go and paint my doorknob, just in case. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #book   #reading   #read   #robots   #RobotApocalypse   #ArtificialIntelligence   #AI   #robot   #RebootingAI

title: The Hidden Mystery Behind PAINTING
content:
A fantastic review came out in the British Medical Journal. Nagendran et al. analyzed the design, reporting standards, risk of bias and claims of studies comparing the performance of diagnostic deep learning algorithms for medical imaging with that of expert physicians. There is a line in their paper that should be on the wall of every company involved with medical A.I.: "The danger is that public and commercial appetite for healthcare AI outpaces the development of a rigorous evidence base to support this comparatively young field." They could only find about a dozen studies and pointed out how many studies are not prospective and have not been validated on real world data. Their results stand as a proof that while the field is new and just started to skyrocket, the same rules must apply to them as to any other medical technologies, no matter how exciting A.I. results sound. There is a long path ahead and we plan to support this mission with two new papers at The Medical Futurist Institute, I hope I can share those with you in no time. title: How To Save Money with MATHEMATICS?
content:
I would never have imagined that I would be affected by depression in my life. After all, I lead a healthy lifestyle, work out regularly, have social relationships - I consider myself an outgoing, happy person with a healthy attitude. It was only these past few months that I started experiencing fatigue and anxiety, and I even lost my motivation because of the feeling of hopelessness and uncertainty. I shouldn't wonder, because these are hopeless and uncertain times, which causes symptoms of depression to more than half (!) of us - as several studies show. Even the WHO put together a brief on mental health considerations during COVID-19, with tailored messages not only to caregivers, but also to the general public. Of course, digital health companies also joined in the efforts. UK-based startup UnMind provides a platform for workplace mental health, Headspace is specializing in meditation, while Big Health offers a digital sleep improvement program to help overcome poor sleep without pills. I have been using  Headspace Inc.  before too, and I found it useful for meditating more often. Do you use an app or a device to take care of your emotional and mental health?

Here are all of them: - Microbiome test (Thryve and Atlas Biomed) - helped refine my diet - Whole Genome Sequencing + BRCA genetic testing (Dante Labs) - helped design a preventive plan with my GP - Genetic ancestry (National Geographic) - for fun - Medication sensitivity, genetic test (MyDNA) - my GP took notes - Gluten and peanut content in food (Nima) - just for the sake of the technology - Celiac disease test (Imaware) - I'm not sensitive to gluten - Food intolerance for fructose and lactose (FoodMarble) - no results yet We are collecting even more to give a comprehensive image about where this industry is heading and what services are becoming available at home. title: How You Can (Do) POLITICAL Almost Instantly
content:
5 things you should try to stay healthy with technologies 1) Keep track of your daily physical activity (I use a Fitbit Ionic device for this purpose, but I can also recommend Polar Chest Strap. You can also find free in-built health apps on your phone.) 2) Use a smart sleep alarm to make sure you wake up easily (Several Fitbit and Apple Watch models have this feature. As an alternative, Sleep as Android is a great free app.) 3) Do an ECG analysis from time to time (mine is Kardia's newest 6-lead device - unfortunately I don't know any free alternatives for that.) 4) Check your blood pressure once a month (I do it with iHealth, but grandma's old blood pressure cuff will also do.) 5) Check your skin lesions (I have skin lesions I should get checked out regularly - in the meantime, I re-check them with SkinVision. Their assessment is free, with possible upgrades.) How many things out of these 5 are you doing already? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy   #fromchancetochoice

title: How To Take The Headache Out Of PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
To help its users stay fit during the lockdown, Fitbit extended its free Premium trial from 7 to 90 days. That's already enough time to experiment with its benefits, so I decided I would give it a try - there is nothing to lose here. Now, after a month, here are a few things that have been definitely useful and worked as an added benefit of being a Premium member of Fitbit. Besides the obvious guided exercise and meditation programs, challenges and adventures, the Wellness Report has been far the most exciting feature for me - it's amazing. In the Android app, you can find it under the Discover menu, then "Health and Wellness Stats" and "Wellness Reports". It gives a great overview of my resting heart rate, sleep patterns, how much time I have spent exercising and how many steps I have made on average. This is much better than the stats in the app and the descriptions are more helpful too. I will share these data with my GP to check how my resting heart rate changes in relation to my workouts. title: Succeed With BUSINESS In 24 Hours
content:
A new paper in npj Digital Medicine just describes how a smartphone-based microscope using deep learning could screen for sickle cell disease. I find it fascinating when research groups can combine these three things: 1) a disease that affects a lot of patients 2) a device that is already in our hands, our smartphone 3) artificial intelligence making use of the data we can capture with it Here is an excerpt: "We blindly tested this mobile sickle cell detection method using blood smears from 96 unique patients (including 32 SCD patients) that were imaged by our smartphone microscope, and achieved ~98% accuracy, with an area-under-the-curve of 0.998. With its high accuracy, this mobile and cost-effective method has the potential to be used as a screening tool for SCD and other blood cell disorders in resource-limited settings." https://lnkd.in/dd8WBSf #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #sicklecelldisease

Could it be relized everywhere or only in selected hospitals? How would a "smart hospital" that's built within days look like? Why is it smart - how is it equipped? We are also working with them to show how they are planning this (updates soon!), and for thinking together, I'm really curious about your insights. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #smarthospital   #smarthospitals   #nvidia She also told me: "We are building a time machine for healthcare researchers harnessing accelerated computing and AI and a real-time response system for healthcare professionals and patients powered by AI and edge computing. In the case of infectious disease or cancer research, every day counts. The world can generate more biomedical data than ever before in our lifetime. Healthcare R&D can no longer take 5-10 years to discover a vaccine or a drug and now has called upon accelerated computing and AI to transform their workflows and do years of research in a matter of hours or days."

title: Now You Can Buy An App That is Really Made For ZOOLOGY
content:
When Frederick Banting discovered insulin in 1923, he refused to put his name on the patent. He felt it was unethical for a doctor to profit from a discovery that would save lives. Had he seen the price tags these days, he would turn in his grave. The annual costs of insulin and supplies are about $6000 today and costs continue to rise. This leads every fourth person with diabetes skimping on, or outright skipping lifesaving doses. Not only people with chronic diseases have to weigh their health in thousands of dollars a year - but almost everyone. Have you ever started calculating how much your life is worth? If you like our videos, we would appreciate if you could also express your support by joining our Patreon community. title: 12 Questions Answered About GRAPHIC
content:
I talked with a professional video game streamer, Blyyy, who was super kind and shared all his insights about live streaming.  We have seen numerous examples of how speakers do it wrong (you know those terrible Zoom check-ins), so I thought why not be inspired by those who are definitely professionals in such technicalities?  I learnt that * He sometimes streams for 12 hours a day. Then he exercises (he often exercised in the stream encouraging his viewers to train with him). * He told us what technologies (hardware and software) we need to use for a good stream. It seems we will experiment with YouTube Live first. * He shared how he "branded" his audience, started calling them by a name that is unique to his channel. * He described how hard it is to maintain contact with them and keep them engaged while sitting in front of a camera and a green screen with his hands on the keyboard and mouse. * He hasn't used a biometric sensor but some of his colleagues have showing their pulse during intense gaming moments. * Many streaming services have a significant lag (even almost a minute) which would make a live Q&A unbearable. So there is plenty of work to be done. But  The Medical Futurist  will hold its first virtual (free) event in May. Details soon! #digitalhealth   #speaker

There are interesting initiatives that involve A.I. in some form in the fight against COVID-19. 1) Google just launched the COVID-19 Research Explorer, a semantic search interface which includes more than 50,000 journal articles and preprints to help scientists and researchers pore through articles for answers or evidence to COVID-19 questions.  https://lnkd.in/gpQauXx 2) At MIT, there is a group of machine learning and life science researchers who are collaborating on developing machine learning methods for finding promising antiviral molecules for COVID-19 and other emerging pathogens.  https://lnkd.in/gndZ9TB 3) Cure-19 offers an at-home clinical trials platform to patients with or without coronavirus symptoms. By joining their studies, patients can help researchers make new discoveries by donating their anonymized symptom and health data to research.  https://www.cure19.org / It's incredible to see how many A.I.-based projects come out of the shadow and this trend might indicate that the attention the medical uses of A.I. should have been receiving already is here to stay. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: Remarkable Website - CRAFT Will Help You Get There
content:
Artificial intelligence has been enjoying a boom in certain medical specialties and radiology always stands out. There is an interesting story in MIT Tech Review about what A.I. is capable of in imaging. Rizwan Malik, radiologist at the Royal Bolton Hospital, turned to A.I. to make his job easier. In his hospital, patients often had to wait six hours or more for a specialist to look at their x-rays. If an emergency room doctor could get an initial reading from an A.I.-based tool, it could dramatically shrink that wait time. A specialist could follow up the A.I. system’s reading later. So last year, Malik identified a promising A.I.-based chest x-ray system called qXR from  Qure.ai  and proposed to test the system over six months. As COVID-19 jumped into our lives, they also had to re-design the system that now is capable of identifying coronavirus-specific signs. Such a fast response and iteration is only possible in the case of A.I.-based medical technologies. This is why it's so crucial that the FDA, for example, started analyzing companies instead of individual algorithms for approval. Also, there are so many COVID-19 related ongoing A.I. projects in medical imaging, that Stanford started to curate many:  https://lnkd.in/gE_rdhP #themedicalfuturist   #AI

title: Short Story: The Truth About PROGRAMMING

title: The Secret of Successful CRAFT
content:
A rapid systematic review just came out in the  BMJ . It aimed at reviewing and critically appraising reports of prediction models for 1) diagnosing coronavirus disease 2019 (covid-19) in patients with suspected infection, 2) for prognosis of patients with covid-19, and 3) for detecting people in the general population at risk of being admitted to hospital for covid-19-related pneumonia. It's quite devastating what it found and clearly shows why implementing A.I. into the clinical practice is going to be so hard without evidence-based data. They found that the proposed models are poorly reported, at high risk of bias, and their reported performance is probably optimistic. Only one study used patient data from outside of China. We have to exclude hype from those papers and push the medical/scientific community to stick to the standards of reporting about A.I.-based technologies. https://lnkd.in/g_xfSrg #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #covid19   #coronavirus

title: 10 Best Practices For FASHION DESIGN
content:
In the span of a few days mid-March, around 30 of my upcoming keynotes were cancelled. Since then, it has been a logistical nightmare, but finally, our new studio is up and me and my crew have done around 5 keynotes in the past week or so. To be honest, I never thought that virtual keynotes could replace the ones in person and that it's possible to give spectacular keynotes with an engaging Q&A like that, but it turns out I was wrong. What has changed is how people around the world look at this digital solution and are more open to it. Also, I'm not sure if going back to business as usual is the way forward. As the technical background and what we can stream only depend on the creativity of my team, I can make sure to present even better than in person. And being close to my family is an obvious added benefit. So virtual keynotes might be the new norm and I cannot wait to let my top clients discover how it works. https://lnkd.in/gjNWcja #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife   #virtualkeynote   #onlinespeaker

title: The Untold Secret To GRAPHIC In Less Than Ten Minutes
content:
A note for those who don't understand why we had to shut the world down for this pandemic. This new virus led to a significant death toll in weeks, there are no treatment protocols, or thousands of peer-reviewed studies, no experience and knowledge in textbooks. Therefore, we had to shut down the world to let the medical workforce do its best until they can deal with it. Without the lockdowns, there would be peaks of cases in the span of days, leading to tens of millions of avoidable deaths, an overwhelmed medical workforce, and even mroe uncertainty about when we can go back to our lives. All this turns out to be a moment for  #digitalhealth  to shine. Telemedicine has become the norm in many countries to avoid exposure to infections. 3D printing technologies help support the broken supply chains of medical and protective equipment. Chatbots help those who face mental health challenges. Artificial intelligence helps prepare for the spread of the virus, reorganize supplies and help prioritize patients at higher risk for a severe disease. Apps all over the digital health specturm assist those who stay at home and still try to live a healthy lifestyle. As the pandemic passes, and it will, I hope the openness for these technologies will remain with us forever. #covid19

title: Lies And Damn Lies About GST
content:
What if instead of having to go to the hospital you could stay wherever you are and receive care there? What if your treatment was developed specifically for your condition and your organism instead of having been experimented based on the whole population? What if the doctor-patient relationship looked more like a partnership than a hierarchical connection? What if you, the patient owned all your health data instead of institutions? What if physicians served as guides in health management rather than give authoritative orders to their patients? What if everyone could access reliable medical knowledge instead of only medical professionals and researchers? We at  The Medical Futurist  are not just daydreaming - I believe this is what digital health is going to bring for the future of healthcare. Even the current global crisis has shown that some shifts can take place way more smoothly than we have imagined (just think about telemedicine). The infographic explains this vision. If you want to understand it and help it come true, I highly recommend this ebook bundle, 'The Future of Digital Health': https://lnkd.in/gt_a57x #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #book   #reading   #read   #ebook

title: How To Turn PROGRAMMING Into Success
content:
There is a great story in Wired about two startups, BenevolentAI and Atomwise and how their researchers are trying to find drugs that could be useful in treating COVID-19 patients. They look for new drug combinations and also trying to repurpose existing medications.  This is only possible through A.I.-based simulations, data mining and network science. One of the issues of this infection everyone is talking about recently is the cytokine storm it causes that can lead to intensive care even for younger adults. It seems there is an antiviral treatment that could help prevent it from happening and all this was found using the methods I listed above.  A.I. finally becomes mainstream and I cannot wait to read the myriad of papers that come out in the coming weeks. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: An Incredibly Easy Method That Works For All
content:
Yesterday, I had the chance to attend the event (virtual, of course) of  deeplearning.ai  and hear  Andrew Ng  and  Eric Topol, MD  speak about how medicine could attract more A.I. developers. Dr. Topol highlighted some real-life clinical examples where A.I. can help (from radiology to dermatology) and he also pointed out the major flaws with the field today (no prospective studies, only a few clinical trials, not enough data, among others). Dr. Ng told a story about how his physician father wrote in a book in the 1980s that machines will not replace physicians but would only sharpen their decision-making and clinical judgment. In response to what we are witnessing today, they launched an A.I. in medicine course at Coursera for developers and made the event's recording public. title: Interesting Facts I Bet You Never Knew About DANCE
content:
The global community of A.I. developers really came together to address issues raised by COVID-19. There are some interesting projects launching these days. For example, Hermes Ribeiro Sant Anna, a machine learning engineer in São Paulo, Brazil, built a web app that highlights surfaces prone to coronavirus contamination by human touch. You submit a photo from a room, hall or any other place where people might be in and an A.I. will recommend surfaces that require frequent disinfection to avoid contamination.  https://asepsis.org / Also, some of you asked where I find new papers and studies that focus on the intersection between medicine/healthcare and artificial intelligence. First, I have a Google Scholar Search Alert set up so new papers come to my inbox every day. For a more curated set of papers, I'm subscribed to the weekly newsletter of Eric Topol & Pranav Rajpurkar called Doctor Penguin.  https://doctorpenguin.com / And if you have time to read only one abstract these days, make it this one:  https://lnkd.in/g8Qx-4D #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #GoogleScholar   #DoctorPenguin

title: 14 Days To A Better PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
For me, tech company  NVIDIA  has long been an interesting resource from artificial intelligence and molecular dynamics, medical imaging to data analytics. As the platform becomes increasingly active in the fight against COVID-19, offering technology and expertise on multiple levels, I had a chat with Kimberly Powell, Vice President of Healthcare at NVIDIA about the company’s take and vision on A.I. in healthcare.  She mentioned these efforts: * Providing a free 90-day license to Parabricks to any researcher in the worldwide effort to fight the novel coronavirus. Parabricks uses GPUs to accelerate by as much as 50x the analysis of genomic sequencing data. * Teams of expert data scientists have joined a challenge to forecast infection spread and fatalities in regions around the world. Others are creating a model to run natural language queries and summarize the mountain of COVID-19 papers. * NVIDIA Inception is teaming with 160 healthcare startups that are now turning their focus to COVID-19. NVIDIA is lending its expertise, computing resources, and funding to accelerate the work that includes medical imaging models for COVID-19, no-contact body temperature measurement systems, molecular compound discovery algorithms, and UV robots for disinfection. #coronavirus   #covid19

Another example why A.I. has a primetime during COVID-19. We have been analyzing what areas or aspects of medicine and healthcare it could support and this is what we have found: * Detecting future pandemics * Monitoring pandemics through smartphone use * Looking for new drug combinations with network science * Understanding pandemics and their dynamics better * Triage in the intensive care unit * Predicting clinical severity for individual patients * Improving diagnosis through radiology * Predicting healthcare capacity and supplies * Analyzing patient data and tests for diagnosis Have you seen other use cases? It makes sense to be vigilant and to know about the potential privacy issues and dangers that come with the use of A.I., but at the same time, let's have no doubt that we won't be able to tackle the next pandmic without implementing A.I. way before it appears. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: Fear? Not If You Use CRAFT The Right Way!
content:
Google started releasing anonymized location data from users who have the "Location History" setting enabled in their Google accounts. This way, public health officials can see how effective social distancing measures are in 131 countries. The announcement mentions that Google isn't releasing any data on individual people or specific locations. Instead, "it used differential privacy techniques to add noise to the data sets used to create the reports in an effort to make it harder to de-anonymize that data used to create the reports." It means it's possible to deanonymize data, in theory, even though the risk is small. I'm so glad such huge data sets can support the fight against the pandemic, but we have to be vigilant so beating the pandemic doesn't come with the loss of our privacy. I deactivated the location history in my account years ago, but I'll now reactivate it until the pandemic is over. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus   #google   #locationhistory   #virustracking   #privacy

In this video, I speculate how COVID-19 will end based on the analyses of public health experts. I also discuss what it would mean for us and how different it will be going back to our life which is not going to be the same. Also, a few interesting news and developments. Reporters at STAT News tested several chatbots that were specifically designed for answering patients' questions whether they have the coronavirus and the results varied greatly. With the same symptoms, they got different results such as there is probably no risk and start at-home quarantine immediately.  There are A.I.-based technologies that could make contact tracing much faster (it usually takes days) and could send a warning to people's phones who have been in the proximity of a patient who was just testedt positive. While it would significantly help the fight against the pandemic, it would also be a privvacy nightmare. title: A Guide To PAINTING At Any Age
content:
The FDA just approved an antibody-based test for COVID-19 which raises interesting issues. Those patients who are infected with the virus produce antibodies specific to the virus and such tests can detect them. This would show who has already been sick — whether they had symptoms or not — and therefore, who is probably immune enough to the virus to safely move around.  It doesn't mean the test is helpful during the pandemic but it could be useful when we try to go back to living our lives and doing our jobs. I'm just speculating here: What if the pandemic goes on for many months from now even with the worldwide lockdowns and only those people would be allowed to reduce social distancing (to work, do shopping, travel, etc.) who has a positive antibody test and a negative virus test (a PCR test showing there is no coronavirus in their body)? What if biotech companies have to create a sort of biological passport so some people can go back to society? I hope it'd only happen if the worst pandemic scenarios take place. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

title: The ZOOLOGY Mystery Revealed
content:
Social media is truly a double-edged sword during the COVID-19 pandemic. First, it's an essential tool for us to get information and be updated with guidance from pandmic experts. It also serves as a repository of solutions medical professionals can use worldwide. Just look at the myriad of Facebook groups and Twitter hashtags that connect the maker community to those in need.  Second, it overwhelmes us with information that is hard to digest and causes anxiety. Just think about how our lives will change after that. Let's say officials open up the lockdowns and curfews. People will not rush the streets ad buy air tickets immediately. It will take months to regain our trust in the world and its safety. What you can do is to point out reliable resources such as the map dashboard from Johns Hopkins or official sites from WHO or CDC, and direct people who are anxious there. You can help digest the news and look for consensus when it comes to questions like "Shall I wear a mask if I have no symptoms". You can help ease this anxiety so we can get back to an almost normal world (or maybe even a bit better) in a few months. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #COVID19   #COVID_19   #coronavirus

title: Never Lose Your POLITICS Again
content:
A digital twin is a virtual copy of a tangible entity or an intangible system that can be analyzed independently of its real-world counterpart in order to make informed decisions. NASA employed a similar concept when it created physical replicas of its spacecrafts on Earth while the actual ones were in outer space. The same concept can be applied to medicine too: a virtual representation of the human body and its organs where the effects of drugs can be studied. And its impact can be revolutionary. #themedicalfuturist #digitalhealth #future #healthcare #medicine #technology #fromchancetochoice #digitaltwins #digitaltwin #personalizedmedicine

A Canadian doctor who works in Gaza just made 3D printed face shields. On Facebook, there are many new groups dedicated to connecting designers and engineers who can help those in need. title: Take 10 Minutes to Get Started With MATHEMATICS
content:
I just came across a company called Maple that developed a virtual care program that tries to reduce the burden on the staff in emergency departments. They are piloting it with  Health PEI , a governmental organization.   Some patients who meet the program’s specific inclusion and exclusion criteria can use a virtual care visit right on the spot, instead of waiting for in-person treatment. The nursing staff under medical directives can perform a few tests, then add data about the patient on the online platform. This request goes out to a network of physicians using an Uber-like matching approach and physicians determine if they’d like to “pick up the visit” and treat the patient.  They reported an incredible drop in waiting times - down from 8 hours in some cases to under 5 minutes because of their matching algorithm and triage approach. I know there are many emergency physicians here. What is your experience with such solutions? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #ER   #emergencymedicine

title: The Hidden Mystery Behind PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
DeepMind  just made a nice gesture and shared its predictions about the protein structures of the coronavirus, which causes the COVID-19 epidemic.  The system uses a machine-learning technique known as "free modelling" to help it predict protein structures when no similar structures of protein are available. They decided not to wait for a peer-reviewed paper but published the results now.  They emphasised that "these structure predictions have not been experimentally verified, but hope they may contribute to the scientific community's interrogation of how the virus functions". A.I. in action. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #covid19   #coronavirus

A portable robotic device is capable of introducing needles and catheters into deformable tissues such as blood vessels to draw blood or deliver fluids autonomously. title: 52 Ways To Avoid DRAWING Burnout
content:
I was thrilled to read Garry Kasparov's wise remarks about making peace with technology and learning that collaborating with artificial intelligence makes us, humans stronger. He also addresses the dangers of A.I. in a very sophisticated way: "People say, oh, we need to make ethical AI. What nonsense. Humans still have the monopoly on evil. The problem is not AI. The problem is humans using new technologies to harm other humans." His balanced, sensible stance on such issues posed a perfect contrast to the book I just finished, 'To Save Everything, Click Here"" by Evgeny Morozov. I understand that we have to be critical of advanced technologies and skeptic about their impact on our lives, but I'm always on the bright side of this debate and I'm very optimistic about our future because we are creating it.  When it comes to our technological future whose stance can you embrace more? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #book   #reading   #read

title: DANCE An Incredibly Easy Method That Works For All
content:
A new technique based on deep learning can shorten some brain surgeries. During brain cancer operations, surgeons must stop in mid-operation for up to half an hour while they send the tissue to the lab where a pathologist analyzes it. A new test powered by deep learning does the same but within the operating room, with spectroscopy, and in only a few minutes. They trained the network to recognize 13 cancer types that account for around 90 percent of observed brain tumors and measured its performance in a clinical trial (the first trial of a deep learning application in the operating room, they said). We are getting one step closer to taking full advantage of A.I. at surgeries! https://lnkd.in/gSenxd4 #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #deeplearning   #surgery

The WHO estimates that 95 percent of the world’s adult population is inactive, failing to meet minimum recommendations for health of 30 minutes of moderate to intense physical activity five times a week. To make it worse, smartphone users spend an average of two to four hours per day hunched over their phones - putting as much stress on their spines as having an 8-year-old sitting around their necks. It might sound paradoxical that digital health technologies can also help raise awareness and improve on such bad habits. However, trying Lumo Lift - a device that alerts you when you slouch - was a way less annoying experience for me than I thought first, and it really helped me pay attention to my posture. title: The SCIENCE That Wins Customers
content:
I recently shared that because of my high genetic risk for skin cancer, I get regular check-ups by a dermatologist, plus I also re-check the risky spots once a month with  SkinVision . You cannot imagine the flow of negative comments I received after that. A week later, a review concluded that current algorithm-based smartphone apps cannot be relied on to detect all cases of melanoma or other skin cancers. Exactly! This is why I don't only rely on them. I use them to re-check spots. I also asked Skinvision to comment on the study and got this from Erik de Heus, CEO, SkinVision. "The latest research, not included in the authors' overall assessment, proves that our algorithm can detect 95% of cases of skin cancer. In comparison, the sensitivity of general practitioners ranges from 61% and 66%, while the sensitivity of dermatologists is between 75% and 92%. SkinVision has assisted in finding over 40,000 cases of skin cancer already. These objective facts prove that the clinical benefits of the service outweigh the risks." Digital health technologies take time to be proven + these technologies only assist current medical procedures. Skinvision could simply win this battle by having a similar study result that was not supported by them. Where do you stand on this?

title: Want A Thriving Business? Focus On GST!
content:
The FDA just approved the first drug to treat 4-17 years old children having peanut allergies. It's designed to minimize the incidence and severity of a child's allergic reaction to peanuts. In the US, 2.5% of children have peanut allergy, but millions of people are affected worldwide. For some, eating food containing peanut - whether denied by clueless waiters or mislabelled on the package - can even be lethal. So when I say that sensors indicating whether a food has peanut can be very useful, I mean literally life-saving. In this category, I tested  Nima Labs 's sensor (they also have one for gluten), and it does the task flawlessly - if you put a small sample of food in it, it indicates peanut accurately, is truly easy and fast to use, and it's portable. The only flip side is that you have to change capsules for each sampling, which is neither economical nor environmentally friendly. So, at the moment, it's not without fault - but neither is the newly approved treatment.  Which do you think will come true first: the perfect cure for peanut allergy or economical and environmentally friendly testers? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #medicine   #technology   #nima   #glutensensor   #peanutsensor   #glutensensitivity   #glutenintolerance   #peanutallergy   #foodintolerance   #foodallergy
