If you ever wanted to get a good summary of the major ethical and legal concerns that will arise in the age of medical A.I., see this short paper in JAMA. It describes what happens with the privacy of patients and healthcare staff when computer vision-driven ambient intelligence is available in hospitals. It also addresses how consent could be obtained and what methods exist for defending the privacy of all healthcare personnel. It even touches upon whether such recordings could be used in legal cases and in general, how to take these into considerations when A.I.-based systems keep on improving healthcare's efficiency. Check it out:  https://lnkd.in/g9kGfB5 #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #aiethics

title: SCIENCE Made Simple - Even Your Kids Can Do It
content:
MIT Technology Review  published an excellent short study about how 900 healthcare professionals see A.I. today and what they expect from the future. While the report debunks many myths surrounding A.I., I think a key finding is on this image. 75% of medical staff who have AI agree that it has enabled better predictions in the treatment of disease. This is a good start and many A.I.-based methods and systems have not even been proven yet through evidence-based medicine. Moreover, Prof. Michael Brady from the University of Oxford noted that "When we combine AI-based imaging technologies together with radiologists, what we have found is that the combination of the AI technology and the radiologist outperforms either the AI or the radiologist by themselves.” This should go on a T-shirt! Here is the full report:  https://lnkd.in/g3xjiZC #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #artificialintelligence   #ai   #radiology

title: 7 Rules About GRAPHIC Meant To Be Broken
content:
I keep on geting questions about the accuracy of smartphone apps for heartrate measurement. There are smartphone apps that promise to tell you your heartrate if you put your finger on the camera near the flashlight.  The simple conclusion I can share after testing a lot is that well-designed devices are much more accurate than these apps. Even studies showed that their accuracy is questionable. The apps have an error rate of about 5-15% that doesn't sound much but it's basically saying that the heartrate you measure with these apps is far from being precise and, more importantly, far from being a reliable vital sign you can base decisions on. Here is the study:  https://lnkd.in/g7FBgUu #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #health   #healthy   #fromchancetochoice   #healthapp   #heartratemonitor   #heartratemonitorapps   #heartrateapps

title: Where Is The Best FASHION DESIGN?
content:
Another excellent example of how A.I.-based systems could help improve healthcare. On January 9, the WHO notified the public of a flu-like outbreak in China. But a Canadian health monitoring platform,  BlueDot Inc  , sent word of the outbreak to its customers on December 31. It uses an AI-driven algorithm that scours foreign-language news reports, animal and plant disease networks, airline ticketing data and official proclamations to give its clients advance warning to avoid danger zones like Wuhan. It also correctly predicted that the virus would jump from Wuhan to Bangkok, Seoul, Taipei, and Tokyo in the days following its initial appearance. There is so much data that even the most experienced experts are not able to deal with it or see everything while these algorithms can filter through the mess of information. I hope governments and global organizations will take advantage of them. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #wuhan   #coronavirus   #epidemics

This is simply heartbreaking. I have a huge respect for Lee Sedol, not only one of the best Go players of all time, but also the one who accepted the challenge from Deepmind to play against AlphaGo not so long ago. He got beaten and it was a huge milestone in the history of artificial intelligence but his retirement from professional go comes as a surprise.  Thinking about loud here. Is this what we can expect to see in medicine too? title: The Untold Secret To PROGRAMMING In Less Than Ten Minutes
content:
SkinVision is a dermatology app that aims to fight against one of the most deadly diseases, skin cancer. It uses machine learning to assess cancer risk - if you take a photo of a spot on your skin, it classifies it as low, medium as high risk instantly. I have just done my regular check - it took 30 seconds, instead of having to wait 3 months for the appointment and 2 hours in the waiting room at the dermatologist's. I also made my wife check her skin lesions.  #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #healthapp   #dermatology   #dermatologyapp   #healthcareapp   #skincancer   #skinvision   #health   #healthy   #fromchancetochoice

I'm always tempted to put it aside ("NOW I'm in a hurry"), even though I know it serves an important purpose: eat slowly - eat less - be healthier. title: Want More Money? Start PROGRAMMING
content:
When you know that there is a solution for your problem, but the healthcare system's slow bureaucracy and false promises fail to deliver it to you... what would your next step be? Would go the extra mile to pass by the system - if it was a question of life or death?  We collected some case studies where being proactive has not only saved a patient's life, but also revolutionized healthcare - these all show how empowered patients can shape the future. title: 5 Easy Ways You Can Turn PROGRAMMING Into Success
content:
I couldn't have come up with a better example to demonstrate how an artificial intelligence-based system will support the job of physicians than the recent paper from Google Health.  Even the head of Google Health UK said that such algorithms support the job of physicians, not replace them. So please don't believe the hype when you read the headlines such as A.I. outperforms physicians in diagnosing a medical condition.  1) These usually take place on pre-selected data sets, and clinical life is much more diverse than that.  2) Many of these studies are retrospective and still have to prove the efficiency of the algorithm prospectively. Just one of the reasons why I have a keynote narrative entirely dedicated to understanding A.I. from the medical and healthcare perspective. Those working with A.I. algorithms must understand at least the basics and it is indeed possible without any prior knowledge. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #mammography   #googlehealth   #speaker   #speakerlife   #keynotespeaker

A new digital pill gets FDA clearance! etectRx Announces U.S. FDA Clearance of Novel Ingestible Event Marker  https://lnkd.in/g6nm2tr I asked the company what their technology could do: The ID-Cap System may allow healthcare providers to follow medication adherence to life-saving medication used to treat conditions such as atrial fibrillation or heart failure with the intent to prevent strokes and myocardial infarctions.  The use of this ID-Cap System may also help track and improve adherence to medications for the treatment and prevention of infectious diseases, such as HIV, hepatitis C, and tuberculosis,  enabling achievement of better therapeutic outcomes and public health goals.  This technology also provides the potential to identify medication-adherent patients in clinical trials who can more accurately reflect the efficacy and safety of the medications being evaluated.  The goal is to assist in the approval of more medications that may have failed prior clinical trials due to poor medication adherence or suboptimal dosing.  #adherence   #pharma   #drug   #medication   #medicine

Your A.I. Prescription, 3-2-1 Lift Off! Yesterday was the first time I presented my new keynote narrative about my favorite topic: artificial intelligence in healthcare. The audience was a group of medical futurists to-be, students from the Biomedical Instrumentation subject at the Budapest University of Technology and Economics. I talked about why you already live with A.I., and how we can get the best out of it for the sake of patients.  I also had impromptu expert assistance by  Ármin Juhász  (my FIDE-accredited chess trainer) and  Gabor Csato MD, MSc  (CEO of the Hungarian National Ambulance Service). It was fun to have them add their points of view to the story! From the questions, it was good to see how clearly these future inventors and engineers see the potentials and threats of A.I., as well as their key role in keeping control of it: the majority of questions were about ethical concerns and responsibility issues. I hope I'll have a chance to present this narrative to you somewhere along my upcoming speaker tour. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife   #artificialintelligence   #AI

Out of curiosity, I decided to dive into the database of  Pubmed.com  in September to see how many studies have mentioned machine or deep learning technologies in the last decade. It seems we have an almost exponential boom of such studies in medicine and healthcare - which is not surprising. It was also expected that oncology, pathology, and radiology stand out when it comes to using A.I. methods in medicine. However, I was surprised to see so many studies in psychiatry, surgery, and neurology while you don't see discussions, news and announcements about those developments often. At the same time, it seems that cardiology, ophthalmology, and dermatology, the specialties with the most exciting news and developments seem to be underrepresented. The explanation could lie in the method I used to mine the database but it's still interesting. title: Take 10 Minutes to Get Started With HR MANAGEMENT
content:
After recently giving a talk about the future of digital health, I received a simple yet challenging question: "Where should I start?"  The lady was the leader of a professional medical education organization in the US and she assured me she was on track with the whole cultural transformation of digital health. However, she was concerned about where she should start. I asked her whether she has seen or read about any technology in science fiction that made her excited. She told me that she loved those hoverbikes that flew in the desert in the original Star Wars. I asked her is she ever talks about that with her family or colleagues. She said no as she would feel embarrassed talking about such sci-fi things.  I described that it starts with such discussions. Playing with the "what if" question is a wonderful way of developing a mindset for preparing for changes and the use of advanced technologies.  What was the technology you have seen or read about that made you hopeful for the future? title: How To Make Your Product Stand Out With PAINTING
content:
Glaucoma is tough to treat. One of the only indicators of progression for this blinding disease is intra-ocular pressure which squeezes and damages the optical nerve. Injectsense hopes to change this scenario with an ultra-miniature injectable sensor that will track your eye pressure continuously over years, with the resulting data telling doctors what treatment is effective and what is not.  As eye injections are now as common as cataract surgery, this invention may transform the drug development industry. The company has just finished the initial animal tests - we are looking forward to seeing the sensor in clinical tests!

title: The A - Z Guide Of POLITICS

There are some exiting studies that came out in the last 1-2 weeks. Topol's team compared the accuracy of deep learning algorithms to that of medical professionals in making diagnoses on medical images. Besides giving a comprehensive overview of the field (without any hype), they pointed out 5 major issues with those studies. 1) most studies took the approach of assessing diagnostic accuracy in isolation not reflecting clinical practice 2) there were very few prospective studies done in real clinical environments 3) a wide range of metrics were employed to report diagnostic performance 4) there is inconsistency over key terminology 5) most studies did not do an out-of-sample validation for both health-care professionals and deep learning algorithms Read it here:  https://lnkd.in/gFVPT4u Also, some other news: Machine learning could offer faster, more precise results for cardiac MRI scans  http://bit.ly/2oPXnqA Prediction system for risk of allograft loss in patients receiving kidney transplants: international derivation and valhttps://lnkd.in/gyTbbUU #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: Avoid The Top 10 Mistakes Made By Beginning PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
I've tested a myriad of ECG devices that patients can use at home. From Kardia to Viatom Checkme Pro, I've seen a range of hardware and app interfaces. As on the photo,  AliveCor Inc.  obviously stands out. Whenever I mention such technologies in my talks, I get colleagues asking me why a patient would record an ECG at home. I keep on telling them that identifying arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation can be life-saving and that we cannot wait to get checked once every few years at the point-of-care. We want to be the point-of-care. And then this comprehensive study comes out: Screening for Atrial Fibrillation and the Role of Digital Health Technologies It really covers every issue around the subject. It doesn't promote digital health blindly but concludes that while such devices might be used to increase the ease and specificity of screening for AF compared to traditional methods, it still requires further studies. Check it out, it's available in open access. https://lnkd.in/dAR7pwf #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #sensor   #study

What's the difference between health IT and digital health?  Even medical professionals and policy makers confuse these two terms, so I invented the Gary-rule as a simple guideline: If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it, it’s an IT issue.  If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders must get involved, it’s digital health.  You can read the study with extensive clarification and examples in JCTRES:  https://lnkd.in/g2UvetW Which one have you seen being realized at your healthcare provider? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice

title: Marriage And SCIENCE Have More In Common Than You Think
content:
It was really hard to track down the developers of Leela Chess Zero, the highest rated chess engine today, but I managed to find them in a developer forum. It was interesting to learn that the developers are not professional chess players and they don't even need to be to develop such an algorithm.  Imagine the same in medicine. Developers creating the highest rated medical algorithm without having a profound knowledge of medicine. This is the era artificial intelligence is bringing to us. Here is how they described the algorithm works: "Leela Chess uses a neural network trained without human knowledge. The training procedure uses reinforcement learning to train the next generation of the network based on games played using the previous one against itself (“self-play”) so without any external influence. The initial network is trained using random games so there is no human input in the process. The next network improvement comes from using a (small) search tree to improve the neural network’s evaluation of a position and using this outcome, together with the game result, to train the next network. Any principles used during play are discovered this way, but not in a way that can be easily extracted as such. Obviously, the rules of chess are hard-coded in the engine."

It sounds like the sleep tracker jackpot so I had to test it.  Here is what I learnt after the first night.  I don't have sleep apnoe, my sleep score is high but my deep sleep was not long enough. title: The Truth Is You Are Not The Only Person Concerned About CRAFT
content:
The art of medicine is not going to vanish with  the use of A.I., in fact, it’s only getting started. For the past 15 years, I’ve been traveling and giving speeches about the digital health revolution. And wherever I go, I keep hearing the same fears and criticisms against it.  A big part of the medical community simply doesn’t want to embrace something like A.I. as they feel that their job as physicians and their value as a diagnostician will be in danger. They tell me that technology takes away the art of medicine.  But it’s a flawed mindset. And I’d like to use a documentary, AlphaGo, to prove to you that digital technologies are going to be tools in the hands of physicians and they will help us find new and exciting ways to beat deadly diseases and make our lives better.  As I said before, if we embrace these tools, the real art of medicine only begins now: https://lnkd.in/gtfJcRy #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

Here is the second part of the analysis of my genetic test report from Atlas Biomed. I had a call with their microbiome expert and learnt a lot about not only my microbiome but also about the diet I should have.  I'm the "Western gourmand" type which means I'm the victim of the Western diet no matter how hard I fight against it. Thus, I have below average levels of beneficial bacteria and my microbiome diversity is average. I was advised to consume much more fibres and eat types of food that help improve the diversity of the microbiome, especially when it comes to beneficial bacteria. The quick win for me is eating kefir or yoghurt to improve the level of bifidobacteria. Atlas Biomed provides a list of foods I should try every week. I'm happy to share that The Medical Futurist Institute just launched a collaboration with the  American Medical Association . We are now on their Physician Innovation Network (PIN). The PIN is an excellent resource of medical professionals who would like to move medicine forward by discussing challenging issues and sharing best practices. It also gives physicians opportunities to get involved with health tech companies! The AMA has already been showing the way for many medical associations worldwide. First with their Digital Health Implementation Playbook that included key steps, best practices and resources to accelerate the adoption and scale of digital health solutions, and that of telemedicine in particular. title: Never Lose Your MUSIC Again
content:
I received the results of my genetic test with Atlas Biomed. I thought I'd share all the results piece by piece here before publishing the big review on  medicalfuturist.com . Part I. Disease risks They analyzed a lot of polymorphisms in my DNA that have been associated with disease risks. I discussed that with their genetic counselor and she also made it clear that it matters which studies a certain company chooses to base their estimations on. In my case, I have high risk for three conditions (coronary heart disease, ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease). I've seen these in other genetic tests before but my high melanoma risk was not included in the report as they don't check for polymorphisms in cancer. The "average risk" conditions I have are quite common across populations.  Regarding hereditary diseases, I don't carry any of the about 200 conditions they check for. It doesn't mean it's a 100% I don't carry those gene variants but there is a big chance for that. To check for a specific condition, I'd need a more detailed genetic test.  Conclusion: to discuss the prevention plan about coronary heart disease with my GP. In the next posts, I'd describe my nutrition, sports and personal traits & my microbiome analysis. #genetics   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine 
 
 
 …see more

There is an amazing country that uses digital health in the right way! In the keynote I gave about Privacy in the Digital Health Era at the recent GLOBSEC event, I analyzed patients' freedom of choice from the digital health perspective. 1) In China, the freedom of choice patients have about digital health technologies is limited because the government makes them use A.I. and other ways of obtaining data about them. 2) In Rwanda, the freedom of choice is there but limited as otherwise they don't get access to healthcare, only through digital health technologies. 3) In the US, patients have a lot of freedom of choice but without proper incentives, medical professionals are not encouraged to get involved. Which country's example do you think I used as the best in the world? title: 5 Ways Of HR MANAGEMENT That Can Drive You Bankrupt - Fast!
content:
What do you wish you knew before starting your career? I just finished Confessions of a public speaker, a book every speaker should read. I stopped keeping track of how many presentations and keynotes I have given after 500. The book made me think about the one thing that I would have loved to know before even giving a speech. The example I saw back then was that you make a breakthrough (in science, in business, or by publishing a great book, etc.) and then you can ride that wave for many years. I've seen good speakers give the same talk many times. The truth is that in the 21st century it doesn't work. Being a speaker today means that you constantly refresh yourself and the content you present while also making it as spectacular as possible. You have to entertain while keeping your integrity (especially critical for me talking about healthcare). It's a pressing challenge but I've been enjoying this ""ride"" for long. Along these lines, my new keynote narrative entirely dedicated to artificial intelligence in medicine comes out this September. So, what do you wish you knew before starting your career? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

I recently gave a keynote about "Privacy in the Digital Health Era" at GLOBSEC 2019 in Bratislava.  I talked about the advantages of digital health and their impact on my lifestyle that come with privacy issues (sometimes nightmares): - heart rate monitor - fitness smartwatch - dirrect-to-consumer genetic tests - a whole genome sequencing service - microbiome testing - apps logging my habits and even calorie intake - gadgets such as ECG or stress trackers that I use from time to time - and so on. I also mentioned that I'm happy to give up some of my privacy for a chance for a longer and healthier life. I have complete freedom of choice and I will do everything I can to keep it this way. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

Clinical trials today are long and expensive. Pharma companies spend billions of dollars and still, at the end of the day a drug might not become approved. On the one hand, this creates a huge risk for them to invest into innovation, on the other hand patients sometimes have to wait for unnecessarily long until a new drug reaches the market. Moreover, we live in an era when we test new drugs on patients.  In silico clinical trials aided by artificial narrow intelligence have the promise to change this by using less time, money and human resources.  Do you see any ongoing clinical trials which are based on findings from deep or machine learning analyses? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice

title: Get The Most Out of GST and Facebook
content:
If senators don’t understand Facebook, how will they regulate digital health issues? – I asked last year.  http://bit.ly/2XRTQ77 After yesterday’s Facebook Libra hearing before the Senate Banking Committee, I wonder whether Congress is savvy enough to understand Libra to the extent that it can coherently regulate it.  During Tuesday’s two-hours-long session, most of the lawmakers seemed far less concerned with the technology than with Facebook and the series of scandals (which should also be a key issue on the table) around the company in recent years.  Policy-makers must inevitably have a profound knowledge of new technologies so they can make the best decisions when it comes to regulating Libra or when considering complex ethical issues regarding the 3D printing of synthetic tissues, autonomous surgical robots or the use of artificial intelligence in diagnostics. What is your take on that? Image:  pcmag.com #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice

I gave a keynote about Privacy in the Digital Health Era at the recent  GLOBSEC  event and will release the full talk tomorrow! I analyzed this from the perspective of the freedom of choice and used the example of 4 countries. 1) In China, the freedom of choice patients have about digital health technologies is limited because the government makes them use A.I. and other ways of obtaining data about them. 2) In Rwanda, the freedom of choice is there but limited as otherwise they don't get access to healthcare, only through digital health technologies. 3) In the US, patients have a lot of freedom of choice but without proper incentives, medical professionals are not encouraged to get involved. 4) In Estonia, the government designed the right policies to help make patients the point-of-care through digital health by giving patients the real freedom of choice. Subscribe to my YouTube channel and check it out on Wednesday at 6:00 PM EDT:  https://lnkd.in/gvWyHm5 #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

content:
The essence of digital health from a recent paper of The Medical Futurist Institute: "Through the cultural transformation called digital health, the hierarchy of traditional medicine is transforming into an equal-level partnership between patients and caregivers. Besides many disruptive technologies, AI has the biggest potential to support this transition by analyzing the vast amounts of data patients and healthcare institutions record in every moment.  By taking away the repetitive parts of a physician’s job, it might lead to being able to spend more precious time with their patients, improving the human touch. However, AI can only fulfill its mission if it remains a safe, efficient, and proven aid in treating patients and improving healthcare." https://lnkd.in/gRGWDxt #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #TMFI   #research

title: Don't Fall For This BANKING Scam
content:
I hear more and more about Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) while learning about artificial intelligence but I haven't been able to comprehend it properly. Now I just heard a good analogue and I thought I would share it with you.  There is a painter who wants to create better and better fake Picasso paintings and a policeman who wants to spot these fakes with an increasing efficiency. What happens is that the painter keeps getting better at making fakes, while the policeman keeps getting better at detecting those. The two models keep trying to beat each other and after many iterations, the painter creates images indistinguishable from a real Picasso. This was the goal of the whole GAN. It's crucial in medicine where privacy concerns limit the amount of available data because GANs can fill in the missing data, making it possible to produce entirely fabricated patient datasets that are just as useful for training AI as the real thing. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

title: Avoid The Top 10 DRAWING Mistakes
content:
If you are looking for a great example of how artificial intelligence-based algorithms can assist (and not replace) medical professionals, look at the recent paper from the teams of Kristen Yeom and Andrew Ng. They concluded that radiologists could improve their diagnoses of brain aneurysms with the help of an artificial intelligence algorithm developed by medical experts and computer scientists. "Any artificially intelligent algorithm will have strengths and weaknesses that reflect its programming and training. In the case of HeadXNet, the researchers focused on its ability to identify the presence aneurysms rather than on detecting their absence. As a result, HeadXNet improved clinicians’ ability to see aneurysm but didn’t affect their ability to identify scans without them." It's there to make sure they make the best decisions but it doesn't do the job for them. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: 3 Simple Tips For Using ART To Get Ahead Your Competition
content:
Yesterday, I gave a keynote about artificial intelligence's role in healthcare to a biopharma company. One of the best questions I received was about liability. Who is to blame if an A.I. algorithm makes a mistake? This is a recurring issue and I like to answer it with a metaphor. If a physician listens to your heart sounds with a stethoscope and there was something wrong with the device and it misled the diagnosis, who is to blame? The manufacturer of the stethoscope? Never. The physician is supposed to be using all the available technologies at their disposal and with their expertise and knowledge therefore only they can be blamed, the final decision is their responsibility.  The same applies to the use of A.I. It is a (regulated, supervised and assessed) tool in the physician's hand and thus only contributes to the decisions, not making them.  What do you think? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

title: 5 Ways You Can Get More PAINTING While Spending Less
content:
Moravec paradox represents a super exciting issue in the world of artificial intelligence. It basically says that high-level reasoning requires much less computation than low-level sensorimotor skills. In short, it's easier to write a program to be the CEO of a major company than to be a coal miner.  As Hans Moravec writes, "it is comparatively easy to make computers exhibit adult level performance on intelligence tests or playing checkers, and difficult or impossible to give them the skills of a one-year-old when it comes to perception and mobility". Regarding the A.I. era of medicine, it might mean that it makes more sense to teach an algorithm to get better at certain skills important for us working in healthcare than expect programmers to write a code that can do it right away. Meaning we have to be very patient with algorithm when they come to medicine. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney 
 
 
 …see more

title: Should Fixing POLITICAL Take 60 Steps?
content:
Very promising papers come out every day about machine and deep learning algorithms used for medical and healthcare purposes and this field is just blowing up. I received questions from physician colleagues who are not A.I. experts about how they should evaluate these papers. I thought I would share a few things I do myself. - It matters where the paper is published. It's not scientific elitism but it matters if a new algorithm gets presented in Nature Medicine or in a third level journal. - Look for the Methods section where they describe where they got the data. No algorithm can be trained without a good amount of quality data. Some groups just use a good dataset and do tricks on it to make it bigger (e.g. invert images to double the database size). That's not the same as getting a huge amount of annotated data. - Look for the clinical collaboration they had. If an algorithm works well on a pre-selected dataset, that sounds fine. But when it works on clinical datasets too, that is the one we are looking for. When I saw @ DeepMind  collaborating closely with the NHS, I knew that was the right direction. Can you please share the tricks you use while assessing a medical A.I. paper? #digitalhealth   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #TMFchessjourney 
 
 
 …see more

title: If You Do Not (Do)PROGRAMMING Now, You Will Hate Yourself Later
content:
What can you do when doctor shortages do not allow a country to provide care for everyone? You send out junior doctors to rural regions without any major experience. This is where artificial or augmented intelligence can jump in.  A Chinese company, RXThinking, is training medical algorithms to become super-diagnostician that can be dispatched to all corners of China. Instead of replacing physicians with algorithms, RXThinking's A.I.-based diagnosis app empowers them because it acts like a navigation app for the diagnostic process, drawing on all available knowledge to recommend the best route but still letting the physicians control the decision-making process. Just one example how and why A.I. is crucial for solving healthcare's global issues. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning

Many physicians complain today about how hard it is to deal with patients who uses Google to learn about their diagnoses. This is why we released a free guide for them ( http://bit.ly/2CeLRsR ).  I wonder what my peers will complain about when patients start using artificial intelligence-based tools that are available online. An excerpt from the book: "The fact that my lymphoma had affacted over twenty sites, had spread above and below my diaphragm, and had entered an organ outside the lymphatic system meant that I was automatically categorized as a stage IV patient. But what I didn't know at the time of diagnosis was that this crude method of staging has more to do with what medical students can memorize than what modern medicine can cure.  In the depths of my own research, I found a research paper that did quantify the predictive power of these alternate metrics." #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

title: World Class Tools Make PROGRAMMING Push Button Easy
content:
The question about A.I. is never technology vs humans. GM Garry Kasparov introduced the concept of advanced chess, also known as cyborg or centaur chess. He wanted to bring together human and computer skills to achieve the following results: - increasing the level of play to heights never before seen in chess; - producing blunder-free games with the qualities and the beauty of both perfect tactical play and highly meaningful strategic plans; - offering the public an overview of the mental processes of strong human chess players and powerful chess computers, and the combination of their forces. The most exciting medical studies that used machine or deep learning did not conclude that algorithms are better than physicians at doing a specific task but those that showed how the combination of computational and human cognition leads to the best results.  My favorite studies in this are the ones with detecting breast cancer on slides and diabetic retinopathy on retinal images. Excellent results underscoring the notion that artificial narrow intelligence will work with medical professionals and vice versa for the best results.  Have you seen other similar studies concluding the same? Photo source:  Kasparov.com #digitalhealth   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #TMFchessjourney

title: 10 Warning Signs Of Your OPERATING SYSTEM Demise
content:
I started working with IM Ármin Juhász exactly 6 months ago. I started with a  Chess.com  ELO of around 800 and now I'm over 1400. I have learnt a lot of patience, strategy and the joy of learning something new again. Also, I've had about 10 anxiety attacks and even cried a few times because of the failures I've had along the way. You dedicate hours of your already limited time to a task and still learning the game is a very slow process.  I started learning chess to understand better what developers of machine and deep learning algorithms go through while improving their product. Kudos to all of them! It's incredibly hard to excel at a game like chess and they have to train something that has no conscience and they cannot communicate with it. I value the work of anyone being in the field of artificial intelligence even more. During the summer, I'll register at FIDE and will participate in my first real tournaments.  Side note: I hope you get the message of our matching T-shirts and the first one who can tell me which endgame motive we discussed on that board will get a book or ebook for free, I promise. :) #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

title: POLITICAL Expert Interview

The art of medicine is not going to vanish with  the use of A.I., in fact, it’s only getting started. For the past 15 years, I’ve been traveling and giving speeches about the digital health revolution. And wherever I go, I keep hearing the same fears and criticisms against it.  A big part of the medical community simply doesn’t want to embrace something like A.I. as they feel that their job as physicians and their value as a diagnostician will be in danger. They tell me that technology takes away the art of medicine.  But it’s a flawed mindset. And I’d like to use a documentary, AlphaGo, to prove to you that digital technologies are going to be tools in the hands of physicians and they will help us find new and exciting ways to beat deadly diseases and make our lives better. title: Using 7 OPERATING SYSTEM Strategies Like The Pros
content:
Digital health is a cultural transformation. That’s a key message I regularly address in my keynotes and also a basis of The Medical Futurist Institute’s research on the paradigm shift currently taking place in healthcare. Let me demonstrate it through an example.  Brennan Spiegel, MD, MSHS  and the VR clinical research team at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center have been doing a tremendous job assessing the health benefits of virtual reality. They have been experimenting with the technology for several years and found a significant drop in pain scores in case of VR therapies. What strikes me in their story is that the immersive,  multi-sensory environments had a more significant impact on patients when medical professionals participated in the therapy as a guide, introducing the technology gradually and coaching the patient along the session. VR is an area of endless possibilities, but it can demonstrate it’s real effect when it’s combined with the human touch, medical professionals taking up the role of guiding their patients through digital health technologies. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

title: 3 Mistakes In MATHEMATICS That Make You Look Dumb
content:
So I've been progresing in chess studying openings and exercising 2-3 hours every day. I'm around 1400 ELO on  chess.com  (an increase of 600 points since November). I learn so much about how A.I. will be used in medicine on the way. Rudolf Spielmann said that in chess, ""Play the opening like a book, the middle game like a magician, and the endgame like a machine.” There is a huge overlap with how we practice medicine.  The opening is obtaining data and information about patients. It should be done like reading a book. Seamless and by the rules. The middle game is the hard part: making a diagnosis. It is even currently being done like magicians do their job. A lot of people don't understand it but it's fascinating, hard and creative.  The endgame is the therapy and monitoring part which should work like a machine: automated following guidelines. This is only possible by implementing artificial narrow intelligence into the daily work of medical professionals. This is why it's so important to understand the basics of A.I. On the photo, I discuss an opening issue with a potential GM. ☺ #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

title: Listen To Your Customers. They Will Tell You All About MATHEMATICS
content:
A peak flow meter is a handheld device that measures how well air moves out of your lungs. It can measure how narrow your airways are hours, even days, before you have any asthma symptoms. By taking your asthma medicine when your peak flow meter indicates changes – before you notice symptoms – you may be able to avoid a serious asthma episode.  Simple technology that can have a huge impact on someone's life.  The Smart Peakflow device promises the same. I blow into it as hard as I can and it gives me the results on the app. It's that simple. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy   #fromchancetochoice

title: Answered: Your Most Burning Questions About FASHION DESIGN
content:
What would you name as the biggest obstacle for AI adoption in most businesses? Everyone seems to be building artificial intelligence-based software, also in healthcare, but no one talks about one of the most important aspects of the work: data annotation and the people behind it.  That’s the point when we need a deep dive into context: How do you create a smart algorithm? Where and how do you get the data for it? What do you need for a pattern recognizing program to work well and what are the challenges?  Why context matters? It is about asking a lot of questions to show why a particular piece of information, event, technology is important, how these things can provide a way to understand the world. With The Medical Futurist team we help healthcare stakeholders contextualize where they stand in the stream of new trends. So back to the main question, one of the biggest obstacles for AI adoption is the lack of labeled data. We will never have smart algorithms in healthcare without data annotators. https://lnkd.in/gJCUpZs #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

Physicians should experience a shift from the lone wolf to the curious team player, from the rule follower to the creative and from the demigod to the guide in the jungle of digital health. A great summary of what hyperfocus means and how we can achieve that on a daily basis. It also makes a great point about the importance of scattered focus in order to have hyperfocus regularly. title: 27 Ways To Improve DANCE

I've been in touch with the A.I. group of the  American Medical Association  to give feedback on the guide they released. Wonderful job! I wish every medical association would follow AMA's lead (also think about the Digital Health Playbook they made available). The strong points which I have never seen any medical association address properly before: - the concept of "explainable A.I." is brilliant - the levels of A.I. are clearly explained - the need for an A.I. policy and the approach of constantly refining this policy are crucial - the clear definition of augmented intelligence I further recommended addressing how different approaches deep and reinforcement learning require compared to pure machine learning; the essential role of data annotators and why there will be no A.I. without them; and the ultimate experience would be a course based on the Finnish example ( elementsofai.com ). Kudos to the AMA! #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

Between the two states of waking up and needing 3 cups of coffee to start the day and being able to start the day with energy, there might only be two minutes (light vs deep sleep). I'm so happy to share that the World Health Organization asked me to submit a concept paper about digital health and its impact on healthcare which I did with Zsuzsa Győrffy working with me at The Medical Futurist Institute.  We are now having discussions with the WHO whether we can also release the paper in a form. I can't wait to share it with you. Here is the table of contents until then: 1) Introduction 2) Noncommunicable diseases and patients in their new role 3) The summarized evolution of medical technology on the road to digital health 4) Healthcare in the 21st century 5) Technological examples and trends -Social media and smartphone apps -Health sensors -Telemedicine -Portable diagnostic devices -Virtual reality (VR) -Augmented reality (AR) -Direct-to-consumer genomics -Artificial or augmented intelligence -3D printing -Medical transportation organized through patients 6) Ways for tackling these technologies -Improving the doctor-patient relationship -Recommendations for better policies -Innovative health technologies in low-resource regions -Medical and post-graduate education -Advanced patient education -Guidelines adjusted to the 21st century needs 7) Conclusions #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice

title: 4 Ways You Can Grow Your Creativity Using BUSINESS
content:
I often get a question about the issue of privacy in the digital health era after my keynotes. The way I look at this question is always the same.  As long as I'm the one deciding what parts of my privacy I'm willing to give out in exchange for a chance for a healthier and longer life, I'm ethically fine. I've tested so many devices and genetic tests that I'm sure my data has been shared by some of those companies with third parties. But I learnt so much along the way about my health that while such privacy breaches should never happen, I still gained more.  What is your take on this question? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #speaker   #keynote   #speakerlife

content:
Here is another study concluding that an A.I.-based algorithm and physicians working together achieve the best efficiency even in eye care. Ten ophthalmologists were asked to read each image once under one of three conditions: unassisted, grades only, and grades + heat map. They found that A.I. and physicians working together can be more accurate than either alone.  This is the argument I always refer to: the issue is not whether A.I. will replace physicians but how physicians will learn to work together with A.I. to improve their job. https://lnkd.in/gRMMRHx #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney

title: Find A Quick Way To BUSINESS
content:
Yet another example for how a very simple digital health device can improve patients' lives. The Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America describes that a peak flow meter is a handheld device that measures how well air moves out of your lungs. It can measure how narrow your airways are hours, even days, before you have any asthma symptoms. By taking your asthma medicine when your peak flow meter indicates changes – before you notice symptoms – you may be able to avoid a serious asthma episode. I start testing the Smart Peakflow which promises the same. #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #health   #healthy   #fromchancetochoice

title: GST An Incredibly Easy Method That Works For All
content:
Let’s imagine the following situation: A patient walks into your office. They read about genetic testing on the internet and would like your advice about how to proceed further. He has a lot of questions. Is it worth taking a genetic test? What about whole genome sequencing? Which direct-to-consumer genetic test to choose?  That’s a typical situation when the Guide To Ask Me About Digital comes in handy. Browsing through the Guide you will be able to answer all their questions whether it is worth taking a genetic test or trying whole genome sequencing, whether your patient wants to know more about ancestry, health risks, paternity or maternity questions, or perhaps, pharmacogenomics and nutrigenomics. Also, if you are looking for a database to find genetic tests and testing companies, here you will find a curated collection of the latest ones. title: How To Make Your SCIENCE Look Amazing In 5 Days
content:
Health IT vs digital health? Here is the Gary rule to clear up this misconception.  If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue.  If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health. Can you apply the Gary rule to the last technological issue you had? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #fromchancetochoice   #digitization   #electronics   #futurism   #software

title: Best 50 Tips For SCIENCE
content:
I live like someone will live 10 years from now. I got genome sequencing which I discuss regularly with my primary care physician. I improve my sleep quality, daily exercises, stress and many more lifestyle elements with digital health technologies. I monitor parts of my health and lifestyle with the hope to catch diseases early.  Recently, I started finishing my keynotes with saying that I'm the patient of the future, ask me questions.  I know it's a weird idea, but people love it and ask me about my relationship with technologies, when I need a break from them, how I deal with privacy issues and in general, how I try to improve my health with technologies. It's a refreshing experience to see how excited people become when they can ask about the future. title: Why Most People Will Never Be Great At FASHION DESIGN
content:
On my A.I. journey, I just had a workshop with a developer who works with deep and machine learning algorithms. I had a hundred questions and he helped me understand the details of not just these methods but also their implications for medicine and healthcare.  What stroke me the most was what I learnt about reinforcement learning. AlphaGo that beat the world's best GO player (Lee Sedol, on the photo) also used that. It means you describe rules and then let the algorithm get outputs. Then you retrospectively tell the algorithm which output was fine and it creates its own rules for reaching those outputs. Do you know what it means?  It means it's not bound the cognitive limitation of people. Physicians have been accusing me that I want to take away their "art of practicing medicine". I now go further than that. The era of medicine being an art will just begin when reinforcement learning tackles medical tasks. Can you imagine what new ways we will learn about finding cures, treatments and managing conditions? Ways we have never thought of. Just like how AlphaGo made moves nobody made before for thousands of years. What do you think? #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #technology   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #deeplearning   #machinelearning   #TMFchessjourney 
 
 
 …see more

title: The Secret of Successful PAINTING

title: The Biggest Lie In ZOOLOGY
content:
Last November, I decided to start working with a chess trainer because chess is the perfect example for how humans use computers to excel at a task. My theory was that learning to play chess hours every day will help understand better the issues around how humans can work with computers in medicine and healthcare. I'm extremely lucky to have the chance to learn from IM Ármin Juhász who is not only the world's second youngest highest ranked FIDE trainer at the age of 20 with an ELO of around 2400 but also an exceptional teacher who teaches like someone who has been doing this for decades. Besides these, he has a wicked chess humor (so they say...). I dedicate the following weeks to raising issues about the role of artificial intelligence in medicine, healthcare and pharma. As I dive deeper and deeper into these topics, I'll keep on sharing all the experiences, details and questions that arise.  I hope you will follow me on my journey as artificial intelligence is the biggest threat as well as the biggest opportunity for humanity's progress, especially in healthcare. Digital health technologies will only make patients the point-of-care with proper, accurate and safe A.I. #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #AI   #artificialintelligence   #chess   #TMFchessjourney

title: Fall In Love With DRAWING
content:
At the end of last year, the FDA announced that it is reviewing the regulatory issues related to the bioprinting of biological, cellular and tissue-based products to determine whether additional guidance is needed. During the year, the agency organized workshops and meetings to prepare the regulatory body as well as the players of the industry for the coming changes.  I expect that the FDA will update its regulatory framework for bioprinting in 2019, and by the time a bioprinting company issues their first product, it will be ready to face the new challenges. When you want do develop a technology or a product for patients and you know what they want, that's a question of service design. When you don't know what they want or what they will want in the future, you are basically doing forecasting. This is why it's so important to improve skills related to this exciting cognitive game. title: 9 Ways MATHEMATICS Can Make You Invincible
content:
The special issue of The Journal of Clinical and Translational Research just came out. Do you know the difference between health IT and digital health? A lot of people and even large organizations don't. That's why I introduced the Gary-rule in it. Here it is. If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the antivirus software becomes outdated or the electronic medical record system stopped working, and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it whatever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue. If Gary is not enough to address the problem because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g., letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the medical practice and merge that with electronic medical records, or allowing physicians to do remote consultations on a regular basis), it’s digital health. The paper is in open access:  https://lnkd.in/g2UvetW #healthcare   #medicine   #digitalhealth   #healthIT   #future

title: HR MANAGEMENT Strategies For Beginners
content:
A while ago, I mentioned that I would do a workshop for a large organization about the future of digital health and I asked you to share what ultimate health tracker you would like to have in your life and you came up with amazing ideas.  Here a few examples:, enjoy! :) An auto-immune stress sensor that utilizes my DNA and knows which relevant genes have expressed so I can check in periodically on how my body is functioning across the spectrum.  A short-term memory sensor to help me track/trend my short-term memory and provide tips to improve it, including sleep. A blood glucose sensor for diabetics that does not cost our entire month's salary to acquire. Eye monitor so I know it is time to stop looking at the scree n& take a break. The ultimate sleep sensor that regulates and measures melatonin, which you can regulate yourself (night workers, jet lag, etc). Nose sensor measuring quality and quantity of CO2 emitted to calculate base calories consumed and during activities, keto status sensing as add-on for low carbs diets. Sensors suggesting micro and macronutrient a body requires on particular day eg- heavy exercise day or on a relaxed day.

title: Master (Your) BANKING in 5 Minutes A Day
content:
My 2018 in a nutshell:  - 25 minutes of daily intensive exercise (150 hours all together) - an average cognitive score of 7,8 and an emotional score of 8,1 - sleep quality average score is 4,6! - reading paperback books for over 20 minutes every day - lost 2 kg of weight - learned something new 30 minutes a day.  Being a data-maniac, I created a health data system to document my vital signs and the progress towards the goals I set in areas of my life, which I want to improve. Here’s what I learned in 2018 and what you could get to know about yourself with the help of my Excel spreadsheet system about physical, mental and cognitive health. title: Short Story: The Truth About ART
content:
Dr. Zsuzsanna Varga, a primary care physician in Budapest, put the Ask Me About Digital sticker on her door.  She told me: “a young girl came in the other day, who saw the badge earlier that week, so she was brave enough to come in and show me the pictures she took with her phone on her urticaria that only comes in the morning. The patient also told me about how she googled her symptoms but couldn’t find any reasonable explanation. She was happy about the badge because she has mixed experiences of googling and interpreting it to healthcare practitioners. I think it’s a great possibility to get closer to younger generations because she felt safe and understood, so she won’t be hesitating next time she has any problem”.  See more stories:  bit.ly/fromchancetochoice #healthcare   #health   #primarycare   #medicine   #digitalhealth

title: How To Turn Your PROGRAMMING From Zero To Hero
content:
I just watched The American Meme documentary on Netflix and it should be a cautionary tale for all of us who share our lives online. Before, content was the king. Now it's just pure attention.  What I learnt here is not that being an influencer with millions of followers without any "traditional" content or quality is bad. What I learnt that for all of us who discuss health, technology and science online, we need to learn how to get quality attention, not just how to provide quality content. title: What Alberto Savoia Can Teach You About MATHEMATICS
content:
Dr. Freddy Abnousi, Head of Healthcare at Facebook, published a paper with his colleagues in JAMA about Social Determinants of Health in the Digital Age. They argue that: "Social media user profiles represent archives of people’s activities and connections, curated in real time. This information has the potential to improve understanding of the social determinants of health in a deeper way than prior data sources have ever allowed, and, in turn, identify novel targets that could meaningfully influence health outcomes." This would mean a big boost for digital biomarkers. What chance do you think such sets of data have to become biomarkers that could be used in studies? #biomarker   #healthcare   #health   #medicine   #digitalhealth

title: Find Out How I Cured My POLITICS In 2 Days

title: The MUSIC That Wins Customers
content:
The software is designed to detect greater than a mild level of diabetic retinopathy by using an A.I. algorithm to analyze images of the adult eye taken with a special retinal camera. A doctor uploads the images to a cloud server, and the software then delivers a positive or negative result. This is the first device authorized to provide a screening decision without the need for a specialized doctor to interpret the image or results. It's just the beginning. #artificialintelligence   #AI   #innovation   #technology   #healthcare   #medicine

A Chinese scientist shocked the scientific community a couple of days ago with the announcement of having modified the very blueprint of life. If his claims are true, he tried to bestow two baby girls the ability to resist possible future infections with HIV. The outrage shows that humanity is not prepared to utilize the power of gene editing on embryos yet. We have no idea about the biological consequences, and we haven’t tackled the necessary legal and ethical issues.

title: Can You Really Find MUSIC (on the Web)?
content:
My trainer just casually mentioned today whether I have seen the new app on Fitbit: the FREAKING SMART SLEEP ALARM!!! I've been pushing Fitbit for years with articles, videos and posts that they must make it happen as the smart sleep alarm is the Holy Grail of health tracking. Between the two states of waking up and needing 3 cups of coffee to start the day and being able to start the day with energy, there might only be two minutes (light vs deep sleep). A smart alarm helps you wake up only from light sleep to feel better for the whole day. Jackpot! Give me a reason why you would not want this in your life! #themedicalfuturist   #digitalhealth   #future   #healthcare   #medicine   #technology   #wearable   #health   #healthy   #fromchancetochoice

title: 3 Ways Twitter Destroyed My ZOOLOGY Without Me Noticing
content:
Individuals share about 99.97 percent of their DNA and only the remaining 0.03 percent is responsible for the differences in skin, hair or eye color, height, shoe size or sunspots. Scientists discovered somewhat recently that our bodies also metabolize drugs differently so it would make sense to prescribe medications based on the knowledge hidden in our DNA. In some cases, physicians already do that. Here’s what you need to know about pharmacogenomics and the future of prescription drugs. #medicine   #genetics   #personalizedmedicine   #pharmacology   #genetictesting

title: Old School GRAPHIC
content:
At The Medical Futurist Institute, we argue that patient empowerment, the spread of digital health, the bio-psycho-social-digital approach and the disappearance of the ivory tower of medicine lead to a new role for physicians. In a new paper we just submitted to JMIR, we propose that it’s time to EMPOWER PHYSICIANS in the same way patients have been empowered to let them use their unique vision, knowledge and insights to help make the best decisions for patients aided, not replaced, by advanced technologies. The submission is open to peer review which anyone can join. I encourage you to do so.  https://lnkd.in/gwnbGP9 #technology   #socialmedia   #design   #bigdata   #health   #healthcare

title: 12 Questions Answered About ART
content:
I just gave a keynote to  Innomar Strategies  in a beautiful place in North Canada about how it's possible to bring science fiction to the lives of patients and how digital health makes patients the point-of-care. Excellent feedback, even better questions and an open-minded group with a bold vision about the future. On the photo, my amazing host,  Alexandra Novis. One question was particularly interesting, A gentleman asked about the future of privacy in health insurance. I responded that on the nightmare end of the scale (Dr. Big Brother scenario), data cannot be part of the system. No insurance company should be able to raise my premium as I choose a steak over a salad live because they can measure it. The GINA law in the US is a fine example how to avoid that. On the paradise end of the scale (Oscar Health scenario), companies can only reward a healthy lifestyle by sharing data with them. Have you seen good or bad examples worldwide on either end of the scale? #technology   #business   #design   #health   #healthcare   #digitalhealth   #insurance   #future   #keynote   #speaker 
 
 
 …see more

title: Using 7 FASHION DESIGN Strategies Like The Pros
content:
As even organizations like the WHO have been mixing up health IT and digital health, I published an editorial in the Journal of Clinical and Translational Research and introduced the Gary rule to clear up this misconception.  If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue. If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health.  https://lnkd.in/g2UvetW 
 
 
 …see more

title: No More Mistakes With SCIENCE
content:
Zipline was the first company to offer drones for medical purposes. Last October, the Rwandan government teamed up with them to deliver medical supplies to five of its hospitals.  “Every day, we have hundreds of Rwandans lining up along the fence of the distribution center to watch operations. The whole crowd cheers for every single take-off and landing throughout the day. Some people show up at 6 am to get good seats!” says Justin Hamilton, Zipline’s spokesman in our latest interview book. title: How To Make Your Product Stand Out With OPERATING SYSTEM
content:
Are You Going To Wake Up From Cryosleep? - The Medical Futurist Cryonics has been around for more than sixty years, but recently it’s been getting more and more attention as billionaires from the Silicon Valley start to look at it as a real possibility to cheat death. The technology to put people into hibernation is not fictional. Even today, we can freeze people with terminal diseases, and put them in a state of suspended animation for an indefinite time until a cure is found… One tiny problem though. We’re not sure if we can wake them up.

title: 9 Ways HR MANAGEMENT Can Make You Invincible

At The Medical Futurist Institute, we argue that patient empowerment, the spread of digital health, the bio-psycho-social-digital approach and the disappearance of the ivory tower of medicine lead to a new role for physicians. In a new paper we just submitted to JMIR, we propose that it’s time to empower physicians in the same way patients have been empowered to let them use their unique vision, knowledge and insights to help make the best decisions for patients aided, not replaced, by advanced technologies. The submission is open to peer review which anyone can join. I encourage you to do so.  https://lnkd.in/gwnbGP9

title: I Don't Want To Spend This Much Time On GRAPHIC. How About You?
content:
A while ago, I asked you which medical specialty you think will be affected the most by digital health technologies and which ones will remain the same. It seems I opened the box of Pandora with such a questions because I've received an enormous amount of responses, thank you for those! Here are the initial results. Specialties that will change the most on the top (quoting you from the comments): Radiology Family Practice will change to an app or will cease to exist. Dermatology Pathology Oncology Epidemiology Specialties that rely heavily on labs could be affected greatly by the digital health and  #AI  revolution including nephrology, rheumatology and hematology. Endo, GI: Patients get so few minutes with providers, digital will give greater insights while not in the office. Ophthalmology Sports medicine and rehabilitation Specialties that will change the least: Psychiatry Trauma / Emergency medicine Gastro specialists ENT Nursing #technology   #health   #healthcare   #medicine   #future   #digitalhealth   #jobs

title: Short Story: The Truth About BUSINESS
content:
Dr Sudeshan Govender, an Integrated Practitioner practicing in a rural area 50 km outside Durban in South Africa sent us these photos. Inspired by The Medical Futurist, he us using digital innovations to disrupt healthcare delivery in his community.  He told us that ""From EHR adoption 6 years ago, moving the point-of-care from hospicentric to patient centric, using wearables, biosensors and smart devices to finally offering synchronous and asynchronous virtual care. We have successfully assembled multidisciplinary teams to combat numerous chronic conditions. Digital disruptive innovations in healthcare are allowing us to practice at scale without compromising quality."" This is why we launched the Ask Me About Digital campaign.  askmeaboutdigital.com #askmeaboutdigital   #fromchancetochoice   #digitalhealth   #technology   #healthcare

title: Sexy BANKING
content:
We need a new Hippocratic Oath that meets the expectations of the 21st century. The Hippocratic Oath is the most famous text in Western medicine and constitutes the ethical basis of the medical profession. For centuries, it has provided an overview of the principles of this noble mission and doctors’ professional behavior. At the dawn of a new era in medicine, it is high time to rewrite the Oath so that it would reflect the state of technological development, changes in social structures and in general, the requirements of the 21st century.  So far, no leader of a medical school has taken up the challenge of upgrading their oath to the new one.  Which medical school will be the first to properly address the changes of the 21st century?    #medicaleducation   #medicine   #technology   #design   #meded   #future

title: Here Is A Quick Cure For OPERATING SYSTEM
content:
I just received this description of a new project from  http://kiron.nucleode.com /. What do you think? The video shows a 72y old female with a right parasagittal meningioma before a neurosurgery procedure. Using Microsoft HoloLens, the surgeon is able to see a patient-specific 3D model based on the pre-operative MRI, placed with accuracy inside of the patient: in yellow the brain cortex, in green the meningioma and in blue and red the two spino-thalamic tracts. This offers more information to the surgeon, who can better decide the position of the patient for the procedure and the correct approach for the craniotomy and the reaching of the tumor.  https://lnkd.in/gXpfnCG

She said that “a young girl came in the other day, who saw the badge earlier that week, so she was brave enough to come in and show me the pictures she took with her phone on her urticaria that only comes in the morning. The patient also told me about how she googled her symptoms but couldn’t find any reasonable explanation. She was happy about the badge because she has mixed experiences of googling and interpreting it to healthcare practitioners. I think it’s a great possibility to get closer to younger generations because she felt safe and understood, so she won’t be hesitating next time she has any problem”.  #askmeaboutdigital   #fromchancetochoice   #technology   #health   #healthcare   #primarycare

title: The Single Most Important Thing You Need To Know About PHOTOGRAPHY
content:
I ordered steak. The menu item blinked in red twice in my digital lens but I didn’t care. I was very hungry and I love meat. Since it became possible to merge our genomic data with health records in the cloud synchronized with each and every digital device, choosing food has turned into a stressful activity. They wanted to tell me what and when to eat and it has made me crazy. They knew better what me and especially my body needed. My grandfather told me that back in the day nobody knew what the hell you were eating. You just went to a restaurant, ordered and finished your meal. Simple as that. I know they died from a lot of diseases without any foreseeable signs but still. That freedom of choice is special. I don’t even understand why we bother to eat at all today. Just choose whatever is tailored to me and bring it in a powder or something. It’s not worth the effort when it’s so expensive to eat less healthy foods or choose what is out of my metabolic bounds. Sometimes I wish I were in the old ages with infections, sudden deaths, and short lifespans. But man, going out to eat whatever you want must have been a hell of an experience. I get back to my steak, which is obviously artificial but might taste like those dishes my grandfather talked about.

When it’s difficult to draw a line between health IT and digital health, the “Gary-rule” as a general rule of thumb could help. It means that any tech-related issue in a healthcare setting that Gary, the IT guy can solve belongs to health IT. On the other hand, problems in the medical-technological universe, which cannot get resolved without the involvement of other stakeholders of healthcare constitute the terrain of digital health. #health   #healthcare   #technology   #digitalhealth

content:
As even organizations like the WHO have been mixing up health IT and digital health, I published an editorial in the Journal of Clinical and Translational Research and introduced the Gary rule to clear up this misconception.  If a technological issue comes up in a healthcare setting such as the anti-virus software becomes outdated and we have to call Gary, the IT guy, as he is alone capable of solving it what-ever methods he uses, it’s an IT issue.  If Gary is not enough to solve the issue because more stakeholders of healthcare must get involved, (e.g. letting patients bring the data of their trackers into the practice and merging that with electronic medical records), it’s digital health.  http://bit.ly/2CEg4UN #ai   #technology   #health   #healthIT   #digitalhealth   #research

title: Should Fixing BANKING Take 60 Steps?
content:
I followed the Theranos story from the beginning. I wrote about them in 2015 saying that they would decide the fate of medical innovation for some time. If they fail because they lied about their technology, it will doom investors' trust for long. If they succeed, they will rewrite the rule of healthcare. Still, Bad Blood turned out to be one of (if not) the best non-fiction books I've ever read.  Literally, you can't put this book down. It's like Stephen King wrote about digital health. A very dark story that works as a cautionary tale for all of us.  Some things that marked this experience: 1) in digital health you are worth nothing without evidence-based background, 2) if something seems too good to be true, be vigilant, and 3) human decency must remain at the core of what represents us even when we are about to make a huge contribution to healthcare. If you read it, what did you learn? #theranos   #badblood   #book   #reading   #healthcare   #digitalhealth

I loved challenging 4000 medical educators, deans and professors about the need for a new Hippocratic Oath that meets the expectations of the 21st century. The Hippocratic Oath is the most famous text in Western medicine and constitutes the ethical basis of the medical profession. For centuries, it has provided an overview of the principles of this noble mission and doctors’ professional behavior.  At the dawn of a new era in medicine, it is high time to rewrite the Oath so that it would reflect the state of technological development, changes in social structures and in general, the requirements of the 21st century. I look for medical schools that would be brave enough to introduce the new wording. https://lnkd.in/gZte2RR #meded   #medicine   #future   #digitalhealth   #oath20

title: The Next 3 Things To Immediately Do About BUSINESS
content:
I woke up in the morning with a sore throat. I immediately turned to my voice assistant to ask for help. She asked me to take a picture of my throat with a phone and she guided me to make sure I get a photo good enough for analysis. I snapped the picture, uploaded it to her cloud and she responded in a second: "You have a sore throat and let's make sure it will go away as smoothly as possible."  She told me what to have for breakfast, what kind of tea to make and what over-the-counter drug to start with. She also told me she would monitor my vital signs through my skin patch and will let me know if I need antibiotics. I asked her how much time it would take to get better and whether I can work today. She responded with empathy and encouragement sharing the conclusions of analyzing millions of patient journeys with the same issue: "We will take care of it together, don't worry. You are in good hands." After a few days of guidance and suggestions, she made me get better sooner than expected. At not one point I felt alone with my problems. This is primary care in the 2020s and I love chatbots. Well, I wouldn't have enough money to see real a doctor anyway. #chatbot   #ai   #technology   #health   #healthcare

Another good example for shady coverage.  "Watson for Oncology was supposed to synthesize enormous amounts of data and come up with novel insights. But it turns out most of the data fed to it is hypothetical and not real patient data. That means the suggestions Watson made were simply based off the treatment preferences of the few doctors providing the data, not actual insights it gained from analyzing real cases." So it's a matter of bad data management while the title implies that the idea behind using such algorithms for mining data is wrong. It's not.  #ai #business #technology #healthcare #machinelearning

title: Ho To (Do) DRAWING Without Leaving Your Office(House).
content:
Just to clarify, these are not my organs but my heart rate! I got early access to Virtuali-Tee's new heart rate tracker feature. It visualises your own heart rate in augmented reality through the app. It will be a fantastic addition to science lessons bringing a fun new dimension to learning about the heart and circulatory system. My phone's LED got a bit hot during the process but the visualization is excellent as usual! I gave them this feedback and they immediately responded to solve the issue. The app uses your phone's camera to measure the amount of light passing through your fingertip and detects tiny changes as blood passes through to calculate heart rate accordingly. It's being released on the App Store and Google Play on Monday 23rd July.  https://lnkd.in/eq_6nEA #digitalhealth #meded #education #ar #augmentedreality
